{"timeCrawl": "15:27:00", "uri": "709837904", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:27:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "Business Recorder", "uri": "brecorder.com", "id": "1214"}, "url": "http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/15/364906/uk-to-seek-temporary-customs-union-after-brexit/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON: Britain said on Tuesday it would seek a \"temporary customs union\" with the European Union after Brexit, in an opening gambit for trade negotiations that received a cool response from Brussels.\n\nThe government said broadly similar arrangements could apply to EU-UK trade in goods as they do now for around two years, to allow businesses longer to adapt to new post-Brexit systems.\n\nUnlike at present, however, Britain said it wanted to be able to negotiate free trade agreements with third countries during the interim period which would then be implemented afterwards.\n\n\"It's much more sensible, we think, if there is a shortish period in which we maintain the current arrangements,\" Brexit minister David Davis told BBC radio, adding that it could last \"something like two years\" -- ending before the 2022 election.\n\nThe proposal for a transitional arrangement was welcomed by the Confederation of British Industry, Britain's big business lobby group, but critics dismissed it as a \"fantasy\".\n\nThe European Commission, the EU's executive arm, said it would \"take note\" of the proposals, but warned: \"'Frictionless trade' is not possible outside the single market and customs union.\"\n\nEU chief negotiator Michel Barnier also repeated that talks on the future trading relationship could not begin until progress was made on other issues, including Britain's exit bill.\n\n- 'Clock is ticking' -\n\nBritain says its membership of the EU customs union, which allows for the tariff-free movement of goods, will end along with its membership of the single market -- its largest trading partner -- when it leaves the bloc in March 2019.\n\nExperts have warned it will be extremely difficult, if not impossible, to negotiate a new EU-UK free trade agreement before then, raising fears of a damaging \"cliff-edge\".\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU,\" the Brexit ministry said.\n\nThe CBI's deputy director Josh Hardie said the government's proposal was \"encouraging\", but added: \"The clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible.\"\n\nIn a policy paper published on Tuesday, Britain said it could streamline and simplify trade arrangements with the EU once it has left the customs union.\n\nBut it admitted there would be \"an increase in administration compared with being inside the EU customs union\".\n\nAn alternative would be a new customs partnership in which Britain effectively adopts the EU's external customs border to allow for free EU-UK trade, but applies its own trade policy and tariff for imports and exports with third countries destined only for the UK market.\n\nBut in recognition of the huge practical challenges that Brexit presents, the policy paper acknowledged this was \"an innovative and untested approach\".\n\n- 'Wishful thinking' -\n\nA third round of Brexit negotiations is due to begin at the end of August, focused on Britain's financial settlement, the issue of expatriate rights, and the border between British-controlled Northern Ireland and Ireland.\n\nLondon argues that customs arrangements are crucial to resolving the Irish border issue, on which it plans to publish further proposals on Wednesday.\n\nBut Brussels insists there must be broad agreement on the three priority issues before trade negotiations begin, by the EU leaders' summit in October at the earliest.\n\n\"The quicker UK & EU 27 agree on citizens, settling accounts and Ireland, the quicker we can discuss customs and future relationship,\" Barnier said on Twitter.\n\nOpposition Labour lawmaker Chris Leslie, from the campaign group Open Britain, said the proposal for an interim customs union represented \"wishful thinking of the highest order\".\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union,\" he said.\n\nGuy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's outspoken Brexit negotiator, added: \"To be in & out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy.\"", "id": "9306633", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "UK to seek 'temporary customs union' after Brexit | Business Recorder", "image": {"timeCrawl": "12:59:00", "uri": "709771248", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:59:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "Port Stephens Examiner", "uri": "portstephensexaminer.com.au", "id": "3423"}, "url": "http://www.portstephensexaminer.com.au/story/4858286/uk-reveals-not-one-but-two-options-for-post-brexit-borders/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "More than a year after the Brexit referendum the UK has revealed its plan for its post-Brexit trade borders: or rather two plans, which are incompatible with each other.\n\nMore than a year after the Brexit referendum the UK has revealed its plan for its post-Brexit trade borders: or rather two plans, which are incompatible with each other.\n\nView More Local BusinessList Your Business Here\n\nUnder one option, a \"new customs partnership\" would succeed the current customs union, which the UK government said would remove the need for a customs border with the EU but still leave it free it to strike new trade deals with other countries.\n\nUnder the other, technology and bureaucracy would combine to create a \"streamlined\" and \"frictionless\" customs border between the UK and EU to minimise the impact of Brexit on trade and commerce.\n\nThe plans, published on Tuesday in a long-anticipated position paper, also contemplate a temporary customs union with Europe following Brexit, to give countries more time to put border checks and infrastructure in place after the UK leaves the European Union in March 2018.\n\nBut the government's plan - which it admitted was \"unprecedented\" - has already faced criticism from many sides.\n\nSome called it wishful thinking from \"the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it\", and others calling it a \"Brexit betrayal\" against the will of the British people.\n\nThe UK also wants the freedom to strike new trade deals with other countries such as Australia during the transition phase - deals which would come into effect once the transition is over.\n\nBrexit secretary David Davis could not say how long the temporary arrangement would last. He estimated to the BBC \"something like two years, maybe a bit shorter\", and said it would end by 2022 at the latest.\n\nThe paper also sets out two alternatives for a permanent customs arrangement with the EU. It does not say which the government prefers, calling them \"two broad approaches the UK could adopt\" depending on negotiations with the EU.\n\nUnder one, a \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\", the UK and EU would use \"technology-based solutions\" to make it easier for businesses to satisfy new requirements and procedures when moving goods across the border.\n\nUnder the other, the UK would sign a \"new customs partnership\" with the EU that would eliminate the need for a border - for example mirroring EU requirements for imports from the rest of the world where the final destination is the EU.\n\nInternational Trade Secretary Dr Liam Fox said leaving the customs union would allow Britain to generate \"fully independent trade policy\".\n\n\"We will seek a new customs arrangement that ensures that trade between the UK and the EU remains as frictionless as possible and allows us to forge new trade relationships with our partners in Europe and around the world,\" he said.\n\nA European Commission spokesman they would study the UK position paper ahead of the next round of negotiations at the end of August.\n\nHowever they do not want to start talking about customs plans until they have made more progress on talks over the \"divorce bill\" - an agreement on the Brexit financial settlement as well as issues including the rights of EU citizens in the UK.\n\n\"We take note of the UK's request for an implementing period and its preferences as regards the future relationship, but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal,\" the spokesman said.\n\n\"An agreement on a future relationship between the EU and the UK can only be finalised once the UK has become a third country??? 'frictionless trade' is not possible outside the single market and customs union.\"\n\nThe EU is also working on a position paper on the customs union.\n\nMr Davis said during the transition period Britain would be able to negotiation new trade deals.\n\n\"We should be able to have an arrangement where we can do the negotiations, sign it off, but not enter into effect,\" he said.\n\nBut former European commissioner for trade Karel de Gucht told the BBC he doubted the EU would agree to a temporary customs union if it also meant Britain could start working on other trade deals.\n\nOtherwise the EU would effectively be agreeing to help the UK undercut EU tariffs, he said.\n\nInstead, he predicted, the EU would want the UK to stay in the customs union on its own terms: paying contributions to the EU budget and not seeking to sign other trade deals.\n\n\"It's a quagmire, you know,\" he said.\n\nIreland's EU commissioner Phil Hogan told the Financial Times that Dublin could block a customs deal unless the problem of the Northern Ireland border was satisfactorily solved.\n\n\"There's a high level of delusion in London at the moment about what is required to be done,\" Mr Hogan said.\n\nThe government is expected to publish its plan for the border on Wednesday.\n\nThe customs plan is being seen as a concession towards a 'soft Brexit' that has been sought by companies and other groups worried about the impact of a rushed exit from Europe.\n\nThe Federation of Small Businesses said it \"would give small businesses the time they need to prepare for new customs arrangements, which is very welcome\".\n\nBut the official Leave campaign called it a \"Brexit betrayal\", saying it was a \"stitch-up to delay global trade for years\".\n\n\"When 17.4 million voted Leave last year we wanted to control our destiny as a trading nation,\" the Leave.EU Twitter account said. \"This new plan is a disgrace!\"\n\nWhen 17.4m voted Leave last year we wanted to control our destiny as a trading nation. This new plan is a disgrace!https://t.co/Ylk1eQKiNvpic.twitter.com/cw2ZaE33ui??? LEAVE.EU ???????? (@LeaveEUOfficial) August 15, 2017\n\nFormer UKIP leader Nigel Farage said \"I warned of the great Brexit betrayal two weeks ago. It is now official government policy.\"\n\nLabour's Shadow Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union Keir Starmer said the government's plans were \"incoherent and inadequate proposals designed to gloss over deep and continuing divisions within the cabinet\".\n\nAnd anti-Brexit Labour MP Chris Leslie told Politico the government had returned \"to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it\".\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union,\" he said.\n\n\"This is wishful thinking of the highest order.\"\n\nThe story UK reveals not one, but two options for post-Brexit borders first appeared on The Sydney Morning {"timeCrawl": "10:30:00", "uri": "709705829", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T10:30:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "News18", "uri": "news18.com", "id": "2489"}, "url": "http://www.news18.com/news/world/britain-asks-for-interim-customs-deal-with-eu-new-trade-deals-post-brexit-1492043.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "London: Britain has said it wants an interim customs agreement with the European Union after Brexit to allow the freest possible trade of goods, but that it will also seek the right to negotiate other trade deals -- a possible sticking point in the talks.\n\nAccording to excerpts of a government document to be published on Tuesday setting out Britain's strategy, the government will say one option to minimise friction when it leaves the bloc in March 2019 would be to introduce a temporary customs union, which should be \"time-limited\".\n\nThat would provide certainty for businesses, the government said, aiming to address a main concern of companies who fear the introduction of customs checks will cause expensive delays.\n\n\"Ministers will announce an intention to seek an 'interim' period with the EU of close association with the customs union that would allow for a smooth and orderly transfer to the new regime,\" the government said in a statement ahead of publication of the first in a series of \"future partnership papers\".\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU ... During this interim period, which will be negotiated with Brussels, Britain will look to negotiate bold new trade relationships around the world.\"\n\nBusinesses welcomed the proposals, but the Confederation of British Industry also warned the government that \"the clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible\".\n\nEU WANTS PROGRESS ON WITHDRAWAL\n\nThe EU said it would study the proposals carefully but it would only address the proposal for an implementation period once sufficient progress had been made on Britain's withdrawal.\n\nThe EU wants to make progress on several key issues by October, including the financial bill for Britain's exit, but Brexit minister David Davis told the BBC there would not be an agreed figure on the financial settlement by then.\n\n\"We're going to talk it through very, very carefully, so at this stage we're not going to commit,\" he said.\n\nHe later told LBC Radio: \"We're going to have a long haggle ... (EU chief negotiator) Michel (Barnier) is getting quite cross with us. He's saying 'You should make your proposal'.\"\n\nDavis said Britain should not have to pay to have a temporary customs union with the EU. Any transitional period would most likely last for two years, he added, and must be over by the time of the next British national election, due in 2022.\n\nIn an effort to move the talks with the EU on to the issue of Britain's future relationship, Prime Minister Theresa May and her government had promised to publish a series of policy documents this week.\n\nBut after being accused by some EU officials of being ill prepared for the first rounds of negotiations, the government's demand to secure trade deals while participating in a temporary customs union may cause further problems.\n\n\"It looks like the new unified position in the cabinet is to return the government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it\", said Chris Leslie, a pro-EU campaigner and member of Britain's opposition Labour Party.\n\nTURKISH ARRANGEMENT?\n\nCountries that are part of the EU's customs union are not allowed to negotiate bilateral trade deals, and May's government has said Brexit means Britain must leave the customs union.\n\nBut Turkey, while not an EU member, is part of a separate customs union for industrial goods and can still negotiate bilateral trade deals. It was not clear whether Britain was pursuing a similar arrangement to Turkey.\n\nThe government said that, by sorting out the customs arrangements, Britain and the bloc could avoid a \"hard border\" with EU member state Ireland, something that officials fear could reignite tensions between Irish nationalists and unionists in British-ruled Northern Ireland.\n\nIt proposed two different approaches -- a highly streamlined customs arrangement managed by Britain, or a new customs partnership with the EU -- that it said could \"negate the need for a customs border\".\n\nThe government will set out its proposed solutions for the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland in detail on Wednesday.\n\nThe position papers are intended to flesh out the government's Brexit vision and show a united stance over the future relationship after rifts emerged among ministers.", "id": "9255196", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Britain Asks for Interim Customs Deal With EU, New Trade {"timeCrawl": "22:01:00", "uri": "709997468", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T22:01:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "Japan Today", "uri": "japantoday.com", "id": "18472"}, "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/world/update-3-real-thing-or-just-fantasy-britain-proposes-new-eu-customs-deal", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Britain outlined plans for a future customs agreement with the European Union on Tuesday and an interim deal to ease companies' Brexit concerns, proposals one senior EU official described as \"fantasy\".\n\nAfter a slow start to negotiations to end more than 40 years of union, Prime Minister Theresa May's government is keen for the discussion to move beyond the EU's focus on a divorce agreement to consider how a new relationship could work.\n\nThe EU said it would \"carefully\" study the proposals, including measures for an interim customs agreement and two suggestions for a new trade partnership, but the terms of divorce needed to be settled first.\n\nBritain's Brexit minister, David Davis, said in a statement:\"The UK is the EU's biggest trading partner so it is in the interest of both sides that we reach an agreement on our future relationship.\n\n\"The UK starts from a strong position and we are confident we can deliver a result that is good for business here in the UK and across the EU.\"\n\nBritain lost a battle earlier this year to discuss the immediate divorce and future ties alongside each other.\n\nThe EU said the two sides must first make progress on the rights of expatriates, Britain's border with EU member Ireland and a financial settlement, the lack of progress on which Davis said had made the EU's chief negotiator \"quite cross\".\n\nWhile welcoming the proposals, the European Commission, the EU's executive, again said it would not budge from its stance that progress on the divorce needed to be made first.\n\nGuy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's Brexit point-man, underlined the distance between the two sides.\n\n\"To be in and out of the customs union and 'invisible borders' is a fantasy,\" he said on Twitter. \"First need to secure citizens rights and a financial settlement\"\n\nIn what it described as the first of a series of \"future partnership papers\", Britain outlined two possible approaches to a new customs relationship with the EU after leaving the bloc and its customs union.\n\nIt described a \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\" that would borrow from existing systems while expanding the use of technology, or a new customs partnership that could mirror the EU's requirements for imports from the rest of the world.\n\nBritain also wants an interim customs agreement to allow the freest possible trade of goods by removing the threat of costly logjams at borders and to enable businesses to adapt to any future customs arrangement after leaving the bloc in March 2019.\n\nDavis said Britain should not have to pay to have a temporary customs union with the EU. Any transitional period would most likely last for two years and must be over by the time of the next British election, due in 2022, he said.\n\nBut May's government, which hopes that the publication of its thinking will paper over the cracks between ministers on Brexit, will also demand that Britain should be able to negotiate deals with other countries during the interim period - a potential sticking point with the EU.\n\nOpposition politicians criticised the government for wanting to have \"their cake and eat it\", while pro-Brexit campaigners said Britain was taking a \"defeatist attitude\" by accepting it could not implement new trade deals during the interim period.\n\nCountries that are part of the EU's customs union are not allowed to negotiate bilateral trade deals, and May's government has said Brexit means Britain must leave the customs union.\n\nBut Turkey, while not an EU member, is part of a separate customs union for industrial goods and can still negotiate bilateral trade deals.\n\nBritain said that \"while the government has looked at precedents set by customs agreements between other countries, it is not seeking to replicate another country's model\".\n\nThe government said that, by sorting out the customs arrangements, Britain and the bloc could avoid a \"hard border\" with EU member state Ireland, something that officials fear could reignite tensions between Irish nationalists and unionists in British-ruled Northern Ireland.\n\nThe government will set out its proposed solutions for the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland in detail on Wednesday.\n\n\"Our proposals are ambitious, and rightly so,\" finance minister Philip Hammond said in a statement.\n\n\"They set out arrangements that would allow UK businesses to continue to trade with their European partners in the future, while expanding their markets beyond the EU.\"\n\n\u00a9 (c) Copyright Thomson Reuters 2017.", "id": "9364714", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "10:53:00", "uri": "709715204", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T10:53:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "EurActiv.com", "uri": "euractiv.com", "id": "6591"}, "url": "http://www.euractiv.com/section/uk-europe/news/uk-floats-post-brexit-interim-customs-deal-idea/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "It is not clear from the UK government's plan whether London wants to pursue an agreement similar to the customs union Turkey has with the EU. [Shutterstock]\n\nThe United Kingdom has said it wants an interim customs agreement with the European Union after Brexit to allow the freest possible trade of goods, but that it will also seek the right to negotiate other trade deals - a possible sticking point in the talks.\n\nAccording to excerpts of a government document to be published on Tuesday (15 August) setting out Britain's strategy, the government will say one option to minimise friction when it leaves the bloc in March 2019 would be to introduce a temporary customs union, which should be \"time-limited\".\n\nThat would provide certainty for businesses, the government said, aiming to address a main concern of companies who fear the introduction of customs checks will cause expensive delays.\n\n\"Ministers will announce an intention to seek an 'interim' period with the EU of close association with the customs union that would allow for a smooth and orderly transfer to the new regime,\" the government said in a statement ahead of publication of the first in a series of \"future partnership papers\".\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU... During this interim period, which will be negotiated with Brussels, Britain will look to negotiate bold new trade relationships around the world.\"\n\nBusinesses welcomed the proposals, but the Confederation of British Industry also warned the government that \"the clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible\".\n\nEU demands progress\n\nThe EU said it would study the proposals carefully but it would only address the proposal for an implementation period once sufficient progress had been made on Britain's withdrawal.\n\nThe EU wants to make progress on several key issues by October, including the financial bill for Britain's exit, but Brexit minister David Davis told the BBC there would not be an agreed figure on the financial settlement by then.\n\n\"We're going to talk it through very, very carefully, so at this stage we're not going to commit,\" he said.\n\nHe later told LBC Radio: \"We're going to have a long haggle ... (EU chief negotiator) Michel (Barnier) is getting quite cross with us. He's saying 'You should make your proposal'.\"\n\nDavis said Britain should not have to pay to have a temporary customs union with the EU. Any transitional period would most likely last for two years, he added, and must be over by the time of the next British national election, due in 2022.\n\nIn an effort to move the talks with the EU on to the issue of Britain's future relationship, Prime Minister Theresa May and her government had promised to publish a series of policy documents this week.\n\nBut after being accused by some EU officials of being ill prepared for the first rounds of negotiations, the government's demand to secure trade deals while participating in a temporary customs union may cause further problems.\n\n\"It looks like the new unified position in the cabinet is to return the government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it\", said Chris Leslie, a pro-EU campaigner and member of Britain's opposition Labour Party.\n\nTurkey model?\n\nCountries that are part of the EU's customs union are not allowed to negotiate bilateral trade deals, and May's government has said Brexit means Britain must leave the customs union.\n\nBut Turkey, while not an EU member, is part of a separate customs union for industrial goods and can still negotiate bilateral trade deals. It was not clear whether Britain was pursuing a similar arrangement to Turkey.\n\nThe government said that, by sorting out the customs arrangements, Britain and the bloc could avoid a \"hard border\" with EU member state Ireland, something that officials fear could reignite tensions between Irish nationalists and unionists in Northern Ireland.\n\nIt proposed two different approaches - a highly streamlined customs arrangement managed by Britain, or a new customs partnership with the EU - that it said could \"negate the need for a customs border\".\n\nThe government will set out its proposed solutions for the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland in detail on Wednesday (16 August).\n\nThe position papers are intended to flesh out the government's Brexit vision and show a united stance over the future relationship after rifts emerged among ministers.", "id": "9258952", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "UK floats post-Brexit interim customs deal idea", "image": {"timeCrawl": "13:17:00", "uri": "709779664", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:17:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "The Border Mail", "uri": "bordermail.com.au", "id": "3421"}, "url": "http://www.bordermail.com.au/story/4858286/uk-reveals-not-one-but-two-options-for-post-brexit-borders/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "More than a year after the Brexit referendum the UK has revealed its plan for its post-Brexit trade borders: or rather two plans, which are incompatible with each other.\n\nMore than a year after the Brexit referendum the UK has revealed its plan for its post-Brexit trade borders: or rather two plans, which are incompatible with each other.\n\nView More Local BusinessList Your Business Here\n\nUnder one option, a \"new customs partnership\" would succeed the current customs union, which the UK government said would remove the need for a customs border with the EU but still leave it free it to strike new trade deals with other countries.\n\nUnder the other, technology and bureaucracy would combine to create a \"streamlined\" and \"frictionless\" customs border between the UK and EU to minimise the impact of Brexit on trade and commerce.\n\nThe plans, published on Tuesday in a long-anticipated position paper, also contemplate a temporary customs union with Europe following Brexit, to give countries more time to put border checks and infrastructure in place after the UK leaves the European Union in March 2018.\n\nBut the government's plan - which it admitted was \"unprecedented\" - has already faced criticism from many sides.\n\nSome called it wishful thinking from \"the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it\", and others calling it a \"Brexit betrayal\" against the will of the British people.\n\nThe UK also wants the freedom to strike new trade deals with other countries such as Australia during the transition phase - deals which would come into effect once the transition is over.\n\nBrexit secretary David Davis could not say how long the temporary arrangement would last. He estimated to the BBC \"something like two years, maybe a bit shorter\", and said it would end by 2022 at the latest.\n\nThe paper also sets out two alternatives for a permanent customs arrangement with the EU. It does not say which the government prefers, calling them \"two broad approaches the UK could adopt\" depending on negotiations with the EU.\n\nUnder one, a \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\", the UK and EU would use \"technology-based solutions\" to make it easier for businesses to satisfy new requirements and procedures when moving goods across the border.\n\nUnder the other, the UK would sign a \"new customs partnership\" with the EU that would eliminate the need for a border - for example mirroring EU requirements for imports from the rest of the world where the final destination is the EU.\n\nInternational Trade Secretary Dr Liam Fox said leaving the customs union would allow Britain to generate \"fully independent trade policy\".\n\n\"We will seek a new customs arrangement that ensures that trade between the UK and the EU remains as frictionless as possible and allows us to forge new trade relationships with our partners in Europe and around the world,\" he said.\n\nA European Commission spokesman they would study the UK position paper ahead of the next round of negotiations at the end of August.\n\nHowever they do not want to start talking about customs plans until they have made more progress on talks over the \"divorce bill\" - an agreement on the Brexit financial settlement as well as issues including the rights of EU citizens in the UK.\n\n\"We take note of the UK's request for an implementing period and its preferences as regards the future relationship, but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal,\" the spokesman said.\n\n\"An agreement on a future relationship between the EU and the UK can only be finalised once the UK has become a third country??? 'frictionless trade' is not possible outside the single market and customs union.\"\n\nThe EU is also working on a position paper on the customs union.\n\nMr Davis said during the transition period Britain would be able to negotiation new trade deals.\n\n\"We should be able to have an arrangement where we can do the negotiations, sign it off, but not enter into effect,\" he said.\n\nBut former European commissioner for trade Karel de Gucht told the BBC he doubted the EU would agree to a temporary customs union if it also meant Britain could start working on other trade deals.\n\nOtherwise the EU would effectively be agreeing to help the UK undercut EU tariffs, he said.\n\nInstead, he predicted, the EU would want the UK to stay in the customs union on its own terms: paying contributions to the EU budget and not seeking to sign other trade deals.\n\n\"It's a quagmire, you know,\" he said.\n\nIreland's EU commissioner Phil Hogan told the Financial Times that Dublin could block a customs deal unless the problem of the Northern Ireland border was satisfactorily solved.\n\n\"There's a high level of delusion in London at the moment about what is required to be done,\" Mr Hogan said.\n\nThe government is expected to publish its plan for the border on Wednesday.\n\nThe customs plan is being seen as a concession towards a 'soft Brexit' that has been sought by companies and other groups worried about the impact of a rushed exit from Europe.\n\nThe Federation of Small Businesses said it \"would give small businesses the time they need to prepare for new customs arrangements, which is very welcome\".\n\nBut the official Leave campaign called it a \"Brexit betrayal\", saying it was a \"stitch-up to delay global trade for years\".\n\n\"When 17.4 million voted Leave last year we wanted to control our destiny as a trading nation,\" the Leave.EU Twitter account said. \"This new plan is a disgrace!\"\n\nWhen 17.4m voted Leave last year we wanted to control our destiny as a trading nation. This new plan is a disgrace!https://t.co/Ylk1eQKiNvpic.twitter.com/cw2ZaE33ui??? LEAVE.EU ???????? (@LeaveEUOfficial) August 15, 2017\n\nFormer UKIP leader Nigel Farage said \"I warned of the great Brexit betrayal two weeks ago. It is now official government policy.\"\n\nLabour's Shadow Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union Keir Starmer said the government's plans were \"incoherent and inadequate proposals designed to gloss over deep and continuing divisions within the cabinet\".\n\nAnd anti-Brexit Labour MP Chris Leslie told Politico the government had returned \"to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it\".\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union,\" he said.\n\n\"This is wishful thinking of the highest order.\"\n\nGuy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's chief Brexit negotiator, also suggested the UK's plan was unrealistic, Tweeting: \"To be in & out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy.\"\n\nTo be in & out of the Customs Union & \"invisible borders\" is a fantasy. {"timeCrawl": "10:23:00", "uri": "709702433", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T10:23:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "MyMcMurray", "uri": "mymcmurray.com", "id": "1171"}, "url": "http://www.mymcmurray.com/2017/08/15/uk-says-it-may-seek-temporary-customs-union-with-eu/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON - Britain might seek to remain in a customs union with the European Union for a time to avoid border chaos after leaving the bloc, the government's Brexit department said Tuesday.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said there could be \"a temporary customs union between the U.K. and the EU\" to help businesses make the transition to life outside the EU.\n\nAnd it said a future \"customs partnership\" could eliminate the need for a border for goods travelling between Britain and the EU.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said the transition period would likely last about two years, and would be replaced by a new deal offering \"extremely slick, extremely streamlined customs arrangements.\"\n\nSome British businesses have accused the government of being vague about whether there will be economic barriers with the EU after Brexit in March 2019. The persistent uncertainty -- 14 months after Britain voted to leave the EU -- is weighing on the economy.\n\nTrade Secretary Liam Fox and Treasury chief Philip Hammond wrote in the Sunday Telegraph that in 2019 Britain will leave both the EU's single market in goods and services and its customs union.\n\nThe single market ensures tariff-less trade in goods and services and is linked closely by the EU with other rights, such as the right of EU citizens to cross borders. The customs union allows goods to move within the EU without checks, but also imposes tariffs on imports from outside the EU. That would prevent Britain striking new free trade deals while it remains inside the arrangement.\n\nThe British proposal says the U.K. should be free to negotiate new trade relationships during the transition period, something EU officials are likely to find problematic.\n\nEU officials say Britain's stated goal of \"frictionless\" trade is impossible outside the single market and customs union.\n\nThe British government is trying to rebuff claims by EU officials that it is has been underprepared for divorce negotiations before a new round of talks in Brussels at the end of this month.\n\nThe customs proposals are the first in a series of papers covering thorny issues in the negotiations. Another, on the status of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, is due to be published this week.\n\nThe European Commission said it took note of Britain's suggestions, \"but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal\" from the bloc.\n\nThe EU says negotiations on its future relations with Britain can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to settle its outstanding commitments to the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of 3 million EU nationals living in Britain.", "id": "9253841", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "UK says it may seek {"timeCrawl": "05:31:00", "uri": "710123934", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T05:31:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/britain-s-brexit-fudge-will-not-fly-with-the-rest-of-the-eu-1.3187638", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The document from the British government on how trade might operate after Brexit shows how politics and economics are colliding to create chaos. London has tried to cover up the cracks in the British cabinet by dancing around the key decisions, while at the same time seeking to assure British businesses that it does not plan to crash out of the EU without a deal on what happens next.\n\nThe result is a fudge which will not fly with the rest of the EU. This plan will not survive contact with the enemy when the British negotiators get to Brussels.\n\nBefore Brexit we did not spend much of our time talking about the EU customs union. It is the agreement which allows goods to circulate freely within the EU. It also means that goods imported from outside the EU can move without restriction around the EU, once they clear customs at the first point of entry.\n\nIt is a normal part of business now for companies across the union - and in Britain - for example allowing car parts to be manufactured in France and assembled in the UK, or goods to move from Ireland through the UK for onward sale in Germany, France or wherever.\n\nBritain is trying to hold on to the advantages of this - in so far as it can - while at the same time winning flexibility to negotiate new trade deals with other countries, such as the US. At the same time, London is trying to come up with a plan which keeps the hard Brexit lobby happy, while at the same time avoiding the cliff-edge fall out of the EU in March 2019 which business fears.\n\nThe resulting confusion is best seen in its approach to the customs union. It would make sense for Britain to propose to remain in the customs union, certainly for a transition period after Brexit and - from an economic point of view - beyond that as well.\n\nHowever the hard Brexit lobby insists \"Brexit means Brexit\" and Britain must leave the EU single market and the customs union. To try to ride both horses at once, the document suggests that Britain will leave the customs union when it leaves the EU in March 2019, but that it will seek to have an interim period when it would have a \"continued close association with the EU customs union for a time-limited period after the UK has left the EU\". This, it says, could involve a common external tariff and no customs processes and duties between the UK and the EU.\n\nNow, using the duck test, this would mean in effect that Britain wants to remain a member of the customs union, in all but name, during the interim period. But at the same time it would see itself as free to start trade negotiations with other third countries. This won't fly with the rest of the EU. Why should they agree to it? They are likely to tell Britain that it is either in or out of the customs union during any transition - and if it is in, it plays by all the rules. This has echoes of the wider Brexit dilemma for Britain - it can't hold on to the advantages of EU membership, while at the same time implementing its own policies in areas such as immigration.\n\nBeyond the transition period, wider questions appear about a long-term UK/EU trade deal. The paper sees two possible solutions. One is to erect customs borders, but to try to keep them as seamless as possible. There is no doubt that advanced IT can help, but a border is still a border and the paper concedes that the administrative burden on business will rise. The economic nonsense of Brexit is exposed again - a whole load of new IT and customs investment for something that is worse than the situation which currently exits.\n\nThe second option seen by the paper in the longer term is some kind of new customs union deal between Britain and the EU, which the document says could avoid the need for a UK/EU goods border. This looks even less likely to come into being .\n\nThe key issue here is how to control goods entering Britain from third countries and ensure the correct rules and tariffs are applied before they enter the EU. The document makes suggestions on policing this, but they don't look very convincing. Also, the same issue applies for the EU. Why sign up to this deal which gives Britain so many benefits of a customs union without the same obligations as the rest?\n\nGiven the incoherence of the British approach, the best strategy for Ireland - for the moment at least - seems to be to keep pushing for Britain to remain in the customs union. The document says that it won't, but a lot of talking still lies ahead.\n\nWe also need to play the Border card as hard as possible. The British paper rules out Border controls between the North and the UK. This means that if Britain is out of the customs union, a Border will be needed on the island. This is where we need to dig in.\n\nW e also need to be ready for some serious rows when the talks start again in a few weeks, with all the unwelcome uncertainty that will bring. The most overused phrase we will hear about Brexit in the weeks ahead is \"the clock is ticking\". But, as ever, it is.", "id": "9408814", "details": {"liCnt": 13}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Britain's Brexit fudge will not fly with the rest of the EU", "image": {"timeCrawl": "18:00:00", "uri": "709906876", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T18:00:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "WHBQ", "uri": "fox13memphis.com", "id": "114"}, "url": "http://www.fox13memphis.com/news/uk-says-it-may-seek-temporary-customs-union-with-eu/592093320", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The plans were dismissed as \"a fantasy\" by one senior EU official. And anti-Brexit campaigners in Britain said they would merely replace EU regulations with new ones that could be even more onerous.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said there could be \"a temporary customs union between the U.K. and the EU\" to avoid border chaos when Britain officially leaves the bloc in March 2019.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said the transition period could last about two years.\n\nIn the long term, the department said, a \"customs partnership\" could eliminate the need for a border for goods traveling between Britain and the EU. The partnership would see Britain impose the exact same requirements as the EU on goods from outside the bloc destined for member states.\n\nAlternately, it suggested \"a highly streamlined customs arrangement\" could be set up, using technology to ease border procedures.\n\nThe proposals drew a cool response from Brussels.\n\n\"To be in & out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy,\" tweeted Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's Brexit coordinator.\n\nSome British businesses have accused the government of being vague about whether there will be economic barriers with the EU after Brexit. The persistent uncertainty - 14 months after Britain voted to leave the EU - is weighing on the economy.\n\nTrade Secretary Liam Fox and Treasury chief Philip Hammond wrote in the Sunday Telegraph that in 2019 Britain will leave both the EU's single market in goods and services and its customs union.\n\nThe single market ensures tariff-less trade in goods and services and is linked closely by the EU with other rights, such as the right of EU citizens to cross borders. The customs union allows goods to move within the EU without checks, but also imposes tariffs on imports from outside the EU. That would prevent Britain striking new free trade deals while it remains inside the arrangement.\n\nThe British proposal says the U.K. should be free to negotiate new trade relationships during the transition period, something EU officials are likely to find problematic.\n\nScottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who favors Britain's staying in the single market and customs union, accused the government on Twitter of having a \"daft 'have cake and eat it' approach\" to Brexit.\n\nPro-EU Labour lawmaker Chuka Umunna said the proposals \"are offering a red tape bombshell for British business.\"\n\nThe customs proposals are the first in a series of papers covering thorny issues in the negotiations, which are due to resume in Brussels at the end of this month. Another, on the status of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, is due to be published this week.\n\nThe European Commission said it took note of Britain's suggestions, \"but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal\" from the bloc.\n\nThe EU says negotiations on its future relations with Britain can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to settle its outstanding commitments to the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of 3 million EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nMichel Barnier, the EU's chief Brexit negotiator, tweeted that the quicker the two sides \"agree on citizens, settling accounts and Ireland, the quicker we can discuss customs & future relationship.\"", "id": "9332495", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "UK says it may seek {"timeCrawl": "10:59:00", "uri": "709718131", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T10:08:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "Washington Post", "uri": "washingtonpost.com", "id": "104"}, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/uk-says-it-may-seek-temporary-customs-union-with-eu/2017/08/15/6c47c37c-81a1-11e7-9e7a-20fa8d7a0db6_story.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON -- Britain might seek to remain in a customs union with the European Union for a time to avoid border chaos after leaving the bloc, the government's Brexit department said Tuesday.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said there could be \"a temporary customs union between the U.K. and the EU\" to help businesses make the transition to life outside the EU.\n\nAnd it said a future \"customs partnership\" could eliminate the need for a border for goods traveling between Britain and the EU.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said the transition period would likely last about two years, and would be replaced by a new deal offering \"extremely slick, extremely streamlined customs arrangements.\"\n\nSome British businesses have accused the government of being vague about whether there will be economic barriers with the EU after Brexit in March 2019. The persistent uncertainty -- 14 months after Britain voted to leave the EU -- is weighing on the economy.\n\nTrade Secretary Liam Fox and Treasury chief Philip Hammond wrote in the Sunday Telegraph that in 2019 Britain will leave both the EU's single market in goods and services and its customs union.\n\nThe single market ensures tariff-less trade in goods and services and is linked closely by the EU with other rights, such as the right of EU citizens to cross borders. The customs union allows goods to move within the EU without checks, but also imposes tariffs on imports from outside the EU. That would prevent Britain striking new free trade deals while it remains inside the arrangement.\n\nThe British proposal says the U.K. should be free to negotiate new trade relationships during the transition period, something EU officials are likely to find problematic.\n\nEU officials say Britain's stated goal of \"frictionless\" trade is impossible outside the single market and customs union.\n\nThe British government is trying to rebuff claims by EU officials that it is has been underprepared for divorce negotiations before a new round of talks in Brussels at the end of this month.\n\nThe customs proposals are the first in a series of papers covering thorny issues in the negotiations. Another, on the status of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, is due to be published this week.\n\nThe European Commission said it took note of Britain's suggestions, \"but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal\" from the bloc.\n\nThe EU says negotiations on its future relations with Britain can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to settle its outstanding commitments to the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of 3 million EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. {"timeCrawl": "13:03:00", "uri": "709772628", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:03:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "digitaljournal.com", "uri": "digitaljournal.com", "id": "556"}, "url": "http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/world/uk-to-seek-temporary-customs-union-after-brexit/article/500061", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Britain said on Tuesday it would seek a \"temporary customs union\" with the European Union after Brexit, in an opening gambit for trade negotiations that received a cool response from Brussels.\n\nThe government said broadly similar arrangements could apply to EU-UK trade in goods as they do now for around two years, to allow businesses longer to adapt to new post-Brexit systems.\n\nUnlike at present, however, Britain said it wanted to be able to negotiate free trade agreements with third countries during the interim period which would then be implemented afterwards.\n\n\"It's much more sensible, we think, if there is a shortish period in which we maintain the current arrangements,\" Brexit minister David Davis told BBC radio, adding that it could last \"something like two years\" -- ending before the 2022 election.\n\nThe proposal for a transitional arrangement was welcomed by the Confederation of British Industry, Britain's big business lobby group, but critics dismissed it as a \"fantasy\".\n\nThe European Commission, the EU's executive arm, said it would \"take note\" of the proposals, but warned: \"'Frictionless trade' is not possible outside the single market and customs union.\"\n\nEU chief negotiator Michel Barnier also repeated that talks on the future trading relationship could not begin until progress was made on other issues, including Britain's exit bill.\n\n- 'Clock is ticking' -\n\nBritain says its membership of the EU customs union, which allows for the tariff-free movement of goods, will end along with its membership of the single market -- its largest trading partner -- when it leaves the bloc in March 2019.\n\nExperts have warned it will be extremely difficult, if not impossible, to negotiate a new EU-UK free trade agreement before then, raising fears of a damaging \"cliff-edge\".\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU,\" the Brexit ministry said.\n\nThe CBI's deputy director Josh Hardie said the government's proposal was \"encouraging\", but added: \"The clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible.\"\n\nIn a policy paper published on Tuesday, Britain said it could streamline and simplify trade arrangements with the EU once it has left the customs union.\n\nBut it admitted there would be \"an increase in administration compared with being inside the EU customs union\".\n\nAn alternative would be a new customs partnership in which Britain effectively adopts the EU's external customs border to allow for free EU-UK trade, but applies its own trade policy and tariff for imports and exports with third countries destined only for the UK market.\n\nBut in recognition of the huge practical challenges that Brexit presents, the policy paper acknowledged this was \"an innovative and untested approach\".\n\n- 'Wishful thinking' -\n\nA third round of Brexit negotiations is due to begin at the end of August, focused on Britain's financial settlement, the issue of expatriate rights, and the border between British-controlled Northern Ireland and Ireland.\n\nLondon argues that customs arrangements are crucial to resolving the Irish border issue, on which it plans to publish further proposals on Wednesday.\n\nBut Brussels insists there must be broad agreement on the three priority issues before trade negotiations begin, by the EU leaders' summit in October at the earliest.\n\n\"The quicker UK & EU 27 agree on citizens, settling accounts and Ireland, the quicker we can discuss customs and future relationship,\" Barnier said on Twitter.\n\nOpposition Labour lawmaker Chris Leslie, from the campaign group Open Britain, said the proposal for an interim customs union represented \"wishful thinking of the highest order\".\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union,\" he said.\n\nGuy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's outspoken Brexit negotiator, added: \"To be in & out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy.\"", "id": "9280971", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "UK to seek 'temporary customs union' after Brexit", "image": {"timeCrawl": "12:01:00", "uri": "709743238", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:01:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "Bradenton Herald", "uri": "bradenton.com", "id": "2725"}, "url": "http://www.bradenton.com/news/business/article167239832.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Britain might seek to remain in a customs union with the European Union for a time to avoid border chaos after leaving the bloc, the government's Brexit department said Tuesday.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said there could be \"a temporary customs union between the U.K. and the EU\" to help businesses make the transition to life outside the EU. Brexit Secretary David Davis said the transition period could last about two years.\n\nIn the long term, the department said, a \"customs partnership\" could eliminate the need for a border for goods traveling between Britain and the EU. Alternately, it suggested \"a highly streamlined customs arrangement\" could be set up, using technology to ease border procedures.\n\nThe proposal -- one of a series intended to disprove allegations that Britain is underprepared for Brexit -- drew a cool response from Brussels.\n\n\"To be in & out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy,\" tweeted Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's Brexit coordinator.\n\nSome British businesses have accused the government of being vague about whether there will be economic barriers with the EU after Brexit in March 2019. The persistent uncertainty -- 14 months after Britain voted to leave the EU -- is weighing on the economy.\n\nTrade Secretary Liam Fox and Treasury chief Philip Hammond wrote in the Sunday Telegraph that in 2019 Britain will leave both the EU's single market in goods and services and its customs union.\n\nThe single market ensures tariff-less trade in goods and services and is linked closely by the EU with other rights, such as the right of EU citizens to cross borders. The customs union allows goods to move within the EU without checks, but also imposes tariffs on imports from outside the EU. That would prevent Britain striking new free trade deals while it remains inside the arrangement.\n\nThe British proposal says the U.K. should be free to negotiate new trade relationships during the transition period, something EU officials are likely to find problematic.\n\nScottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who favors Britain's staying in the single market and customs union, accused the government on Twitter of having a \"daft 'have cake and eat it' approach.\"\n\nThe customs proposals are the first in a series of papers covering thorny issues in the negotiations, which are due to resume in Brussels at the end of this month. Another, on the status of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, is due to be published this week.\n\nThe European Commission said it took note of Britain's suggestions, \"but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal\" from the bloc.\n\nThe EU says negotiations on its future relations with Britain can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to settle its outstanding commitments to the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of 3 million EU nationals living in Britain.", "id": "9270448", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "UK says it may seek {"timeCrawl": "12:19:00", "uri": "709753680", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:19:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "KHNL TV 8", "uri": "hawaiinewsnow.com", "id": "11710"}, "url": "http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/36136217/uk-says-it-may-seek-temporary-customs-union-with-eu", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON (AP) - Britain might seek to remain in a customs union with the European Union for a time to avoid border chaos after leaving the bloc, the government's Brexit department said Tuesday.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said there could be \"a temporary customs union between the U.K. and the EU\" to help businesses make the transition to life outside the EU. Brexit Secretary David Davis said the transition period could last about two years.\n\nIn the long term, the department said, a \"customs partnership\" could eliminate the need for a border for goods traveling between Britain and the EU. Alternately, it suggested \"a highly streamlined customs arrangement\" could be set up, using technology to ease border procedures.\n\nThe proposal - one of a series intended to disprove allegations that Britain is underprepared for Brexit - drew a cool response from Brussels.\n\n\"To be in & out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy,\" tweeted Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's Brexit coordinator.\n\nSome British businesses have accused the government of being vague about whether there will be economic barriers with the EU after Brexit in March 2019. The persistent uncertainty - 14 months after Britain voted to leave the EU - is weighing on the economy.\n\nTrade Secretary Liam Fox and Treasury chief Philip Hammond wrote in the Sunday Telegraph that in 2019 Britain will leave both the EU's single market in goods and services and its customs union.\n\nThe single market ensures tariff-less trade in goods and services and is linked closely by the EU with other rights, such as the right of EU citizens to cross borders. The customs union allows goods to move within the EU without checks, but also imposes tariffs on imports from outside the EU. That would prevent Britain striking new free trade deals while it remains inside the arrangement.\n\nThe British proposal says the U.K. should be free to negotiate new trade relationships during the transition period, something EU officials are likely to find problematic.\n\nScottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who favors Britain's staying in the single market and customs union, accused the government on Twitter of having a \"daft 'have cake and eat it' approach.\"\n\nThe customs proposals are the first in a series of papers covering thorny issues in the negotiations, which are due to resume in Brussels at the end of this month. Another, on the status of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, is due to be published this week.\n\nThe European Commission said it took note of Britain's suggestions, \"but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal\" from the bloc.\n\nThe EU says negotiations on its future relations with Britain can't start until sufficient progress has been made on three initial issues: how much money the U.K. will have to pay to settle its outstanding commitments to the bloc; whether security checks and customs duties will be instituted on the Irish border; and the status of 3 million EU nationals living in Britain.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"timeCrawl": "17:00:00", "uri": "709880420", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T17:00:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "GULF NEWS", "uri": "gulfnews.com", "id": "3935"}, "url": "http://gulfnews.com/business/economy/britain-asks-for-interim-customs-deal-with-eu-1.2074893", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "London: Britain has said it wants an interim customs agreement with the European Union after Brexit to allow the freest possible trade of goods, but that it will also seek the right to negotiate other trade deals -- a possible sticking point in the talks.\n\nAccording to excerpts of a government document to be published on Tuesday setting out Britain's strategy, the government will say one option to minimise friction when it leaves the bloc in March 2019 would be to introduce a temporary customs union, which should be \"time-limited\".\n\nThat would provide certainty for businesses, the government said, aiming to address a main concern of companies who fear the introduction of customs checks will cause expensive delays.\n\n\"Ministers will announce an intention to seek an 'interim' period with the EU of close association with the customs union that would allow for a smooth and orderly transfer to the new regime,\" the government said in a statement ahead of publication of the first in a series of \"future partnership papers\".\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU... During this interim period, which will be negotiated with Brussels, Britain will look to negotiate bold new trade relationships around the world.\" Businesses welcomed the proposals, but the Confederation of British Industry also warned the government that \"the clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible\".\n\nEU wants progress on withdrawal\n\nThe EU said it would study the proposals carefully but it would only address the proposal for an implementation period once sufficient progress had been made on Britain's withdrawal.\n\nThe EU wants to make progress on several key issues by October, including the financial bill for Britain's exit, but Brexit minister David Davis told the BBC there would not be an agreed figure on the financial settlement by then.\n\n\"We're going to talk it through very, very carefully, so at this stage we're not going to commit,\" he said.\n\nHe later told LBC Radio: \"We're going to have a long haggle... [EU chief negotiator] Michel [Barnier] is getting quite cross with us. He's saying 'You should make your proposal'.\"\n\nDavis said Britain should not have to pay to have a temporary customs union with the EU. Any transitional period would most likely last for two years, he added, and must be over by the time of the next British national election, due in 2022.\n\nIn an effort to move the talks with the EU on to the issue of Britain's future relationship, Prime Minister Theresa May and her government had promised to publish a series of policy documents this week.\n\nBut after being accused by some EU officials of being ill prepared for the first rounds of negotiations, the government's demand to secure trade deals while participating in a temporary customs union may cause further problems.\n\n\"It looks like the new unified position in the cabinet is to return the government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it\", said Chris Leslie, a pro-EU campaigner and member of Britain's opposition Labour Party.\n\nTurkish arrangement?\n\nCountries that are part of the EU's customs union are not allowed to negotiate bilateral trade deals, and May's government has said Brexit means Britain must leave the customs union.\n\nBut Turkey, while not an EU member, is part of a separate customs union for industrial goods and can still negotiate bilateral trade deals. It was not clear whether Britain was pursuing a similar arrangement to Turkey.\n\nThe government said that, by sorting out the customs arrangements, Britain and the bloc could avoid a \"hard border\" with EU member state Ireland, something that officials fear could reignite tensions between Irish nationalists and unionists in British-ruled Northern Ireland.\n\nIt proposed two different approaches -- a highly streamlined customs arrangement managed by Britain, or a new customs partnership with the EU -- that it said could \"negate the need for a customs border\".\n\nThe government will set out its proposed solutions for the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland in detail on Wednesday.\n\nThe position papers are intended to flesh out the government's Brexit vision and show a united stance over the future relationship after rifts emerged among ministers.\n\nBritish inflation steadies as Brexit impact fades\n\nLondon: Britain's annual inflation rate steadied in July, with an expected rise failing to materialise as the pound recovers from a Brexit-fuelled slump, official data showed Tuesday.\n\nThe Consumer Prices Index (CPI) stood at 2.6 per cent last month, the same level as June, the Office for National Statistics said in a statement.\n\nThe ONS added that lower motor fuel costs offset rising prices for clothing, food and household goods.\n\nAnalysts' consensus forecast had been for an increase to 2.7 per cent.\n\n\"The expected pick-up didn't happen,\" said Neil Wilson, analyst at trading firm ETX Capital.\n\n\"The sterling exchange rate has stabilised, meaning far less pass-through from the weaker pound on the inflation rate. We're even getting to the stage in the year where the pound will be actually stronger than it was 12 months before, especially against the US dollar,\" Wilson said.", "id": "9323288", "details": {}, "eng-3358827", "body": "Britain said yesterday it would seek a \"temporary customs union\" with the European Union after Brexit, in an opening gambit for trade negotiations that received a cool response from Brussels.\n\nThe government said broadly similar arrangements could apply to EU-UK trade in goods as they do now for around two years, to allow businesses longer to adapt to new post-Brexit systems.\n\nUnlike at present, however, Britain said it wanted to be able to negotiate free trade agreements with third countries during the interim period which would then be implemented afterward.\n\n\"It's much more sensible, we think, if there is a shortish period in which we maintain the current arrangements,\" Brexit minister David Davis told BBC radio, adding that it could last \"something like two years\" -- ending before the 2022 election.\n\nThe proposal for a transitional arrangement was welcomed by the Confederation of British Industry, Britain's big business lobby group, but critics dismissed it as a \"fantasy.\"\n\nThe European Commission, the EU's executive arm, said it would \"take note\" of the proposals, but warned: \"'Frictionless trade' is not possible outside the single market and customs union.\"\n\nEU chief negotiator Michel Barnier also repeated that talks on the future trading relationship could not begin until progress was made on other issues, including Britain's exit bill.\n\nBritain says its membership of the EU customs union, which allows for the tariff-free movement of goods, will end along with its membership of the single market -- its largest trading partner -- when it leaves the bloc in March 2019.\n\nExperts have warned it will be extremely difficult, if not impossible, to negotiate a new EU-UK free trade agreement before then, raising fears of a damaging \"cliff-edge.\"\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU,\" the Brexit ministry said.\n\nThe CBI's deputy director Josh Hardie said the government's proposal was \"encouraging,\" but added: \"The clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible.\"\n\nIn a policy paper published yesterday, Britain said it could streamline and simplify trade arrangements with the EU once it has left the customs union.\n\nBut it admitted there would be \"an increase in administration compared with being inside the EU customs union.\"\n\nAn alternative would be a new customs partnership in which Britain effectively adopts the EU's external customs border to allow for free EU-UK trade, but applies its own trade policy and tariff for imports and exports with third countries destined only for the UK market.\n\nBut in recognition of the huge practical challenges that Brexit presents, the policy paper acknowledged this was \"an innovative and untested approach.\"\n\nA third round of Brexit negotiations is due to begin at the end of August, {"timeCrawl": "07:32:00", "uri": "710173433", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T23:36:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"title": "Intelligencer Post", "uri": "intelligencerpost.com", "id": "18982"}, "url": "http://www.intelligencerpost.com/britain-suggests-no-customs-checks-invisible-uk-eu-borders-brexit/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Post-Brexit transition period is to be done by 2022 at the latest, according to British Brexit Secretary Davis.\n\nBritain's government has published a paper proposing a new system that would mean no customs checks at borders between the UK and the EU following Brexit, i.e. the former's exit from the latter.\n\nThe talks for Brexit between the EU and the UK finally began on June 19, 2017, about a year after the Brexit referendum was held, and after on March 29, 2017, British Prime Minister Theresa May formally triggered Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty, which deals with exit from the European Union, initiating a two-year process of negotiations.\n\nIn their June 2016 referendum, the majority of the British citizens voted in favor of Brexit (51.9% to 48.1%).\n\nThe guidelines for the Brexit talks adopted by the EU list three main priorities: securing the rights of EU nationals in the UK; collecting Britain's financial dues; and avoiding a hard border between the Republic of Ireland, which is an EU member state, and Northern Ireland, which is part of the UK, should be avoided.\n\nBritain and the EU recently had their first full session of talks on Brexit, with the two parties remaining at odds on key issues such as citizens' rights and the divorce bill the UK is expected to pay. May has made it clear the UK is to end free movement of people with the EU in 2019.\n\nSimon Fraser, former head of the British diplomatic services, has said the Brexit talks have not begun well for Britain so far because of an internal discord in the UK Cabinet.\n\nThere have been reports in the British press that the government in London is prepared to pay up to GBP 36 billion (app. EUR 40 billion, USD 47 billion) to the EU to settle the so called Brexit \"divorce bill\", a substantially lower figure than the EUR 60 - 100 billion cited by some estimates.\n\nMedia reports have alleged the EU plans to ask Britain to pay some EUR 60 billion (USD 71 billion) to settle all financial obligations undertaken by the EU 28 until 2019, which is when Brexit is supposed to become a fact.\n\nHowever, a report by The Financial Times said the Brexit \"divorce bill\" to be sought by the EU was estimated at EUR 100 billion (USD 118 billion), almost double the previous estimate.\n\n'Untested Approach'\n\nThe British government will propose an \"innovative and untested approach\" to customs checks as part of its Brexit negotiations, the BBC reported.\n\nThe model is one of two being put forward in a newly-published paper, and would mean no customs checks at UK-EU borders.\n\nThe UK's alternative proposal - a more efficient system of border checks - would involve \"an increase in administration\".\n\nThe UK has already said it will leave the customs union - the EU's tariff-free trading area - after Brexit, and businesses have been calling for clarity on what the replacement system will involve.\n\nThe UK's departure from the EU's customs union was confirmed at the weekend in a joint article by Chancellor Philip Hammond and Trade Secretary Liam Fox.\n\nThe UK's proposals, detailed in what it calls a \"future partnership paper\", also include the possibility of a \"temporary customs union\" after the UK leaves the EU in March 2019 to avoid a \"cliff-edge\" for business as they adapt to the new arrangements.\n\n'Highly Streamlined' or No Border at All\n\nAccording to the newly-published government paper, the UK could ask the EU to establish a \"temporary customs union\" after Brexit in March 2019.\n\nBut during this period, it would also expect to be able to negotiate its own international trade deals - something it cannot do as an EU customs union member.\n\nOnce this period expires, the UK will look to agree either a \"highly streamlined\" border with the EU, or a new \"partnership\" with no customs border at all.\n\nThe British government said the interim arrangements would mean businesses would only have to adjust once to the new arrangements.\n\nAll of this will have to be negotiated with the EU - and the two sides have not yet even started discussing trade matters.\n\nDavid Davis, Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union, said he envisioned the interim customs system being \"as close as we can to the current arrangements\", but with the UK able to negotiate and sign its own international trade deals.\n\nHe did not rule out the UK paying to be part of the arrangement, saying he was not going to conduct negotiations on air.\n\nDavis said he did not believe the European Court of Justice would be the arbiter of the temporary arrangement, adding that the government would publish proposals on \"international arbitration\" next week.\n\nHe added the transition period had \"to be done by the election\", which has to take place by 2022 at the latest.", "id": "9424725", "details": {}, "date":
