{"timeCrawl": "16:26:00", "uri": "709865176", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:26:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "WalesOnline", "uri": "walesonline.co.uk", "id": "1272"}, "url": "http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/politics/governments-plan-post-brexit-trade-13480566", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "There is alarm at the bureaucracy people and businesses could soon face\n\nGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nThe UK Government's proposals for the \"freest and most frictionless trade possible\" with the EU post-Brexit have been described as a \"red-tape bombshell for British business\".\n\nThe Government paper gives the clearest insight yet into the trading relationship with the EU that Theresa May's administration plans to pursue.\n\nOne option is an \"innovative and untested approach\" intended to avoid the need for customs checks at EU-UK borders. But an alternative proposal for a \"streamlined customs arrangement\" would, the Government admits in its \"future partnership paper\", result in \"an increase in administration compared with being inside the EU customs union\".\n\nThe Welsh Government said it was \"unacceptable\" there had been no attempt to seek its input into the paper before it was finalised. It is also concerned there has been \"insufficient attention to the implication for trade with the Irish Republic using Welsh ports\".\n\nThe UK Government has also said it will levy customs duty and VAT on EU imports if no deal can be reached - and that UK exporters would also face new requirements.\n\nThe paper states: \"In this scenario, without any further facilitations or agreements, the UK would treat trade with the EU as it currently treats trade with non-EU countries. Customs duty and import VAT would be due on EU imports.\n\n\"Traders would need to be registered. Traders exporting to the EU would have to submit an export declaration, and certain goods may require an export licence.\n\n\"The EU would also apply the customs rules and VAT to imports from the UK that it applies to non-EU countries.\"\n\nLeading Labour pro-EU MP Chuka Umunna was unimpressed by the proposals, saying: \"They might promise frictionless trade, but they are offering a red tape bombshell for British business.\"\n\nPlaid Cymru claimed the \"notion that the British Government can have a transition period in which it retains the perks of remaining in the EU customs union whilst negotiating alternative deals with third countries is at best na\u00efve and at worst deluded\".\n\nHere are the key points from the proposals:\n\n1 .The UK Government wants to avoid a 'cliff-edge for businesses and individuals on both sides'.\n\nIn order to avoid chaos and disruption when the UK leaves the EU in March 2019, the Government argues there should be a \"time-limited interim period\" of \"continued close association with the EU customs union\". This could involve a \"new and time-limited customs union\".\n\nThe idea is that it would provide time for technology to be put in place to ensure the future customs regime is \"as smooth as possible\". A goal is to ensure \"businesses and people in the UK and the EU only have to adjust once to a new customs relationship\".\n\n2. An unprecedented customs partnership could be agreed.\n\nIt is hoped this could be done \"in a way that removes the need for a UK-EU customs border\".\n\nThe paper states: \"By mirroring the EU's customs approach at its external border, we could ensure that all goods entering the EU via the UK have paid the correct EU duties. This would remove the need for the UK and the EU to introduce customs processes between us, so that goods moving between the UK and the EU would be treated as they are now for customs purposes.\"\n\nBritain could apply its own tariffs on goods that were intended for the UK market.\n\nThe Government admits this is an \"untested\" approach and that there may be a need for a \"tracking mechanism, where imports to the UK were tracked until they reached an end user, or a repayment mechanism, where imports to the UK paid whichever was the higher of the UK's or the EU's tariff rates and traders claimed a refund for the difference between the two rates when the goods were sold to an end user in the country charging lower tariffs.\"\n\n3. The Government wants to avoid delays at ports such as Holyhead.\n\nIt seeks to simplify the requirements for moving goods across borders.\n\nOne possibility is that a continued waiver from the requirement to submit entry and exit declarations for goods moved between the EU and the UK could be negotiated.\n\nAnother is that goods being moved between the UK and the rest of the world could travel through the European Union without EU duties having to be paid through membership of the Common Transit Convention (CTC). The Government argues this would provide \"cash-flow benefits to traders, and would make border clearances easier at key ports and airports, such as Dover and Holyhead.\"\n\nA further option is for \"a technology-based solution for roll-on, roll-off ports which could consist of pre-arrival notification of consignments on a port IT system, linked to customs declarations and vehicle registration numbers so that vehicles were not required to stop at the border, enabling traffic to flow smoothly\".\n\n4. The Government has ruled out staying in the existing customs union.\n\nThe Government is emphatic that this is not possible, stating: \"To achieve our objectives on trading independently with both the EU and the rest of the world, we will need to establish a new customs arrangement with the EU outside of the EU customs union.\"\n\n5. There are big ambitions to boost the export of services.\n\nThe Government states: \"The share of services in total UK exports has increased from around 27% in 1990 to 45% in 2016 - the largest share of any of the G7 economies. To capitalise fully on those opportunities, the UK will need an independent trade policy, with the freedom to set for ourselves the terms of our trade with the world.\"\n\n6. There will be action to ensure businesses do not get a raw deal.\n\nThe Government insists it will \"protect our businesses from unfair anti-competitive practices,\" stating: \"When countries do not play by the rules or take an unfair advantage, we will act swiftly to ensure that trade remains fair and that markets are kept open. We, like many of our partners, believe that providing a safety net for domestic businesses if they suffer harm as a result of unfair trading practices is an important part of supporting the free trade agenda.\"\n\n7. The Government says future free trade deals will not put public services at risk.\n\nThis has been a key concern. Campaigners have warned that a free trade deal with the UK could lead to lower environmental standards and stop a future government rolling back the use of the private sector in the NHS.\n\nThe Government's paper rejects such fears, stating: \"We will maintain our high level of standards and protect our public services. As we leave the EU, the Government will continue to maintain our high standards for consumers, employees, the environment and animal welfare.\n\n\"The Government will also ensure that decisions about how public services including the NHS are delivered for UK citizens, are made by UK governments and not by our trade partners.\"\n\n8. Avoiding a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic is a priority.\n\nThe paper states: \"The border between Northern Ireland and Ireland is the UK's only land border. We must avoid a return to a hard border, and trade and everyday movements across the land border must be protected as part of the UK-EU deal...\n\n\"The Government has made clear that the answer to avoiding a hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland cannot be to impose a new customs border between Northern Ireland and Great Britain. We should avoid any approach that would create new barriers to doing business within the UK (including between Northern Ireland and Great Britain).\"\n\n9. Discussions with the Welsh Government will take place (but there is unhappiness in Cardiff).\n\nThe paper notes that customs is the responsibility of Westminster but it says the UK Government is \"committed\" to working with the devolved administrations to \"understand the practical impact of new customs arrangements in different parts of the UK\" including the \"implications for ports in Wales\".\n\nHowever, a Welsh Government spokeswoman said: \"We welcome the fact that the UK Government is at last starting to set out its thinking on key issues in a little more detail. We particularly welcome the recognition that there will need to be an interim or transitional period with as little change as possible in terms of practical customs arrangements, something we have been pressing for since the publication of our White Paper, Securing Wales' Future.\n\n\"At the same time, while we recognise that this is a discussion paper and is intended as the basis for consultation, we think it is unacceptable that once again, there has been no attempt to seek input to the document from ourselves and the other devolved administrations in advance of finalising it.\n\n\"While we need time to consider the issues raised, we are disappointed that there is no economic analysis of the costs and benefits of establishing an independent trade policy and no consideration of the option of entering a new customs union with the EU post-Brexit. We also believe there is insufficient attention to the implication for trade with the Irish Republic using Welsh ports of the twin requirements of avoiding a hard border on the island of Ireland and avoiding any customs border between Northern Ireland and Britain.\"\n\nPlaid Cymru MP Hywel Williams said: \"In their first collision with reality, the hard-line Brexiteers have finally conceded that a deal must be struck and a transitional deal put in place. The British Government's position paper, however, does sound the loudest of alarm bells.\n\n\"The notion that the British Government can have a transition period in which it retains the perks of remaining in the EU customs union whilst negotiating alternative deals with third countries is at best na\u00efve and at worst deluded. It's highly unlikely that the EU will even contemplate agreeing to this - and the two sides have not yet even started discussing future trade matters...\n\n\"The two options for future trading arrangements put forward by the Government once this period expires are both as damaging as one another for Wales. There should quite rightly be no hard border between the Republic of Ireland and the UK.\n\n\"However, the reality of both positions in the British Government's paper means that the onus of the self-admitted 'increase in administration' will now lie on ports in Wales. I doubt Ministers in Whitehall have given any consideration to the financial, infrastructural and practical implications this will have on our nation, let alone how it will impact on policing and security requirements there.\n\n\"Plaid Cymru has been clear and consistent in its view that we must maintain single market and customs union membership and that Welsh jobs and trade must not be endangered by Brexit. This position paper is by definition in clear contradiction to our policy.\"\n\nLabour Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer said: \"The Government's proposals are ambiguous, unachievable and offer no viable solutions.\n\n\"The first proposal for a streamlined customs arrangements is code for a hard-edged exit from the Customs Union, which will inevitably involve a border between the UK and any trading partner, including the EU27. This will mean delays and costs for UK businesses, especially manufacturing. The Government appear to be relying on unspecified technological solutions to reduce these burdens, but they can't suggest how and when these new systems could be in place or how much they might cost.\n\n\"The second proposal is in David Davis's own words 'untested'. That's because it is, in truth, a half-in half-out proposal without any clarity about how the Government plan to negotiate or deliver it. This will almost certainly entail considerable new bureaucratic burdens for British businesses, including complicated \"tracking and repayment mechanisms\".\n\n\"We've seen today that the Government still has no viable plan to deliver frictionless trade with our largest market and closest allies. They are, as ever, putting jobs and the economy through their chaotic handling of Brexit.\"", "id": "9317255", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Government plans for post-Brexit trade 'a {"timeCrawl": "02:05:00", "uri": "709533836", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T02:05:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4790896/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "David Davis (pictured) will ask Brussels to keep its custom rules to make the change a smooth transition\n\nBritain will today demand that it is allowed to start striking trade deals the day after Brexit - while creating a temporary EU customs deal to prevent border chaos.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis will set out plans to begin 'negotiating bold new trade relationships around the world' as soon as the country leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nBut he will ask Brussels to keep in place current customs rules that prevent goods having to be checked as they go between Britain and the EU for an interim period, which could last up to two or three years.\n\nMr Davis will argue that such a deal, where the UK mimics the EU's tariffs and rules on customs, would give more time for a smooth switch to the new trading regime, which would benefit businesses on both sides of the Channel.\n\nMinisters have been warned about the strain ports could be put under if they face a sudden increase in bureaucracy for dealing with goods entering and leaving the country.\n\nMr Davis will argue that while maintaining a temporary customs arrangement, the country must be allowed to begin developing a trade policy that makes it 'more outward-looking than ever before' as soon as possible.\n\n'As we exit the EU, we must not only seek to secure our existing markets, but also to tap into new, growing markets across the globe', he will say.\n\nUnder EU rules, member states are forbidden from striking their own trade deals with other countries. The Government will insist that it is allowed to begin this work as soon as it leaves the EU, even if the current EU customs regime remains in place on a temporary basis. But Brussels may put ministers under pressure to promise that these new deals will only come into force at the end of the interim period.\n\nIn the longer term, Mr Davis will say he is seeking 'the most frictionless customs arrangement anywhere', with minimal checks and paperwork on goods going between the EU and UK.\n\nOne option being put forward by Mr Davis would see the UK manage a new customs border with administration streamlined to the 'fullest extent possible' using technology.\n\nHe will also float plans for a customs partnership with the EU that would negate the need for a customs border between the UK and the rest of the bloc.\n\nNegotiations on future customs arrangements are not due to be discussed during the next round of Brexit talks to be held in Brussels at the end of this month.\n\nThe European Commission has said progress first needs to be made on agreeing the divorce bill before work can begin on the future relationship between the EU and UK.\n\nBut Downing Street said it was pushing forward with setting out its plans in order to help businesses both in Britain and across the continent.\n\nMr Davis (pictured with EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Michel Barnier) will argue Britain must be allowed to begin developing a trade policy that makes it 'more outward-looking than ever before'\n\nThe Prime Minister's spokesman said yesterday: 'We have had the first round of the negotiations and those talks have shown that many of the withdrawal questions can only be settled in light of the future partnership. So now is the time to set out our approach to that partnership to inform the negotiations and to provide citizens and business at home and across Europe with a deeper understanding of our thinking.'\n\nBusiness leaders last night welcomed the Government's plan to minimise disruption to trade.\n\nJosh Hardie, deputy director-general of the Confederation of British Industry, said he was encouraged that the papers propose a time-limited interim period and a customs system that is as barrier-free as possible.\n\nHe added: 'All efforts should be made to deliver a single-step transition, so that businesses don't have to adapt twice.'\n\nBut Labour MP Chris Leslie, a leading supporter of the Open Britain campaign group, accused ministers of 'wanting to have their cake and eat it'.\n\nHe said: 'It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the Government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union.'\n\nDowning Street last night announced that Theresa May will embark on a visit to Japan at the end of this month in a bid to boost Britain's post-Brexit trade.\n\nThe Prime Minister, who is currently in Switzerland on holiday, will be received by emperor Akihito and the Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe.\n\nMrs May will be accompanied on the trip by business leaders from a range of sectors.\n\nFormer Ukip donor Arron Banks has written to every voter in Philip Hammond and Amber Rudd's constituencies to try to get them deselected.\n\nThe Chancellor, MP for Runnymede and {"timeCrawl": "19:17:00", "uri": "709936556", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T11:45:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "Verdict", "uri": "verdict.co.uk", "id": "19067"}, "url": "https://www.verdict.co.uk/what-is-the-customs-union/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The British government is set to push for an \"innovative and untested approach\" to customs checks during Brexit negotiations with the European Union, as both parties attempt to avoid potential disruption to businesses.\n\nSecretary of state for international trade Liam Fox confirmed that Britain would be leaving the EU Customs Union following Brexit.\n\nThe rights of EU citizens, divorce bills and trade agreements to aside, customs arrangements is another potential pitfall as talks go on.\n\nThe EU Customs Union is a trade agreement between all of the member states of the EU.\n\nMonaco and UK territories which are not members of the EU are also included in the agreement. Likewise, separate agreements are in place with Andorra, San Marino and Turkey.\n\nThe agreement states that those involved are exempt from import tariffs on goods arriving from other members of the EU. Likewise, items moving between two member states do not require customs checks.\n\nThis is what allows a UK citizen to order an item from France without paying additional duty fees, for example.\n\nA customs agreement proposes that all parties impose a common external tariff when trading with countries outside of the union.\n\nThe purpose of this agreement is to encourage the trade of goods between members of the Customs Union.\n\nThe HM Treasury have recently published a paper on \"Future customs arrangements\", which outlines the British government's plans to continue to provide \"free and frictionless trade\" following Britain's exit from the EU.\n\nAny future customs agreement will depend largely on the stance of EU negotiators. However, Britain is hopeful of securing a good deal. The plan is for the UK to continue to operate within the EU Customs Union throughout a transitional period.\n\nBoth the UK and EU Member States would benefit from time to fully implement the new customs arrangements in order to avoid a cliff-edge for businesses and individuals on both sides. The Government believes a model of close association with the EU Customs Union for a time-limited interim period could achieve this.\n\nSecretary of state for exiting the European Union, David Davis, has said this transition should take no more than two years, providing time for Britain to streamline and integrate a new approach.\n\nThe paper proposes two ideas. The first proposal calls for a \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\". If agreed, Britain would continue to follow many of the trade rules already in place.\n\nThe second proposes a new customs partnership. This would see Britain develop its own system. Britain would align to EU rules only when importing products intended for the EU market, the report states.", "id": "9343423", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Britain wants a {"timeCrawl": "04:02:00", "uri": "709563162", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:18:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "Rappler", "uri": "rappler.com", "id": "7948"}, "url": "http://www.rappler.com/world/regions/europe/178737-uk-may-seek-temporary-customs-union-after-brexit", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Canary Wharf, the London financial district, and the river Thames is seen in London on June 24, 2016. Leon Neal/AFP\n\nLONDON, United Kingdom - Britain could seek a temporary customs union with the European Union after Brexit, the government said Tuesday, August 15, as it prepared to publish its first detailed proposals on the future partnership.\n\nBritain says its membership of the EU customs union, which currently allows for the tariff-free movement of goods, will end along with its membership of the single market when it leaves the bloc in March 2019.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the EU said it will seek to agree a \"time-limited period of implementation\" to provide certainty for businesses and allow for new customs arrangements to be set up.\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU,\" it said in a statement, ahead of the publication of the full paper later on Tuesday.\n\nExperts have warned it will be extremely difficult to negotiate a new EU-UK free trade agreement before Britain leaves the bloc - particularly as Brussels has so far refused even to start trade talks.\n\nIt says there must be broad agreement first on 3 key issues - Britain's financial settlement, the issue of expatriate rights, and the question of the border between British-controlled Northern Ireland and Ireland.\n\nBritain will publish its proposals on the border issue on Wednesday, August 16, ahead of the third round of Brexit negotiations in Brussels at the end of the month.\n\nOfficials in London believe the border is inextricably linked to the customs issue.\n\nAfter Brexit, the Irish border will be Britain's only land border with the EU.\n\nThere are fears that the reintroduction of physical checkpoints could upset the fragile balance of peace in Northern Ireland.\n\nBritain's membership of the EU customs union precludes it from striking its own trade deals, and the government made clear Tuesday that such freedom was crucial to its post-Brexit plans.\n\n\"During this interim period, which will be negotiated with Brussels, Britain will look to negotiate bold new trade relationships around the world,\" it said.\n\nThe statement added: \"Our goal is to secure as frictionless trade as possible with the EU alongside the ability to forge trade deals around the world.\"\n\nHowever, opposition Labour lawmaker Chris Leslie, from the campaign group Open Britain, said the proposal represented \"wishful thinking of the highest order\".\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union,\" he said. - Rappler.com", "id": "9203950", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "UK may seek temporary customs union after Brexit", "image": {"timeCrawl": "16:51:00", "uri": "708846532", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T16:49:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/aug/13/philip-hammond-hard-brexit-tories-uk-customs-union", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Philip Hammond, was accused of ceding ground to cabinet Brexiters on Sunday after he signed an article saying the UK will not remain in the customs union framework during the transitional period after Brexit.\n\nThe chancellor clarified the government's position in a statement jointly written with Liam Fox, the international trade secretary, saying that the UK would be \"outside the customs union\" during the post-Brexit transition phase and that at that point it would be \"a 'third country', not party to the EU treaties\".\n\nThis means that the UK will be free to conclude trade deals with non-EU countries from the moment it leaves in March 2019, and that it will not have to wait until the transition is over, possibly three years later.\n\nHammond and Fox are seen as the two ministers at opposite ends of the soft-hard Brexit spectrum and their joint article, which also said the transitional period would be \"time-limited\", was intended to quash speculation that the cabinet is divided on the issue.\n\nTheresa May will be back at her desk later this week after her holiday, with a set of government Brexit position papers due to be published shortly. Before the UK-EU Brexit talks resume at the end of this month, the government wants to repair the damage caused by summer headlines about Brexit splits.\n\nHammond has spent the last few weeks arguing strongly for a lengthy Brexit transitional period, to the delight of pro-Europeans, and earlier this summer he hinted that he was considering an arrangement that would in effect keep the UK in the customs union, and therefore unable to sign bilateral trade deals with non-EU countries, for the period between Brexit and the final settlement coming into force.\n\nFox, who was alarmed at the prospect of heading an international trade department unable to strike trade deals possibly for the rest of this parliament, admitted last month that there was \"still a discussion to be had\" on this issue (FT paywall). But, in their article in the Sunday Telegraph, Fox and Hammond revealed that this matter has been resolved.\n\n\"We respect the will of the British people - in March 2019 the United Kingdom will leave the European Union,\" they wrote. \"We will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation ... When we've left the customs union, we will build up on [relationships with other countries] by negotiating as an independent nation with the freedom to sign bilateral free trade agreements.\"\n\nVince Cable, the Lib Dem leader, said the article showed that it was not Hammond who \"calls in the shots\" in the cabinet over Brexit. He said: \"Over the summer we heard that Philip Hammond was courageously fighting off the more extreme Brexiteers. Supposedly he was looking for a compromise to keep Britain within the customs union and single market as long as possible.\n\n\"The rebellion didn't last very long. He has now teamed up with one of the more extreme and ideological supporters of a hard Brexit.\"\n\nDavid Jones, the pro-leave Tory who was the Brexit minister until the general election, told the BBC that Hammond had \"rowed back from his previous position\". Richard Corbett, the deputy leader of Labour MEPs, said Hammond had \"caved in\" and that the government was now aiming for the most damaging version of Brexit.\n\nEarlier this summer, Fox made his own concession over Brexit, accepting that a transitional period lasting two or three years might be necessary. Previously he had been downplaying the need for such a lengthy interim stage.\n\nIn their article, Fox and Hammond said: \"We are also clear that during this period our borders must continue to operate smoothly; goods bought on the internet must still cross borders, businesses must still be able to supply their customers across the EU, and our innovative, world-leading companies must be able to hire the talent they need, including from within the EU.\"\n\nBut they did not explain how these aims would be achieved. Nor did they say how long a transitional period would last, or what payments the UK would continue to make to the EU while it was in place.\n\nTheir article was published as the Conservative MP Anna Soubry said that she and probably other pro-Europeans could leave the party if May insisted on pursuing a hard Brexit.\n\nWriting in the Mail on Sunday, Soubry said: \"If the prime minister or her successor (in the event of Theresa standing down) is not prepared to confront the ideologues, I gravely fear that the party could split - and that would change Britain's political landscape completely.\"\n\nBut Soubry, who has become the most vocal pro-European among Tory MPs, was careful in her article to avoid saying what would constitute the \"hard Brexit\" that she could not accept.", "id": "8942157", "details": {"liCnt": 3}, "date": "2017-08-13", "title": "Hammond accused of giving ground to pro-hard Brexit Tories", "image": point.\n\nMembers of the EU customs union aren't generally allowed to negotiate their own trade pacts.\n\nTuesday's (August 15) proposals aim to give businesses more certainty.\n\nThey fear customs checks will cause expensive delays.\n\nBig firms welcoming the proposals, but warning the clock is ticking to get it right.\n\nThe government also hopes the plan could avoid a 'hard border' between {"timeCrawl": "06:17:00", "uri": "709602668", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T06:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "zambia24.com", "uri": "zambia24.com", "id": "18072"}, "url": "http://zambia24.com/news/2017/08/15/brexit-uk-suggests-temporary-customs-union-with-eu/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The EU's customs union means members charge the same tariff on goods coming from other countries\n\nThe UK has set out the \"ambitious new customs arrangement\" it wants to secure with the EU after Brexit.\n\nMinisters said the plans would mean the \"freest and most frictionless possible trade\" with the rest of Europe.\n\nThis could include a \"temporary customs union\" after Brexit to prevent border problems as the UK leaves the EU.\n\nBusinesses have called for clarity since the UK said it was leaving the customs union - the EU's tariff-free trading area - as part of Brexit.\n\nThe customs union document is the first of a series of papers to be published by the UK government on key negotiation issues.\n\nOn Wednesday it is expected to set out proposals for the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.\n\nCountries in the customs union don't impose tariffs - taxes on imports - on each other's goods.\n\nEvery country inside the union levies the same tariffs on imports from abroad.\n\nSo, for example, a 10% tariff is imposed on some cars imported from outside the customs union, while 7.5% is imposed on roasted coffee.\n\nOther goods - such as soap or slate - have no tariffs.\n\nThe UK's departure from the EU's customs union was confirmed at the weekend in a joint article by Chancellor Philip Hammond and Trade Secretary Liam Fox.\n\nAccording to the newly-published government paper, the UK could ask Brussels to establish a \"temporary customs union\" after it leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nBut during this period, it would also expect to be able to negotiate its own international trade deals - something it cannot do as an EU customs union member.\n\nOnce this period expires, the UK will look to agree either a \"highly streamlined\" border with the EU, or a new \"partnership\" with no customs border at all.\n\nThe government said the interim arrangements would mean businesses would only have to adjust once to the new arrangements.\n\nAll of this will have to be negotiated with the EU - and the two sides have not yet even started discussing trade matters.\n\nOther obstacles - including the size of the UK's \"divorce bill\" - need to be agreed first.\n\nKeir Starmer, Labour's shadow Brexit secretary, said the proposals were \"incoherent and inadequate\" and were designed to \"gloss over deep and continuing divisions within the cabinet\".\n\n\"These fantastical and contradictory proposals provide no guidance for negotiators or certainty for businesses,\" he added.\n\nLiberal Democrat Brexit spokesman Tom Brake said the plan would \"only delay the economic pain caused by leaving the customs union\".\n\n\"We still face the prospect of more red tape for businesses, longer queues at our borders and higher prices for consumers once the transition comes to an end.\"\n\nHowever, the CBI, which represents British businesses, said the proposal was \"encouraging\".\n\nIts deputy director general, Josh Hardie, added: \"The clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible.\"\n\nAdam Fleming, BBC Brussels reporter, said the UK was seeking a customs union agreement \"that will keep things broadly the same for an interim period - an attempt to reassure business\".\n\n\"Firms will be told they'll only have to change their processes once,\" he said.\n\n\"In Brussels, EU negotiators are likely to stick to their position that that the future relationship can't be considered until agreement has been reached on their priority issues - the rights of citizens, a financial settlement and the Irish border.\"\n\nBBC political correspondent Ben Wright said the UK government was \"straining to show that it does have a route-map for Brexit\".\n\nHe said ministers were also attempting to \"subtly\" put the issue onto the negotiating table sooner than Brussels wants.\n\n\"They want to hustle EU negotiators into talking about trade much sooner than Brussels intends,\" our correspondent said.", "id": "9217943", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Brexit: UK suggests 'temporary customs union' with {"timeCrawl": "23:25:00", "uri": "710024089", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T23:25:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "Yorkshire Post", "uri": "yorkshirepost.co.uk", "id": "3428"}, "url": "http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/yorkshire-businesses-facing-a-brexit-red-tape-bombshell-as-government-sets-out-future-trade-plans-1-8704778", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Publishing the two favoured options for a future customs arrangement with the EU, the Government has unveiled plans for a unique \"mirroring\" model that could remove the need for border checks even after the UK leaves the Customs Union.\n\nMinisters claim the proposals will minimise post-Brexit trade barriers to industry, while freeing Britain up to strike new trade deals with other countries.\n\nHowever, opponents argue that both options are likely to involve additional paperwork for businesses - while mirroring would leave companies facing a complex two-tier tariff system.\n\n\"[Ministers] might promise frictionless trade, but they are offering a red tape bombshell for British business,\" said Labour MP and Vote Leave Watch chairman, Chuka Umunna.\n\n\"Ministers effectively concede that Britain will need to stay in the Customs Union for transition. But... such a transition only moves the cliff edge for business from 2019 to 2021.\n\n\"If we leave the Customs Union, British firms will still face damaging disruption to their imports, exports and supply chains.\n\n\"To truly ensure frictionless trade between Britain and the European Union, the Government should negotiate to keep Britain in the Customs Union after Brexit.\"\n\nThe Government published the customs proposals ahead of the second round of formal Brexit negotiations later this month.\n\nThe first approach - described as a \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\" - would see the UK and EU trading as third parties, while relying on technology and trade agreements to minimise customs delays.\n\nThis would allow the UK to set its own domestic customs rules. However, the Government admits it would mean \"an increase in administration\" for businesses, and would likely require the introduction of new IT systems and notification procedures at ports.\n\nThe second approach - the mirroring model - would see the UK continue to apply EU customs rules to external borders thereby removing the need for a EU-UK customs border. This would be accompanied by a separate system for products imported solely for domestic markets, for which the UK would be free to set its own, lower tariffs.\n\nOfficials have heralded this model as an \"innovative\" approach to achieving \"frictionless\" trade with the EU. But they also admit it is \"untested, and would require a \"robust enforcement mechanism\" to ensure the correct tariffs are being applied.\n\nThe proposals were largely welcomed by industry yesterday, with the CBI describing them as a \"critical first step forward\". Director general Josh Hardie said the additional clarity \"is vital for businesses making long-term investment decisions today\".\n\nThe Associated British Ports - which manages ports in Hull, Goole and Grimsby - said it was \"committed to working with Government to make sure trade can flow as smoothly as possible following the UK's exit from the Customs Union\".\n\nWhile West and North Yorkshire Chamber of Commerce urged the Government to focus its resources \"on the conclusion of a successful customs deal with the EU\".\n\nHowever, the Brexit Select Committee chairman, Hilary Benn, argued the proposals - which also include plans for a \"temporary customs union\" with the EU - provided little certainty.\n\n\"Six months on from the Brexit white paper, UK businesses are today still no clearer about what will actually happen to our trade with the EU after March 2019,\" he said. \"We have no idea whether the EU will agree to the Government's proposals and if they are rejected, then what?\"\n\nThe Tory MP Anna Soubry, who co-chairs the all-party parliamentary group on EU relations, added: \"Ministers appear to be moving in the right direction, but they need to go further.\n\n\"No new agreement with the EU can fully replace the benefits of customs union membership.\"\n\nThe Department for Exiting the EU is also due to publish its latest negotiating position paper today, ahead of the next round of talks on August 28.\n\nThe document, which focuses on the issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic, restates the Government's intention to avoid any return to a physical border between the two nations. It includes a commitment to ensuring there is \"no change\" to the Common Travel Areas that allows for free travel between the UK and Ireland, while dismissing the idea of a customs border on the Irish Sea.\n\nCommenting on the paper, a Government source said both sides \"need to show flexibility and imagination\" on the issue.\n\nPublishing the two favoured options for a future customs arrangement with the EU, the Government has unveiled plans for a unique \"mirroring\" model that could remove the need for border checks even after the UK leaves the Customs Union.\n\nMinisters claim the proposals will minimise post-Brexit trade barriers to industry, while freeing Britain up to strike new trade deals with other countries.\n\nHowever, opponents argue that both options are likely to involve additional paperwork for businesses - while mirroring would leave companies facing a complex two-tier tariff system.\n\n\"[Ministers] might promise frictionless trade, but they are offering a red tape bombshell for British business,\" said Labour MP and Vote Leave Watch chairman, Chuka Umunna.\n\n\"Ministers effectively concede that Britain will need to stay in the Customs Union for transition. But... such a transition only moves the cliff edge for business from 2019 to 2021.\n\n\"If we leave the Customs Union, British firms will still face damaging disruption to their imports, exports and supply chains.\n\n\"To truly ensure frictionless trade between Britain and the European Union, the Government should negotiate to keep Britain in the Customs Union after Brexit.\"\n\nThe Government published the customs proposals ahead of the second round of formal Brexit negotiations later this month.\n\nThe first approach - described as a \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\" - would see the UK and EU trading as third parties, while relying on technology and trade agreements to minimise customs delays.\n\nThis would allow the UK to set its own domestic customs rules. However, the Government admits it would mean \"an increase in administration\" for businesses, and would likely require the introduction of new IT systems and notification procedures at ports.\n\nThe second approach - the mirroring model - would see the UK continue to apply EU customs rules to external borders thereby removing the need for a EU-UK customs border. This would be accompanied by a separate system for products imported solely for domestic markets, for which the UK would be free to set its own, lower tariffs.\n\nOfficials have heralded this model as an \"innovative\" approach to achieving \"frictionless\" trade with the EU. But they also admit it is \"untested, and would require a \"robust enforcement mechanism\" to ensure the correct tariffs are being applied.\n\nThe proposals were largely welcomed by industry yesterday, with the CBI describing them as a \"critical first step forward\". Director general Josh Hardie said the additional clarity \"is vital for businesses making long-term investment decisions today\".\n\nThe Associated British Ports - which manages ports in Hull, Goole and Grimsby - said it was \"committed to working with Government to make sure trade can flow as smoothly as possible following the UK's exit from the Customs Union\".\n\nWhile West and North Yorkshire Chamber of Commerce urged the Government to focus its resources \"on the conclusion of a successful customs deal with the EU\".\n\nHowever, the Brexit Select Committee chairman, Hilary Benn, argued the proposals - which also include plans for a \"temporary customs union\" with the EU - provided little certainty.\n\n\"Six months on from the Brexit white paper, UK businesses are today still no clearer about what will actually happen to our trade with the EU after March 2019,\" he said. \"We have no idea whether the EU will agree to the Government's proposals and if they are rejected, then what?\"\n\nThe Tory MP Anna Soubry, who co-chairs the all-party parliamentary group on EU relations, added: \"Ministers appear to be moving in the right direction, but they need to go further.\n\n\"No new agreement with the EU can fully replace the benefits of customs union membership.\"\n\nThe Department for Exiting the EU is also due to publish its latest negotiating position paper today, ahead of the next round of talks on August 28.\n\nThe document, which focuses on the issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic, restates the Government's intention to avoid any return to a physical border between the two nations. It includes a commitment to ensuring there is \"no change\" to the Common Travel Areas that allows for free travel between the UK and Ireland, while dismissing the idea of a customs border on the "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/article36033382.ece/18184/AUTOCROP/h342/bpanews_f552885a-b122-448b-b313-b5d130bc177c_1\n\nBritain will not be able to enact post-Brexit free trade deals with countries like the United States until proposed temporary customs arrangements with the European Union end, David Davis has admitted.\n\nThe Brexit Secretary published plans for a time-limited transition period to ensure businesses on both sides of the Channel only have to adapt once to rule changes on the import and export of goods.\n\nThe \"future partnership paper\" also contained two potential options for a long-term deal once the interim period expires.\n\nThe more ambitious option, described as \"innovative and unprecedented\", would see Britain \"mirroring\" Brussels tariffs for goods that will eventually enter the EU to avoid the need for a UK-EU customs border.\n\nAlternatively, a \"streamlined\" approach would see the UK negotiate agreements with the EU to reduce trade barriers and harness technology to avoid long queues at ports.\n\nBut European Parliament Brexit coordinator Guy Verhofstadt said \"invisible borders\" are a \"fantasy\", while European Commission chief negotiator Michel Barnier said talks on customs could not begin until there was agreement on the so-called \"divorce bill\", citizens rights and the Irish border.\n\nBefore any new customs deal is negotiated and implemented, Britain will seek to avoid a \"cliff-edge\" for businesses by putting in place temporary arrangements that are broadly similar to the EU's customs union.\n\n#Brexit Secretary David Davis speaks on temporarily keeping the custom arrangements the same after we leave the EU pic.twitter.com/UjYKt4wGTd -- Good Morning Britain (@GMB)\n\nAugust 15, 2017\n\nThe adoption of this approach is likely to be seen as a victory for Chancellor Philip Hammond, who favours a \"softer\" pro-business Brexit.\n\nMr Davis admitted that during this period, which he said would last \"something like two years\", the UK will not be able to do business under new free trade agreements with countries like the US or Australia.\n\nAsked whether the UK could enact new free trade deals during the temporary period, Mr Davis told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"No, negotiate and sign.\n\n\"You couldn't have an arrangement whereby we have unfettered access to the European market but also the right to bring in raw materials from outside.\n\n\"Because you'd have what they call arbitrage - someone would bring in cheap goods and then sell them on. But we should be able to have an arrangement by which we can do the negotiation, sign it off, but not enter (it) into effect.\"\n\nMr Davis also refused to rule out paying for the temporary deal, while officials admitted the European Court of Justice's role in enforcing customs union rules during the interim period would be subject to negotiations.\n\nDavid Davis says Brexit negotiations are going \"incredibly well\" #r4today pic.twitter.com/A3zbdNCbkH -- BBC Radio 4 Today (@BBCr4today)\n\nAugust 15, 2017\n\nPressed on whether the UK would have to pay, Mr Davis said: \"I am not going to do the negotiation on air. What we are not going to do, let's be clear, we are not going to continue the \u00a310 billion a year net contributions we currently have.\"\n\nThe partnership paper is the first in a series of documents the Government hopes to publish in the coming weeks in order to inform Brexit negotiations. But Mr Barnier insisted a new customs relationship cannot be discussed until agreement is reached on phase one of the talks.\n\nHe tweeted: \"The quicker #UK & EU27 agree on citizens, settling accounts and #Ireland, the quicker we can discuss customs & future relationship.\"", "id": "9295942", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Post-Brexit free trade deals on hold until customs transition ends, Davis admits", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/article36033382.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/bpanews_f552885a-b122-448b-b313-b5d130bc177c_1", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1717, "freq": 2, "date": "2017-08-15", "amb": false, "textEnd": 1732}], "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "concepts": [], "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "id": 108, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 139, "label": "dmoz/Society/Government", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Government"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 140, "label": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 147, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Customer Management", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Customer_Management"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 269, "label": "dmoz/Business/International Business and Trade", "uri": "dmoz/Business/International_Business_and_Trade"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 270, "label": "dmoz/Business/International Business and Trade/Services", "uri": "dmoz/Business/International_Business_and_Trade/Services"}], "time": "14:26:00"}
{"timeCrawl": "12:39:00", "uri": "709762652", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:39:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "uri": "dnaindia.com", "id": "492"}, "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-factbox-britain-s-proposals-for-post-brexit-customs-agreement-with-eu-2530826", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Britain sought to push forward talks with the European Union on Tuesday, setting out proposals for a temporary post-Brexit customs agreement with the bloc and two options for how its longer-term trading relationship could work.\n\nWhile the government is clear Britain will leave the EU's customs union in March 2019, it has proposed a continued close association for a time-limited period to minimise disruption and allow a smooth and orderly transition to the new arrangements.\n\nThis period would involve:\n\n- a new customs union with no customs processes or duties between Britain and the EU, and a shared external tariff\n\n- Britain being able to pursue new trade agreements with non-EU countries during the interim period, although such deals would not be brought into effect until after the transition\n\nThe government put forward two options for its future customs relationship with the EU:\n\n1) \"A HIGHLY STREAMLINED CUSTOMS ARRANGEMENT\"\n\nThis would see the UK and EU trade with each other effectively as third parties but look to make customs procedures as frictionless as possible, including using technology to make it easier for businesses to comply with customs procedures.\n\nBritain acknowledged this system would involve an increased administrative burden compared to being inside the EU's customs union. It also said it had looked at customs agreements between other countries but was not seeking to replicate another country's model.\n\nBritain said such a system would:\n\n- ensure businesses declare goods for import or export and provide the revenue and customs department with documentation including customs declarations, safety and security information\n\n- enable the government to verify a declaration has been made and ensure any duties have been paid\n\n- require new systems to be put in place on both the UK and EU sides, as well as Britain making improvements to its domestic regime\n\n- reduce the risk of delays at ports by using technology such as pre-arrival notification of consignments, linked to customs declarations and vehicle registration numbers, so vehicles do not need to stop at the border\n\n- replicate existing cooperation with the EU on data sharing and customs cooperation to reduce security risks and improve targeting of inspections\n\n- reduce the time and cost of complying with customs procedures through measures such as self-assessment, allowing traders to calculate their own customs duties and speeding up authorisation through greater automation\n\n- involve looking to agree simplified systems for moving goods across borders including:\n\na) a continued waiver from the requirement to submit entry and exit declarations for goods moving between UK and EU\n\nb) membership of the Common Transit Convention, meaning goods could travel from the UK through the EU to the rest of the world, and vice versa, without paying EU duties\n\n2) \"A NEW CUSTOMS PARTNERSHIP WITH THE EU\"\n\nThis would see Britain align its approach to customs with the EU in a way that removed the need for a UK-EU customs border. One such option would be for Britain to mirror the EU's requirements for imports from the rest of the world where the final destination is the EU.\n\nThe government acknowledged this was an untested approach which would take time to implement.\n\nBritain said that under such a system:\n\n- it would need to apply the same tariffs as the EU and the same treatment on rules of origin for goods arriving in the UK before heading on to the EU\n\n- mirroring the EU's customs approach at its external border would ensure all goods entering the bloc via the UK have paid the correct EU duties\n\n- the need to introduce customs procedures between Britain and the EU would be removed, so goods moving between the two would be treated as they are now for customs purposes\n\n- Britain could apply its own tariffs and trade policy to UK exports and imports from other countries\n\n- Britain would require a \"robust enforcement mechanism\" to ensure goods that do not comply with EU trade policy stay in Britain\n\nNEW LEGISLATION\n\nAs rules governing customs mostly come under EU law, the government said Britain would introduce new domestic legislation via a customs bill later this year.\n\nThis legislation would seek to ensure British law remains as consistent as possible with EU law, but will also give the government powers to operate standalone customs, tax and excise systems in the event Britain and the EU fail to reach a deal.\n\nNO DEAL SCENARIO\n\nBritain said that while it hoped to reach a negotiated agreement with the EU, it was also looking at ways to mitigate the impact of not reaching a deal. It said that it expected a \"no deal\" scenario would mean:\n\n- Britain would treat trade with the EU as it currently treats trade with non-EU countries and apply customs duties and import tax on EU imports\n\n- Britain would require traders to be registered, with those exporting to the EU needing to submit export declarations and some goods may need export licences\n\n- The EU would apply the same customs rules and tax to imports from Britain that it applies to non-EU countries\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "id": {"timeCrawl": "13:15:00", "uri": "709779060", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:15:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/uk/brexit-uk-to-mirror-existing-eu-customs-system-1.3187227", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The plans, published on Tuesday, provide the first detailed look at the UK's negotiating strategy and also reveal new reporting requirements for businesses as a way to minimise delays at international borders and avoid the need to build extra physical infrastructure.\n\nThe government has put forward two mechanisms: a process to track all goods and components, and a repayment mechanism - whereby importers pay whichever is higher of the EU or UK tariffs and claim a refund should the end destination be the one with lower tariffs.\n\n\"This is an innovative and untested approach that would take time to develop and implement,\" the Brexit Department said, adding that it wants to \"explore\" the approach with businesses to understand the complexities involved.\n\nThe compromises are outlined in a long-awaited policy paper on future customs arrangements that promises \"the freest and most frictionless system possible\" via a complex series of modifications to the existing system.\n\n\"The approaches we are setting out today will benefit both the EU and UK and avoid a cliff-edge for businesses and individuals on both sides,\" according to UK Brexit secretary David Davis.\n\n\"The way we approach the movement of goods across our border will be a critical building block for our independent trade policy,\" he added.\n\n\"An interim period would mean businesses only need to adjust once to the new regime and would allow for a smooth and orderly transition.\"\n\nBut explanatory briefings by British government officials revealed that the UK government's intention is for this interim phase to involve a new, temporary, customs union with the EU that would be substantially the same as now.\n\nThe paper said this would be a \"new and time-limited customs union between the UK and EU customs union based on a shared external tariff and without customs processes and duties between the UK and the EU\".\n\nOfficials confirmed while this would technically involve leaving the existing EU customs union after March 2019, it would be close enough to existing arrangements that Britain would only be able to negotiate, rather than implement, new trade deals with third-party countries.\n\nThis contradicts confident promises made by trade secretary Liam Fox and the chancellor, Philip Hammond, in a joint article published on Sunday.\n\nThe article was heralded as a victory for the international trade secretary's ambitions to show the benefits of an independent trade policy long before the next election.\n\n\"In March 2019 the United Kingdom will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation,\" they wrote in the Sunday Telegraph.\n\n\"When we've left the customs union, we will build on these relationships by negotiating as an independent nation with the freedom to sign bilateral free trade agreements.\"\n\nOn Tuesday, UK civil service officials refused to say whether new deals could be signed during this interim phase, and stressed that implementation was impossible until after the UK moved to its final customs arrangement.\n\nBut even the two scenarios outlined by the government for this end state position could still involve substantial overlap with EU customs procedures to try to minimise chaos at the ports.\n\nThe second, and more ambitious, of two options outlined in Tuesday's paper was called a \"new customs partnership\" and \"would involve the UK mirroring the EU's requirements for imports from the rest of the world where their final destination is the EU\".\n\nOfficials hope this would remove the need for all customs checks with the EU because UK exports would also be exempt from tariffs under the planned free trade agreement - though all such promises are subject to extensive negotiation with other member states.\n\nThe other option envisaged by the government after the interim stage would be a form of the current customs arrangements with countries outside the EU but rely heavily on new technology, such as number plate recognition, to try to avoid physical checks at the border.\n\nOfficials conceded that both these options would entail significant new red tape for business as they would entail shifting the reporting burden on to exporters at the point of departure rather than building new lorry parks and border posts.\n\nMr Fox struck a defiant note in a statement to accompany the new strategy paper, insisting \"leaving the customs union will allow us to operate a fully independent trade policy in Britain's national interest.\"\n\n\"We will seek a new customs arrangement that ensures that trade between the UK and the EU remains as frictionless as possible and allows us to forge new trade relationships with out partners in Europe and around the world\".", "id": "9283495", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Brexit: UK to 'mirror' existing EU customs system", "image": The proposals for new customs arrangements to allow the 'freest and most frictionless possible' trade with the EU are being outlined in the first of a series of 'future partnership papers' from the government.\n\nThey come after chancellor Philip Hammond and international trade secretary Liam Fox said at the weekend that the UK would pull out of both the single market and the customs union in 2019. Setting out its aims showed the UK's 'desire to ensure our exit from the EU is smooth, orderly and successful,' the government said.\n\nTemporary arrangements could allow trade deals to be negotiated with other countries, something EU members are forbidden from doing.\n\nThe government is putting forward two options, including one for a customs partnership that would negate the need for a customs {"timeCrawl": "08:39:00", "uri": "709660828", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T08:30:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "uri": "gantdaily.com", "id": "537"}, "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/15/britain-tries-to-calm-fears-over-eu-trade-after-brexit/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Britain wants to keep existing customs rules with Europe for about two years after Brexit as it tries to protect manufacturing exports and jobs.\n\nWith a third round of Brexit negotiations due later this month, the U.K. is under growing pressure to clarify its plans for trade and immigration once it leaves the European Union in March 2019.\n\nThe U.K. government said Tuesday in a position paper that it wanted to negotiate customs arrangements that \"facilitate the freest and most frictionless possible trade in goods between the U.K. and the EU.\"\n\nDuring a limited transitional period after Brexit, the U.K. would seek to retain as many of the existing arrangements as possible to avoid the chaos of an abrupt break with its biggest export market, and to allow time for a new trade deal to be negotiated.\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the U.K. and the EU,\" the government said.\n\nThe EU customs union allows goods to move freely, with no tariffs and few checks, between member states. If Britain leaves the EU without a new trade deal or transitional arrangements, business and consumers could face massive disruption and higher prices.\n\n\"What business is concerned about ... is the infamous 'cliff edge,'\" Britain's chief Brexit negotiator David Davis told the BBC, adding that the transitional period was most likely to last about two years.\n\nTreasury chief Philip Hammond said earlier this month that Britain may need a transition of up to three years to protect the economy from the shock that a clean break with the EU would bring.\n\nDavis said the U.K. would also try to negotiate and sign trade deals with countries outside the EU -- such as the U.S. -- but acknowledged they could not be implemented until the Brexit transition period is over.\n\nThere's a huge amount at stake for the U.K. economy, which has slowed sharply this year. Businesses have put investment plans on hold while they wait for greater clarity about what Brexit means.\n\nThe CBI, which represents 190,000 businesses, said it was encouraged by the government's proposals.\n\n\"But the clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible,\" it said in a statement.\n\nManufacturing makes up 45% of U.K. exports and directly employs 2.7 million people. EU member countries account for more than 50% of British manufactured exports, and integrated supply chains mean goods can cross borders several times during the production process.", "id": "9237655", {"timeCrawl": "11:33:00", "uri": "709732036", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T11:31:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/aug/15/uk-mirror-eu-customs-system-brexit-plans-reveal-liam-fox", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Britain expects to \"mirror\" much of the existing EU customs system both during and after Brexit, according to new government plans that could prevent Liam Fox's immediate ability to implement new trade deals.\n\nThis first detailed look at Whitehall's negotiating strategy also reveals new reporting requirements for businesses as a way to minimise delays at international borders and avoid the need to build extra physical infrastructure.\n\nThe compromises are outlined in a long-awaited policy paper on future customs arrangements that promises \"the freest and most frictionless system possible\" via a complex series of modifications to the existing system.\n\n\"The approaches we are setting out today will benefit both the EU and UK and avoid a cliff-edge for businesses and individuals on both sides,\" said the Brexit secretary, David Davis.\n\n\"The way we approach the movement of goods across our border will be a critical building block for our independent trade policy,\" he added. \"An interim period would mean businesses only need to adjust once to the new regime and would allow for a smooth and orderly transition.\"\n\nBut explanatory briefings by government officials revealed that the government's intention is for this interim phase to involve a new, temporary, customs union with the EU that would be substantially the same as now.\n\nThe government paper said this would be a \"new and time limited customs union between the UK and EU customs union based on a shared external tariff and without customs processes and duties between the UK and the EU\".\n\nOfficials confirmed that while this would technically involved leaving the existing EU customs union after March 2019, it would be close enough to existing arrangements that Britain would only be able to negotiate, rather than implement, new trade deals with third-party countries.\n\nThis contradicts confident promises made by Fox and the chancellor, Philip Hammond, in a joint article published on Sunday that was heralded as a victory for the international trade secretary's ambitions to show the benefits of an independent trade policy long before the next election.\n\n\"In March 2019 the United Kingdom ... will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation,\" they wrote in the Sunday Telegraph. \"When we've left the customs union, we will build on these relationships by negotiating as an independent nation with the freedom to sign bilateral free trade agreements.\"\n\nOn Tuesday, Whitehall officials refused to say whether new deals could be signed during this interim phase, and stressed that implementation was impossible until after the UK moved to its final customs arrangement.\n\nBut even the two scenarios outlined by the government for this end state position could still involve substantial overlap with EU customs procedures to try to minimise chaos at the ports.\n\nThe second, and more ambitious, of two options outlined in Tuesday's paper was called a \"new customs partnership\" and \"would involve the UK mirroring the EU's requirements for imports from the rest of the world where their final destination is the EU\".\n\nOfficials hope this would remove the need for all customs checks with the EU because UK exports would also be exempt from tariffs under the planned free trade agreement - though all such promises are subject to extensive negotiation with other member states.\n\nThe other option envisaged by the government after the interim stage would be a form of the current customs arrangements with countries outside the EU but rely heavily on new technology, such as number plate recognition, to try to avoid physical checks at the border.\n\nOfficials conceded that both these options would entail significant new red tape for business as they would entail shifting the reporting burden on to exporters at the point of departure rather than building new lorry parks and border posts.\n\nLiam Fox struck a defiant note in a statement to accompany the new strategy paper, insisting \"leaving the customs union will allow us to operate a fully independent trade policy in Britain's national interest.\"\n\n\"We will seek a new customs arrangement that ensures that trade between the UK and the EU remains as frictionless as possible and allows us to forge new trade relationships with out partners in Europe and around the world\".", "id": "9265844", "details": {"liCnt": 40}, "date": "2017-08-15", {"timeCrawl": "12:38:00", "uri": "709761567", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:38:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4792320/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON, Aug 15 (Reuters) - Britain sought to push forward talks with the European Union on Tuesday, setting out proposals for a temporary post-Brexit customs agreement with the bloc and two options for how its longer-term trading relationship could work.\n\nBelow is a summary of the proposals:\n\nTRANSITION PERIOD\n\nWhile the government is clear Britain will leave the EU's customs union in March 2019, it has proposed a continued close association for a time-limited period to minimise disruption and allow a smooth and orderly transition to the new arrangements.\n\nThis period would involve:\n\n- a new customs union with no customs processes or duties between Britain and the EU, and a shared external tariff\n\n- Britain being able to pursue new trade agreements with non-EU countries during the interim period, although such deals would not be brought into effect until after the transition\n\nThe government put forward two options for its future customs relationship with the EU:\n\n1) \"A HIGHLY STREAMLINED CUSTOMS ARRANGEMENT\"\n\nThis would see the UK and EU trade with each other effectively as third parties but look to make customs procedures as frictionless as possible, including using technology to make it easier for businesses to comply with customs procedures.\n\nBritain acknowledged this system would involve an increased administrative burden compared to being inside the EU's customs union. It also said it had looked at customs agreements between other countries but was not seeking to replicate another country's model.\n\nBritain said such a system would:\n\n- ensure businesses declare goods for import or export and provide the revenue and customs department with documentation including customs declarations, safety and security information\n\n- enable the government to verify a declaration has been made and ensure any duties have been paid\n\n- require new systems to be put in place on both the UK and EU sides, as well as Britain making improvements to its domestic regime\n\n- reduce the risk of delays at ports by using technology such as pre-arrival notification of consignments, linked to customs declarations and vehicle registration numbers, so vehicles do not need to stop at the border\n\n- replicate existing cooperation with the EU on data sharing and customs cooperation to reduce security risks and improve targeting of inspections\n\n- reduce the time and cost of complying with customs procedures through measures such as self-assessment, allowing traders to calculate their own customs duties and speeding up authorisation through greater automation\n\n- involve looking to agree simplified systems for moving goods across borders including:\n\na) a continued waiver from the requirement to submit entry and exit declarations for goods moving between UK and EU\n\nb) membership of the Common Transit Convention, meaning goods could travel from the UK through the EU to the rest of the world, and vice versa, without paying EU duties\n\n2) \"A NEW CUSTOMS PARTNERSHIP WITH THE EU\"\n\nThis would see Britain align its approach to customs with the EU in a way that removed the need for a UK-EU customs border. One such option would be for Britain to mirror the EU's requirements for imports from the rest of the world where the final destination is the EU.\n\nThe government acknowledged this was an untested approach which would take time to implement.\n\nBritain said that under such a system:\n\n- it would need to apply the same tariffs as the EU and the same treatment on rules of origin for goods arriving in the UK before heading on to the EU\n\n- mirroring the EU's customs approach at its external border would ensure all goods entering the bloc via the UK have paid the correct EU duties\n\n- the need to introduce customs procedures between Britain and the EU would be removed, so goods moving between the two would be treated as they are now for customs purposes\n\n- Britain could apply its own tariffs and trade policy to UK exports and imports from other countries\n\n- Britain would require a \"robust enforcement mechanism\" to ensure goods that do not comply with EU trade policy stay in Britain\n\nNEW LEGISLATION\n\nAs rules governing customs mostly come under EU law, the government said Britain would introduce new domestic legislation via a customs bill later this year.\n\nThis legislation would seek to ensure British law remains as consistent as possible with EU law, but will also give the government powers to operate standalone customs, tax and excise systems in the event Britain and the EU fail to reach a deal.\n\nNO DEAL SCENARIO\n\nBritain said that while it hoped to reach a negotiated agreement with the EU, it was also looking at ways to mitigate the impact of not reaching a deal. It said that it expected a \"no deal\" scenario would mean:\n\n- Britain would treat trade with the EU as it currently treats trade with non-EU countries and apply customs duties and import tax on EU imports\n\n- Britain would require traders to be registered, with those exporting to the EU needing to submit export declarations and some goods may need export licences\n\n- The EU would apply the same customs rules and tax to imports from Britain that it applies to non-EU countries\n\n(Reporting by Kylie MacLellan; Editing by Gareth Jones)", "id": "9276657", "details": {}, "date": "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Theresa May is expected to arrive back in Downing Street on Thursday as ministers spend the week fleshing out details of their hopes for Britain's future with the EU after Brexit.\n\nThe Government will spell out its aims for new customs arrangements after the UK has quit the bloc in documents released by Brexit Secretary David Davis.\n\nA position paper on the fraught issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic is also due to be published later this week.\n\nIt comes as Mrs May i s expected to be back at her desk on Thursday after holidays in Europe totalling around three weeks.\n\nThe Prime Minister enjoyed a break in Italy lasting nearly a week at the end of July and is now away with husband Philip in Switzerland.\n\nThe Government has faced complaints from Brussels over a lack of clarity on the British negotiating position on Brexit.\n\nDowning Street said it was clear the talks had shown that the divorce could only be settled with in light of the future relationship with the EU.\n\nThe Prime Minister's official spokesman said: \"We had the first rounds of the negotiation and those talks have shown that many of the withdrawal questions can only be settled in light of the future partnership, so now is the time to set out our approach to that partnership to inform the upcoming negotiations and to provide citizens and businesses at home and across Europe with a deeper understanding of our thinking.\"\n\nEU chief negotiator Michel Barnier is reported to have warned his first two rounds of talks with Mr Davis, covering the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\", had made limited progress.\n\nMeanwhile, The Times said the slow progress so far had led to complaints in Whitehall that senior officials were now trying to rush through decisions in an attempt to break the policy logjam.\n\nThere were said to be concerns that Cabinet Secretary Sir Jeremy Heywood and the Permanent Secretary at the Department for Exiting the EU were railroading issues through at a time when many ministers were away, leading to poor decision-making.\n\nBut following a summer marked by speculation over a possible leadership challenge and jostling for position among senior ministers over Brexit, there was some respite for the Prime Minister with an apparent truce between two of the leading protagonists.\n\nChancellor Philip Hammond, who favours a \"soft\", pro-business Brexit, and the Brexiteer International Development Secretary Liam Fox signed up to a joint statement at the weekend agreeing that there would have to be a transition period after Britain has left the EU.\n\nThey agreed that while the measure was necessary to ensure there was no \"cliff-edge\" break for businesses, it would be time-limited and that Britain would leave the EU single market and the customs union when it left the bloc.\n\nSenior Conservative MP Bernard Jenkin welcomed unity in the Cabinet and questioned why the EU would not treat the UK the same as other countries who have no free trade deal with the bloc but have agreements over aviation services, customs facilitation and product recognition.\n\nMr Jenkin, chairman of the Public Administration and Constitutional Affairs Committee, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Why wouldn't they afford us the same kind of reasonable arrangements unless they want to punish us?\n\n\"And if they want to punish us, should we be intimidated by their determination to punish us?\n\n\"Are they such a dysfunctional and destructive organisation that they would punish themselves as well as us by imposing such a ridiculous scenario - and of course they After Brexit, there will be no need for companies to fill in additional paperwork, ensuring that goods move smoothly across the border with the rest of the EU countries.\n\nIn 2016, Britain imports
