{"timeCrawl": "18:35:00", "uri": "708877088", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T18:35:00Z", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/philip-hammond-accused-of-surrender-to-hard-line-brexiteers-over-single-market-36026721.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/article36026720.ece/e8b83/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-369bd278-44ef-442f-af79-1667f9a4fb04_I1.jpg\n\nChancellor Philip Hammond has been accused of caving in to hard line Cabinet Brexiteers after accepting Britain will withdraw from the European single market and the customs union when it leaves the EU in 20 months' time.\n\nAfter a summer of ministerial feuding, Mr Hammond, who favours a \"softer\" pro-business Brexit, came together with International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, from the Brexiteer wing of the party, to declare there could be no \"back door\" attempt to keep Britain in the EU.\n\nIn a joint article for the Sunday Telegraph, they agreed that while a period of transition would be needed after 2019 to prevent a damaging \"cliff-edge\" break with the EU, it would be \"time limited\" and would mean pulling out of both the single market and the customs union.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May will hope the intervention of the two ministers will cool temperatures in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit and speculation of a possible leadership challenge when MPs return to Westminster in September.\n\nHowever, Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable said it was clear that Mr Hammond had lost his power struggle with the Brexiteers.\n\n\"Over the summer, we heard that Philip Hammond was courageously fighting off the more extreme Brexiteers. Supposedly he was looking for a compromise to keep Britain within the customs union and single market as long as possible,\" he said.\n\n\"The rebellion didn't last very long. He has now teamed up with one of the more extreme and ideological supporters of a 'hard Brexit'. It is now painfully clear who calls the shots in the Cabinet; it isn't the Chancellor.\"\n\nIn contrast, the joint move was welcomed by the pro-Brexit Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson who said it was the \"right way forward\".\n\n\"Create certainty and great new European relationship. Get job done + on with Global Britain,\" he wrote on Twitter.\n\nIn their article, Mr Hammond and Dr Fox said a transition period was needed to give businesses confidence they would be able to carry on trading normally.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU,\" they wrote.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the leading Conservative Remainer Anna Soubry indicated she could be prepared to join with politicians from other parties to stop the country \"staggering recklessly\" towards a hard break with Brussels.\n\n\"Could I ever see myself joining with like-minded people who want to save our country from such an appalling fate? And has that moment arrived yet?\" she wrote in an article for The Mail on Sunday.\n\n\"The answer to the first question is 'it is not impossible'; the answer to the second is 'no'. But I would be betraying my principles if I did not make it clear that country must always come before party.\"\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis said exactly how the transitional arrangements would work had still to be determined.\n\n\"By triggering Article 50 in March of this year we leave in March 2019, what the transition period will look like is down to the negotiations,\" he said during a surprise appearance at Alex Salmond's show at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe.\n\nHowever Labour MP Ben Bradshaw, a supporter of the Open Britain campaign, said that without membership of the single market and the customs union, the country would be worse off.\n\n\"Pulling Britain out of the single market and the customs union in 2019 will drive our economy over a cliff edge, putting jobs and family finances at risk,\" he said.\n\n\"Nobody voted to be poorer last year but that is exactly what will happen if the Government continues to put Eurosceptic dogma ahead of the national interest.\"", "id": "8953070", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-13", "title": "Philip Hammond accused of surrender to hard line Brexiteers over single market", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/article36026720.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/PANews%20BT_P-369bd278-44ef-442f-af79-1667f9a4fb04_I1.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 3339, "date": "2019-03-", "amb": false, "textEnd": 3349}], "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13", "concepts": [], "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "id": 63, "label": "dmoz/Society/Work", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Work"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 140, "label": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 143, "label": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges and Universities", "uri": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges_and_Universities"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 151, "label": "dmoz/Business/Marketing and Advertising", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Marketing_and_Advertising"}], "time": "18:35:00"}
{"timeCrawl": "05:31:00", "uri": "710123006", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T05:31:00Z", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "source": {"title": "Irish Examiner", "uri": "irishexaminer.com", "id": "817"}, "url": "http://www.irishexaminer.com/analysis/britain-reveals-that-it-wants-it-all-and-then-some-more-457138.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "In its first published position paper on Brexit, Theresa May and her government have taken the 'have their cake and eat it' approach.\n\nToday another position paper is to be published which sets out Britain's stall in relation to the North -- and again they want it all their own way.\n\nUK government sources have said that they will be pushing to avoid any physical border infrastructure and border posts between the North and Ireland for any purpose following\n\nBrexit -- which undoubtedly is a positive.\n\nAt the same time, they are not open to any possibility of moving the border out into the Irish Sea as had been suggested by both Taoiseach Leo Varadkar and Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney in recent times.\n\nA seamless and invisible border idea, while welcome, is a pure contradiction.\n\nIn the same breath, highlighting the importance of cementing clear guarantees of no change to the ability to move freely around the Common Travel Area that exists now, today's expected paper will also state that the UK must have the flexibility to design its own arrangements with regards to the border.\n\nPerhaps the UK government is not yet completely sure of what it wants so has asked for everything.\n\nWhen it comes to the EU customs union, the UK is intent on leaving. But they also want an easing out period, and at the same time they believe they should be allowed sidle up to other countries to hammer out side deals.\n\nThe ink on the position paper had barely dried when the demands were dubbed a \"fantasy\" by the European Parliament's Brexit co-ordinator, Guy Verhofstadt.\n\nOn Twitter, Mr Verhofstadt said: \"To be in & out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy. First need to secure citizens rights & a financial settlement.\"\n\nWhile Mr Verhofstadt may have signalled the need to prioritise other issues ahead of the customs union, there is no doubt that whatever agreement is reached in relation to this will have a significant impact on this country.\n\nThe customs union has meant that Ireland and the other 27 states in the EU have enjoyed free trade between countries and have also imposed the same tariff on imports from outside the EU.\n\nFor a small country like Ireland, being part of the customs union has meant being a member of a bloc of 500m people, which undoubtedly wields significant leverage in bargaining with other nations.\n\nCurrently the EU is in the middle of such negotiations with the US on the controversial Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership agreement and on a similar deal with Japan.\n\nUnderstandably, Britain would like to keep the cushy tariff-free deal between itself and all other EU countries that comes with being signed up to the customs union.\n\nThey have asked for an interim customs agreement with the EU for approximately two years after the 2019 Brexit talks deadline.\n\nThis would help soften the blow for UK businesses when Britain finally leaves.\n\nBut in a greedy move they also want to negotiate other trade deals in parallel with this -- current rules bar members of the EU customs union from making their own deals outside the bloc.\n\nEssentially, Britain could hammer out new deals with countries like Brazil to import their beef -- which under the EU customs union incurs a 20% tariff -- meaning they could import Brazilian beef at a far cheaper rate than their EU counterparts.\n\nIreland's agri-food sector, meanwhile, has a high dependence on the British market, with 40% of exports destined for the UK market annually.\n\nIrish farmers have already been severely hit by the impacts of Brexit and an influx of cheaper Brazilian beef into the UK would be a further and possibly fatal blow to many working in the agri-food industry here.\n\nThe fact that the UK is finally putting forward and publishing proposals -- 14 months after its citizens voted to leave the European Union -- has to be welcomed.\n\nThe detail of those proposals, however, will have to be toned down before a Brexit deal is reached.", "id": "9408709", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Britain {"timeCrawl": "02:31:00", "uri": "708995548", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T11:00:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "hitechbeacon.com", "uri": "hitechbeacon.com", "id": "19120"}, "url": "http://hitechbeacon.com/2017/08/13/united-kingdom-ministers-to-release-brexit-position-papers.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "\"I've launched this process because with time of the essence, we need to get on with negotiating the bigger issues around our future partnership to ensure we get a deal that delivers a strong United Kingdom and a strong EU\", David Davis, the secretary of state for exiting the European Union, said in a statement.\n\nThe British government has said it will give more details about its policies on Brexit next week.\n\nThe first set of position papers, to be published from this week, will include one covering the Border between Northern Ireland and the Republic after the United Kingdom has left the EU.\n\nAmong the details is one covering the hard issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland once Britain leaves the EU.\n\nThe Sunday Telegraph reported that Britain was seeking a \"Schengen area\" between Britain and Ireland, which would allow free movement of people and a \"light-touch customs regime\" across the border of the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland.\n\nIt added that businesses should be assured there would be no \"cliff edge\" despite fears expressed that the UK could crash out of the EU without reaching a deal, which would see UK-EU relations revert to World Trade Organisation rules.\n\nFree movement for Irish citizens in and out of Britain is expected to continue after Brexit, with the establishment of a Schengen-style area between Ireland and Britain created to resolve the border problem.\n\nThe British ministers also promised a series of papers on their ideas for a \"Future Partnership\" with the EU to be presented in the run-up to October's European Council.\n\nThe documents - setting out proposals for Northern Ireland and the border with Ireland, continuity on the availability of goods and confidentiality, and access to official documents after Brexit - will seek to prove the U.K.is ready for talks to advance to the next stage, he said. The first of these will set out proposals for a new customs agreement, it said.\n\nHis criticism joins that of a growing number of pro-EU figures from across the political spectrum who say Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit strategy is economically damaging and that voters should be given a chance to halt the process.\n\nMeanwhile, former Labour Foreign Secretary David Miliband has called for politicians on all sides to unite to fight back against the \"worst consequences\" of Brexit.\n\nHowever, pro-European finance minister Hammond and ardent Brexiteer trade minister Fox set out a joint position in the Sunday Telegraph that a transition period was needed when Britain leaves the European Union, but single market membership would still end and the interim period would not be used {"timeCrawl": "15:55:00", "uri": "709850515", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:36:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "http://www.businessgreen.com", "uri": "businessgreen.com", "id": "5810"}, "url": "https://www.businessgreen.com/bg/news/3015680/government-promises-to-maintain-high-environmental-standards-in-post-brexit-trade", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Echoing Environment Secretary Michael Gove's assurances, new Brexit position paper promises changes to trading relationships will not lead to lower environmental standards\n\nThe British government has today reasserted its promise that post-Brexit trade with the EU and other markets will not lead to an erosion of the UK's high environmental and animal welfare standards.\n\nIn a long-awaited position paper released this morning, the government set out the UK's stance on its future trading and customs relationship with the EU and other nations, ahead of its next round of negotiations with Brussels.\n\nThe paper makes clear it does not intend Brexit to lead to a watering down of environmental standards, echoing similar assurances contained in the draft repeal bill and recent speeches by Environment Secretary Michael Gove.\n\n\"We will maintain our high level of standards and protect our public services,\" the latest document states. \"As we leave the EU, the government will continue to maintain our high standards for consumers, employees, the environment and animal welfare. The government will also ensure that decisions about how public services including the NHS are delivered for UK citizens, are made by UK governments and not by our trade partners.\"\n\nThe statement echoes promises made earlier this summer by the Defra Secretary Michael Gove, who promised to deliver a 'Green Brexit' that will uphold the UK's environmental standards.\n\nThe paper sets out a vision for the UK's trading relationship with the EU after 2019, when it is scheduled to leave the trading bloc.\n\nIt reveals plans to adopt a transitional arrangement including some form of temporary membership of the Customs Union that leaves the UK free to negotiate new free trade agreements with other countries.\n\nThe government hopes this new arrangement would eventually transition into either a \"streamlined\" customs agreement between the EU and UK that seeks to simplify and remove as many trade barriers as possible between the two parties, or a brand new customs partnership between the EU and the UK that \"removes the need for a UK-EU customs border\".\n\nThe paper also stresses the government's future approach to trade will align with its forthcoming Industrial Strategy, which is widelty expected to focus on boosting markets for clean tech innovations such as electric cars, offshore wind, and battery storage.\n\n\"The approaches we are setting out today will benefit both the EU and UK and avoid a cliff-edge for businesses and individuals on both sides,\" Brexit secretary, David Davis, said in a statement.\n\n\"The way we approach the movement of goods across our border will be a critical building block for our independent trade policy. An interim period would mean businesses only need to adjust once to the new regime and would allow for a smooth and orderly transition.\"\n\nUnder a \"streamlined\" arrangement the UK and the EU would develop new technologies to speed the passage of goods and services through UK and EU ports. The briefing paper said the UK is already developing a new electronic Customs Declaration Service, set to be finished for January 2019, to enable more streamlined customs checks.\n\nBut the government still warns the new plan will result in \"an increase in administration\" compared with being inside the EU Customs Union.\n\nAlternatively, a new customs partnership would involve the UK \"acting in partnership with the EU\" to operate a regime for imports that \"aligns precisely\" with the EU's external customs border. This would apply to goods for consumption in the EU market, even if they are part of a UK supply chain first.\n\nThe proposed partnership would in effect create a two-tier system, where goods passing through UK supply chains for EU import or export face EU standard duties and checks, whereas UK exports and imports from other countries destined only for the UK would be subject to UK-only rules.\n\nHowever, such a system would require a \"robust enforcement mechanism\" to make sure UK-only goods do not find their way to Europe, the government acknowledged. Potential solutions could involve tracking mechanism to trace goods through the supply chain to an end user, or a refund system where traders could claim a rebate on higher tariffs once goods have reached their end user, the government suggests.\n\nGreen trade experts have warned exiting the Customs Union could allow the UK to sign new trade deals with other markets, but could also result in significant challenges for clean tech firms and green businesses. Specifically, experts have warned UK firms could find themselves having to adhere to EU environmental standards if they export to the bloc, while also facing competition from other markets where lower standards are accepted.\n\nThe EU has yet to declare whether either of the government's customs proposals are achievable from its perspective. However, the government warns that without a deal on customs arrangements it will be forced to implement a standalone system for customs, VAT and excise. \"This is not the government's preferred outcome to the negotiations, but it is essential that the UK is prepared for all possible outcomes on customs arrangements,\" the paper warns.\n\nThe proposals received a terse welcome from senior figures in Brussels. Writing on Twitter, chief negotiator Michel Barnier reiterated that the EU team was unwilling to discuss customs issues until the first stage of the talks are completed. \"The quicker #UK & EU27 agree on citizens, settling accounts and #Ireland, the quicker we can discuss customs & future relationship,\" he wrote.\n\nHis comments were echoed by the European Parliament's lead co-ordinator Guy Verhofstadt, who dismissed Davis' suggestion the UK could replicate the benefits of the customs union through a new agreement. \"To be in & out of the Customs Union & \"invisible borders\" is a fantasy,\" he wrote. \"First need to secure citizens rights & a financial settlement.\"", "id": "9311577", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Government promises to maintain 'high {"timeCrawl": "04:15:00", "uri": "710099663", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T04:15:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "Oman Observer", "uri": "omanobserver.om", "id": "6225"}, "url": "http://omanobserver.om/real-thing-fantasy-uk-proposes-new-eu-customs-deal/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON: Britain set out proposals on Tuesday for a future customs agreement for when it leaves the European Union, but one senior EU official described it as a \"fantasy\".\n\nAfter a slow start to negotiations to end more than 40 years of union, Prime Minister Theresa May's government is keen for the discussion to move beyond the EU's focus on a divorce agreement to consider how a new relationship could work.\n\nThe EU said it would \"carefully\" study the proposals, including measures for an interim customs agreement and two suggestions for a new trade partnership, but the terms of divorce remain to be settled first.\n\nBritain's Brexit Secretary, David Davis, said in a statement: \"The UK is the EU's biggest trading partner so it is in the interest of both sides that we reach an agreement on our future relationship. \"The UK starts from a strong position and we are confident we can deliver a result that is good for business here in the UK and across the EU.\" Britain lost a battle earlier this year to discuss the immediate divorce and future ties alongside each other.\n\nThe EU said the two sides must first make progress on the rights of expatriates, Britain's border with EU member Ireland and a financial settlement, the lack of progress on which Davis said had made the EU's chief negotiator \"quite cross\". May's government says the divorce settlement will be shaped by the future relationship.\n\nWhile welcoming the proposals, the European Commission, the EU's executive, again said it would not budge from its stance that progress on the divorce needed to be made first.\n\nGuy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's Brexit point-man, underlined the distance between the two sides.\n\n\"To be in and out of the customs union and 'invisible borders' is a fantasy,\" he said on Twitter. \"First need to secure citizens rights and a financial settlement\"\n\nIn what it described as the first of a series of \"future partnership papers\", Britain outlined two possible approaches to a new customs relationship with the EU after leaving the bloc and its customs union.\n\nIt described a \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\" that would borrow from existing systems while expanding the use of technology, or a new customs partnership that could mirror the EU's requirements for imports from the rest of the world.\n\nBritain also wants an interim customs agreement to allow the freest possible trade of goods by removing the threat of costly logjams at borders and to enable businesses to adapt to any future customs arrangement after leaving the bloc in March 2019. -- Reuters", "id": "9400516", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Real thing or 'fantasy' --  UK proposes new {"timeCrawl": "23:27:00", "uri": "709492060", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:27:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "POLITICO", "uri": "politico.eu", "id": "19273"}, "url": "http://www.politico.eu/article/uk-sets-out-brexit-customs-plan/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON -- The U.K. will propose a bespoke, temporary customs union with the EU during an \"interim period\" after Brexit, the British government said ahead of the publication of the first in a series of new papers outlining the U.K.'s negotiating position.\n\nUnder the proposals, Britain would leave the existing EU customs union, but would maintain a \"close association\" for a limited period in order to give both sides time to put in place new border checks and infrastructure. A new formal customs union with the EU is one of the options for the transition, the position paper, due to be published Tuesday, will say.\n\nAfter the interim period, Britain is seeking one of two new permanent customs arrangements with the EU. The first option would see it manage a new customs border with the EU, unilaterally simplifying requirements on EU goods entering the country as much as possible and providing border \"facilitations\" to reduce and remove trade barriers, according to a briefing issued by the U.K.'s Department for Exiting the European Union (DExEU).\n\nUnder the second option, the U.K. and the EU would negotiate a \"new customs partnership,\" aligning their approach to customs -- an option which, the Brexit department briefing said, would negate the need for a customs border. Under both options, the U.K. would be out of any customs union and able to strike its own free-trade deals.\n\nThe position paper is the first of up to 12 expected to be published before October, when the European Council will rule on whether talks on the withdrawal agreement have made sufficient progress to proceed to the next phase -- transition and the future relationship.\n\nHowever, the U.K. has grown increasingly impatient with the EU's sequencing of the Brexit talks, believing withdrawal issues are inextricably linked to the future relationship and transition.\n\nBy publishing its customs proposals now, ahead of a position paper on Northern Ireland later this week, the U.K. is hoping to highlight how the latter issue -- defined by the EU as a withdrawal matter -- cannot be settled without agreement on customs, a future relationship issue.\n\nDuring the customs transition period, if the U.K. were to enter into a customs union with the EU, it would have a common external tariff with the EU, one government official told POLITICO. This would mean the U.K. could not implement any trade deals with other countries until after the transition period.\n\nThe interim period will be time limited, but the precise length would be a matter for the U.K.'s negotiation with the European Commission, the official said.\n\nFurthermore, if the U.K. enters a transition-period customs union with the EU, it would be free to negotiate and even sign free-trade deals with other countries -- a key demand of International Trade Secretary Liam Fox -- but not to bring them into force, officials believe.\n\nIt is hoped that the interim period will reassure businesses already contemplating their future operations in the U.K. while giving them time to adjust to the new post-Brexit regime.\n\nJosh Hardie, deputy director general of the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), welcomed the government's progress in publishing position papers and the proposal of an interim period \"that is as barrier-free as possible.\"\n\n\"Business wants to see as frictionless a customs system as possible, with a strong emphasis on digital systems to make it easier to trade,\" he said.\n\n\"But to secure frictionless trade, negotiations on regulation, tariff and non-tariff barriers will have to take place. All efforts should be made to deliver a single-step transition so that businesses don't have to adapt twice.\"\n\nThe publication of the position paper follows two months of Cabinet disagreements over the course of the Brexit strategy. Chancellor Philip Hammond, seen as an advocate of a \"soft Brexit,\" and Fox, previously an ardent Leave campaigner, presented a united front in a joint article for the Sunday Telegraph asserting that the U.K. would leave the single market and the customs union ahead of a transition phase.\n\nMPs supporting a soft Brexit strategy were critical of the plans.\n\n\"These are incoherent and inadequate proposals designed to gloss over deep and continuing divisions within the cabinet,\" Labour's Shadow Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union Keir Starmer said in a statement. \"Businesses, trade unions and the country need certainty about our future trading and customs arrangements.\n\n\"Instead, the cabinet remain split on key issues and cannot decide between two very different but equally unachievable options. The first proposal suggests 'a new customs border with the EU' could be introduced without disrupting trade; the second suggests a new borderless customs partnership could somehow be agreed while Britain also signs external trade deals,\" the statement said.\n\nLabour MP Chris Leslie, a leading supporter of the Open Britain cross-party campaign group, said the Cabinet's \"new unified position is to return the government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it.\"\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union,\" he said.\n\n\"This is wishful thinking of the highest order. The only way to retain genuinely free trade with Europe, and protect the millions of jobs created by it, is to remain a member of the customs union.\"", "id": "9178527", "details": {"liCnt": 97}, "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/article36028788.ece/4d01e/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-b09ea563-73d0-41ea-82df-e2e2b88c3ef9_I1.jpg\n\nTheresa May is expected to arrive back in Downing Street on Thursday as ministers spend the week fleshing out details of their hopes for Britain's future with the EU after Brexit.\n\nThe Government will spell out its aims for new customs arrangements after the UK has quit the bloc in documents released by Brexit Secretary David Davis.\n\nA position paper on the fraught issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic is also due to be published later this week.\n\nIt comes as Mrs May i s expected to be back at her desk on Thursday after holidays in Europe totalling around three weeks.\n\nThe Prime Minister enjoyed a break in Italy lasting nearly a week at the end of July and is now away with husband Philip in Switzerland.\n\nThe Government has faced complaints from Brussels over a lack of clarity on the British negotiating position on Brexit.\n\nDowning Street said it was clear the talks had shown that the divorce could only be settled with in light of the future relationship with the EU.\n\nThe Prime Minister's official spokesman said: \"We had the first rounds of the negotiation and those talks have shown that many of the withdrawal questions can only be settled in light of the future partnership, so now is the time to set out our approach to that partnership to inform the upcoming negotiations and to provide citizens and businesses at home and across Europe with a deeper understanding of our thinking.\"\n\nEU chief negotiator Michel Barnier is reported to have warned his first two rounds of talks with Mr Davis, covering the opening issues of the Irish border, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, and Britain's \"divorce bill\", had made limited progress.\n\nMeanwhile, The Times said the slow progress so far had led to complaints in Whitehall that senior officials were now trying to rush through decisions in an attempt to break the policy logjam.\n\nThere were said to be concerns that Cabinet Secretary Sir Jeremy Heywood and the Permanent Secretary at the Department for Exiting the EU were railroading issues through at a time when many ministers were away, leading to poor decision-making.\n\nBut following a summer marked by speculation over a possible leadership challenge and jostling for position among senior ministers over Brexit, there was some respite for the Prime Minister with an apparent truce between two of the leading protagonists.\n\nChancellor Philip Hammond, who favours a \"soft\", pro-business Brexit, and the Brexiteer International Development Secretary Liam Fox signed up to a joint statement at the weekend agreeing that there would have to be a transition period after Britain has left the EU.\n\nThey agreed that while the measure was necessary to ensure there was no \"cliff-edge\" break for businesses, it would be time-limited and that Britain would leave the EU single market and the customs union when it left the bloc.\n\nSenior Conservative MP Bernard Jenkin welcomed unity in the Cabinet and questioned why the EU would not treat the UK the same as other countries who have no free trade deal with the bloc but have agreements over aviation services, customs facilitation and product recognition.\n\nMr Jenkin, chairman of the Public Administration and Constitutional Affairs Committee, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Why wouldn't they afford us the same kind of reasonable arrangements unless they want to punish us?\n\n\"And if they want to punish us, should we be intimidated by their determination to punish us?\n\n\"Are they such a dysfunctional and destructive {"timeCrawl": "00:50:00", "uri": "709515162", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:16:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "Here Is The City", "uri": "hitc.com", "id": "1475"}, "url": "http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2017/08/14/brexit-david-davis-to-set-out-hoped-for-eu-customs-deal/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "With Theresa May not expected to return to her desk in Downing Street from her holiday until Thursday, the government is keen to show that preparations for Brexit have not ground to a halt.\n\nThe EU has made clear it will not discuss Britain's future trading relationship - including customs arrangements - until it has reached agreement on several key issues, including the terms of the financial payments Britain will make on exit and the future status of the border in Northern Ireland.\n\nBut May's spokesman said the government has concluded from the early Brexit talks that it cannot make more progress without a clearer sense of what the future relationship might look like.\n\n\"We've had the first round of the negotiation, and those talks have shown that many of the withdrawal questions can only be settled in the light of our future partnership, so now is the time to set out our approach to that partnership, to inform the upcoming negotiations, and to provide citizens and businesses at home and across Europe with a deeper understanding of our thinking.\"\n\nPublishing the position paper is also aimed at sending a formal signal that at least one aspect of the bitter row within the cabinet about Britain's future relationship with the EU has been resolved.\n\nThe chancellor, Philip Hammond, regarded by Conservative backbenchers as the champion of a \"soft Brexit\", has signed up to a joint statement with Liam Fox, the international trade secretary, confirming that Britain would be \"outside the customs union\" during the post-Brexit transition phase and that at that point it would be \"a 'third country', not party to the EU treaties\".\n\nFox was concerned that he would be unable to strike trade deals with countries outside the EU unless it was made clear that Britain did not expect to remain part of the customs union, whose members cannot strike individual trade agreements, and are expected to apply EU tariffs on imports.\n\nMay's spokesman said: \"The prime minister set out in January in the Lancaster House speech the need for an implementation period, to avoid a cliff edge for business. The article by the chancellor and the international trade secretary made clear that that is the position of the government.\n\nHe added: \"The customs union as it currently stands has an impact on our ability to make trade deals.\"\n\nHammond appears to have conceded that remaining a member of the customs union is not possible, even as an interim arrangement while a detailed deal is finalised.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union is also expected to publish a separate paper on Northern Ireland later in the week, which will inform the next round of talks as the border with the Republic of Ireland is one of the issues the EU wants resolved early.\n\nAfter the last round of negotiations in Brussels last month, the EU's negotiator, Michel Barnier, expressed some frustration at the lack of detail from the British side - particularly on the financial settlement.\n\nHe said: \"As soon as the UK is ready to clarify the nature of its commitments, we will be prepared to discuss this with the British negotiators ... This week's experience has quite simply shown that we make better progress where our respective positions are clear.\"\n\nDavis initially insisted Britain would like to negotiate a new trade deal alongside the exit terms, describing discussions over the phasing of the talks as \"the row of the summer\" and warning that signing up to a financial settlement early could disadvantage Britain later in the talks.\n\nBut when formal negotiations got under way in June, after the general election wiped out May's comfortable governing majority, Britain quickly signed up to the EU's proposed The two sides will be looking for a solution to those issues at the next round of talks due at the end of this month.\n\nThe decision to announce the publication of papers on its plans indicates Britain's desire to counter criticism from Brussels about its approach to the talks, reported Reuters.\n\nA British paper focused on \"issues unique to Northern Ireland and Ireland\" is expected ahead of the talks, but no further details of the proposal were provided on Sunday.\n\nThe Sunday Telegraph reported that Britain was seeking a \"Schengen area\" between Britain and Ireland, which would {"timeCrawl": "12:02:00", "uri": "709743670", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:02:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "Sky News", "uri": "news.sky.com", "id": "1841"}, "url": "http://news.sky.com/story/govt-hopes-to-strike-new-trade-deals-during-transition-10989413", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Ministers hope they will be able to negotiate and complete trade deals with other countries during any Brexit transitional period.\n\nBut they accept they won't be able to implement them.\n\nSpeaking as the Brexit Secretary David Davis revealed future customs proposals with the EU, Government officials refused to be drawn on whether a third country trade deal could actually be signed.\n\nThis appeared to contradict an earlier promise made by Chancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, who wrote in the Sunday Telegraph that once EU membership ends in March 2019, the UK would be an \"independent nation with the freedom to sign bilateral free trade agreements\".\n\nMr Davis told Sky News a temporary customs arrangement with the EU will be \"in both sides' interests\" but any transition period should not exceed two years.\n\nHe said any interim customs union was there to avoid a \"cliff-edge\" for manufacturers after Brexit.\n\nMr Davis estimated the transition period would be roughly two years - with the deadline of the next General Election in 2022 as the \"absolute maximum\".\n\nThe document sets out two broad approaches to a possible customs deal.\n\nOne aims to continue some existing arrangements the UK has with the EU, using technology to make custom requirements \"as frictionless as possible\".\n\nThe second option is without precedent, which would involve the UK mirroring the EU's requirements for imports where the final destination is the EU.\n\nThe Government also says it has contingency plans in place to deal with the possibility of no agreement.\n\nBut there are increasing concerns that all the Government's possible options mean businesses will be hit with extra red tape and increased costs.\n\nFor example, proposals for goods that do not comply with the EU's trade policy would need a \"tracking mechanism\" where traders could claim \"refunds\" if tariff trades differ.\n\nThe British Irish Chamber of Commerce responded saying it was cautious about the feasibility of some proposals being put forward in London on simplifying new trade barriers with Europe.\n\nJohn McGrane, director of the association, said the ideas were a constructive contribution to the negotiations.\n\n\"The recognition of the need for an interim period to allow for the adoption of new systems and infrastructures will be welcomed by businesses who have long warned of the dangers of leaving the Customs Union without such a transition phase,\" he said.\n\n\"It is important that this phase is as close to the status quo as possible with minimum disruption caused by tariff and non-tariff barriers.\"\n\nA European Commission spokesman said the UK position paper on customs would be examined carefully.\n\n\"We take note of the UK's request for an implementing period and its preferences as regards the future relationship, but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal,\" the spokesman said.\n\n\"An agreement on a future relationship between the EU and the UK can only be finalised once the UK has become a third country.\n\n\"As (EU chief negotiator) Michel Barnier has said on several occasions, 'frictionless trade' is not possible outside the single market and customs union.\"\n\nGuy Verhofstadt, the European parliament's Brexit coordinator, tweeted: \"To be in and out of the Customs Union and 'invisible borders' is a fantasy.\n\n\"First need to secure citizens' rights & a financial settlement.\"\n\nLabour's shadow Brexit secretary, Sir Keir Starmer, branded the customs proposals \"incoherent and inadequate\" and \"designed to gloss over deep and continuing divisions within the Cabinet\".", "id": "9270603", {"timeCrawl": "04:23:00", "uri": "709568983", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T04:23:00Z", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "source": {"title": "The Star", "uri": "the-star.co.ke", "id": "1875"}, "url": "http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2017/08/15/brexit-uk-suggests-temporary-customs-union-with-eu_c1616780", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The UK has set out the \"ambitious new customs arrangement\" it wants to secure with the EU after Brexit.\n\nMinisters said the plans would mean the \"freest and most frictionless possible trade\" with the rest of Europe.\n\nThis could include a \"temporary customs union\" after Brexit to prevent border problems as the UK leaves the EU.\n\nBusinesses have called for clarity since the UK said it was leaving the customs union - the EU's tariff-free trading area - as part of Brexit.\n\nThe customs union document is the first of a series of papers to be published by the UK government on key negotiation issues.\n\nOn Wednesday it is expected to set out proposals for the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.\n\nCountries in the customs union don't impose tariffs - taxes on imports - on each other's goods.\n\nEvery country inside the union levies the same tariffs on imports from abroad.\n\nSo, for example, a 10% tariff is imposed on some cars imported from outside the customs union, while 7.5% is imposed on roasted coffee.\n\nOther goods - such as soap or slate - have no tariffs.\n\nThe UK's departure from the EU's customs union was confirmed at the weekend in a joint article by Chancellor Philip Hammond and Trade Secretary Liam Fox.\n\nAccording to the newly-published government paper, the UK could ask Brussels to establish a \"temporary customs union\" after it leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nBut during this period, it would also expect to be able to negotiate its own international trade deals - something it cannot do as an EU customs union member.\n\nOnce this period expires, the UK will look to agree either a \"highly streamlined\" border with the EU, or a new \"partnership\" with no customs border at all.\n\nThe government said the interim arrangements would mean businesses would only have to adjust once to the new arrangements.\n\nAll of this will have to be negotiated with the EU - and the two sides have not yet even started discussing trade matters.\n\nOther obstacles - including the size of the UK's \"divorce bill\" - need to be agreed first.\n\nKeir Starmer, Labour's shadow Brexit secretary, said the proposals were \"incoherent and inadequate\" and were designed to \"gloss over deep and continuing divisions within the cabinet\".\n\n\"These fantastical and contradictory proposals provide no guidance for negotiators or certainty for businesses,\" he added.", "id": "9206252", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Brexit: UK suggests 'temporary customs union' {"timeCrawl": "09:39:00", "uri": "709684355", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T09:39:00Z", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/business/uk-world/uk-still-haggling-with-eu-over-financial-terms-david-davis-says-36033332.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/business/uk-world/article36033331.ece/8c8e7/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-d1e0d6f9-3358-43e7-b4ca-0ac5fe4cb6eb_I1.jpg\n\nDavid Davis has refused to rule out making payments to Brussels for temporary customs arrangements after leaving the EU.\n\nThe Brexit Secretary will publish proposals on Tuesday morning, outlining plans for a time-limited transition which would ensure businesses on both sides of the Channel only have to adapt once to the rule changes.\n\nIn a series of broadcast interviews, Mr Davis failed to rule out whether the UK would have to pay for the temporary customs deal, which he said would last \"something like two years\".\n\nHe also suggested the t emporary arrangements could allow Britain to negotiate trade deals with other countries for when it leaves, as current rules bar members of the EU customs union from making their own deals outside the bloc.\n\nPressed on whether the UK would have to pay, he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme : \"I am not going to do the negotiation on air.\n\n\"What we are not going to do, let's be clear, we are not going to continue the \u00a310 billion a year net contributions we currently have.\"\n\nAsked if money could be a part of the negotiations, he said: \"I didn't say that. Wait and see.\"\n\nMr Davis also told ITV's Good Morning Britain: \"We sell them, the Europeans, about 230 billion euro of goods and services a year.\n\n\"They sell us 290 billion euro. So there are a lot of things there.\"\n\nAsked whether Britain would have to pay to stay in the customs union, he said: \"Well, I don't think ... well, what happens in that sort of interim period you will have to leave me to negotiate, I'm afraid, how we do it, but the aim is to bring to an end these huge \u00a310 billion-a-year payments, bring that to an end now.\n\n\"We are still haggling with them over what we may owe them in the short term but we are going to bring the overall thing to an end.\n\n\"This is something that is in both sides' interest.\"\n\nSecuring future trade deals outside the EU could also be on the cards under the new plans, Mr Davis said.\n\nHe told Today: \" There's a legal position here.\n\n\"The reason we can't sign now is because of something called the duty of sincere cooperation, it's written into the treaty, and it's not related to the customs union, it's related to the overall treaty.\n\n\"Once in 2019 when we leave, that legal duty goes away.\n\n\"Now we will still be responsible around it but our view is there is no legal basis for saying we can't do it, we are talking about it to other countries, we are just not signing.\"\n\nThe proposals for new customs arrangements to allow trade with the EU are being outlined in the first of a series of \"future partnership papers\" being released by the Government.\n\nOne option being put forward by Mr Davis for new arrangements would see the UK manage a new customs border with administration streamlined to the \"fullest extent possible\".\n\nThe Brexit Secretary will also float plans for a customs partnership with the EU which would negate the need for a customs border between the UK and the rest of the bloc.\n\nHe said the negotiations were going \"fine\" and EU leaders were less hostile than they had been previously.\n\nMr Davis told ITV: \"The simple truth is we want to come out of this better but they (the Europeans) want to come out of it better too.\n\n\"There was a terror early on that we would be the first of many countries breaking off.\n\n\"After the victory of (President Emmanuel) Macron in France, that terror is reduced.\n\n\"They are no longer quite so afraid so the punishment battalion side is now reducing.\"\n\nA European Commission spokesman said: \"We will now study the UK position paper on customs carefully in the light of the European Council guidelines and the council's negotiating directives.\n\n\"The next negotiation round will start in the week of 28 August.\n\n\"We take note of the UK's request for an implementing period and its preferences as regards the future relationship, but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal.\n\n\"An agreement on a future relationship between the EU and the UK can only be finalised once the UK has become a third country.\n\n\"As Michel Barnier has said on several occasions, 'frictionless trade' is not possible outside the Single Market and Customs Union.\"\n\nThe EU is also working on a position paper on the customs union, following a tranche of documents published before the summer on issues such as citizens' rights and nuclear {"timeCrawl": "01:50:00", "uri": "709530416", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T01:50:00Z", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "source": {"title": "The Straits Times", "uri": "straitstimes.com", "id": "611"}, "url": "http://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/britain-asks-for-interim-customs-deal-with-eu-new-trade-deals-post-brexit", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON (REUTERS) - Britain will propose setting up an interim customs agreement with the European Union after Brexit to allow the freest possible trade of goods.\n\nBut it will also seek the right to negotiate other trade deals, a possible sticking point in the talks.\n\nAccording to excerpts of a government document to be published on Tuesday (Aug 15) setting out Britain's strategy, the government will say one option to minimise friction when it leaves the bloc in March 2019 would be to introduce a temporary customs union which should be \"time-limited\".\n\nThat would provide certainty for businesses, the government said, aiming to address a main concern of companies who fear the introduction of customs checks will cause expensive delays.\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\n\"Ministers will announce an intention to seek an 'interim'period with the EU of close association with the customs union that would allow for a smooth and orderly transfer to the new regime,\" the government said in a statement ahead of publication of the first in a series of \"future partnership papers\".\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU ... During this interim period, which will be negotiated with Brussels, Britain will look to negotiate bold new trade relationships around the world.\"\n\nBusinesses welcomed the proposals, but the Confederation of British Industry also warned the government that \"the clock is ticking and what matters now if giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible\".\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May and her government are keen to move the talks with the EU forward to tackle the future relationship rather than focusing only on their divorce, and have promised to publish a series of policy documents this week.\n\nBut after being criticised by some EU officials for being ill-prepared for the first rounds of negotiations, the government's demand to secure trade deals while participating in a temporary customs union may cause further problems.\n\n\"It looks like the new unified position in the cabinet is to return the government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it,\" said Chris Leslie, a pro-EU campaigner and member of Britain's opposition Labour Party.\n\nCountries that are part of the EU's customs union are not allowed to negotiate bilateral trade deals and May's government has said Brexit means Britain must leave the customs union.\n\nBut Turkey, while not an EU member, is part of a separate customs union for industrial goods and can still negotiate bilateral trade deals. It was not clear whether Britain was pursuing a similar arrangement to Turkey.\n\nThe government said that by sorting out the customs arrangements, Britain and the bloc could avoid a \"hard border\"with EU member state Ireland, something which officials fear could reignite tensions between Irish nationalists and unionists.\n\nIt proposed two different ways - a highly streamlined customs arrangement managed by Britain, or a new customs partnership with the EU, which could \"negate the need for a customs border\".\n\nIts proposals on a future customs arrangement are set out in one of several position papers intended to flesh out the government's Brexit vision and show a united stance over the future relationship after rifts emerged among ministers.\n\nOn Wednesday, the government {"timeCrawl": "12:20:00", "uri": "709754356", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:20:00Z", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "source": {"title": "Traveller", "uri": "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "London - Britain says it might seek to remain in a customs union with the European Union for a time to avoid border chaos after leaving the bloc.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union said Tuesday that there could be \"a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU.\"\n\nAnd it said a future \"customs partnership\" could eliminate the need for a customs border between Britain and the EU.\n\nThe question of whether there will be economic barriers with the EU after Brexit in March 2019 has been the subject of mixed signals from UK government ministers.\n\nThe lack of clarity has created uncertainty for British businesses.\n\nThe government is trying to rebuff claims before a new round of talks later this month "title": "'Temporary customs union' with EU could avoid border chaos for UK", "image": "http://cdn.24.co.za/files/Cms/General/d/2517/e18a6705bbaa45a5bab72a6d52a41571.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 484, "date": "2019-03-", "amb": false, "textEnd": 494}], "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "concepts": [{"location": {"label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}, "type": "country"}, "score": 4, "id": {"label": {"eng": "Border"}, "id": "308560", "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Border"}, {"label": {"eng": "Eurasian Customs Union"}, "id": "340949", "score": 4, "type": {"timeCrawl": "19:02:00", "uri": "709930386", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T19:02:00Z", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "source": {"title": "RTE.ie", "uri": "rte.ie", "id": "1151"}, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/analysis-and-comment/2017/0815/897672-brexit-customs/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "As of now (15 August), there are 591 days to go before the UK leaves the EU.\n\nThis is important in understanding one of the key factors behind the publication of the British government's position paper on \"Future Customs Arrangements\".\n\nAnd that factor is time.\n\nOnce British Prime Minister Theresa May started the Article 50 process back in March, time became the chief enemy of the British state. About the only thing anyone is clear about as things stand, is that the UK will leave the EU on 29 March 2019. Before that happens, a separation agreement has to be reached.\n\nThe EU chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, wants to try and get all the negotiations on this agreement wrapped up by October 2018, which would allow roughly six months for ratifications.\n\nThis means there are now about 13 and a half months left to negotiate a separation agreement.\n\nWhich is tricky for anyone trying to run a business. Especially a regulated entity, such as a bank or insurance company.\n\nThe Bank of England Governor, Mark Carney said a couple of weeks ago that regulated entities needed 18 months to make their Brexit related decisions about relocating some or all or their business.\n\nAnd eighteen months is longer than the time left to negotiate a Brexit separation agreement.\n\nSo time is the enemy. Its inexorable march also has implications for the British customs regime.\n\nIt is all well and good to talk about no deal being better than a bad deal, or to state, as today's document does, that the UK will leave the EU Customs Union in 2019. But the practical implication of that is that the UK must have a new customs regime - and the systems to back it up - in place for 29 March 2019. 591 days time.\n\nThat is 591 days to design a new customs regime, secure international (not just EU) agreement on it, hire the staff needed, select - and in some cases invent - the technology necessary to implement the design, procure the technology, commission the technology, build the physical infrastructure (including truck parks at ports and border crossings), and legislate the new regime into existence.\n\n591 days and counting down.\n\nJust legislating for a new customs regime will be tricky.\n\nToday's position paper tells us the British government will bring forward a customs bill in the autumn. This will be accompanied by a white paper, which should give us a lot more detail on what they are planning.\n\nThe customs law (needed because customs is almost exclusively an EU competence, and the UK does not have a sufficient legal base for a standalone customs regime), will have to be supported by changes to UK legislation on VAT and excise regimes.\n\nThat is a hefty chunk of parliamentary time in the best of circumstances, without a clock ticking loudly in the background, forcing the pace (and rushed law is usually bad law, according to most seasoned parliamentarians).\n\nBut the fall back position is needed as part of the threats the UK is using in this Brexit negotiation.\n\nHere is what today's paper says about the new powers the Customs Bill will give the British government to make its own rules and apply them to the rest of us:\n\n\"In this scenario, without any further facilitations or agreements, the UK would treat trade with the EU as it currently treats trade with non-EU countries. Customs duty and import VAT would be due on EU imports. Traders would need to be registered.\n\n\"Traders exporting to the EU would have to submit an export declaration, and certain goods may require an export licence. The EU would also apply the customs rules and VAT to imports from the UK that it applies to non-EU countries. The Government is actively considering ways in which to mitigate the impacts of such a scenario. Other EU Member States will also need to make contingency preparations to mitigate the risk of delays resulting from their own customs processes.\"\n\nIn other words, you Irish/French/Belgians/Dutch better get on with making your own preparations for a hard border, or face the consequences from your own disgruntled business community. And that is going to cost money.\n\nIt is going to cost us money. Even though we do not want it, and did not vote for it. But they insist we pay for it.\n\nOnce again, the nastiness surfaces ...\n\nTo avoid such unpleasantness, the British are suggesting two different routes to a new customs arrangement with the EU.\n\nOne relies on a \"streamlined\" version of a hard customs border, using lots of technology. It admits this is untried and untested (and in some cases non-existent). If it all worked, it would ease the queues at border crossings considerably, and there is much to be said for using as much IT as possible in the whole customs/excise/VAT trade flow as possible anyway.\n\nBut the paper clearly states \"there will remain an increase in administration compared with being inside the EU Customs Union\".\n\nYou can \"streamline\" all you like, the fact is Brexit will double the amount of red tape and bureaucracy involved in trading with the UK.\n\nThe other route today's paper proposes is a \"new customs partnership\" with the EU, which would \"align\" the two customs regimes so closely that there is no need for an actual customs border between the UK and the EU.\n\nThis is particularly good for getting around the problem of the Northern Ireland border. The only snag is, it won't work.\n\nNot in the form the UK is suggesting, which is that the UK would \"mirror\" EU customs law for goods that would come into the UK and then go on to the EU.\n\nBut a different regime would apply to goods destined only for the UK market.\n\nThis is tricky enough to implement among honest and noble businesses and traders, but the flip side of the customs coin is smugglers. Criminals infest all border regimes, because there is money to be made.\n\nThis UK proposal would open a gigantic hole in the EU customs defences, creating a massive incentive for customs, excise and VAT criminals to exploit the differences between the EU and UK regimes. It is very rare for governments to propose facilitating revenue loss on such a grand scale.\n\nThe British paper admits this approach is \"unprecedented\" and would be \"challenging\" to implement. Indeed.\n\nHere is what the paper says about trying to manage such a system in practice:\n\n\"There would need to be a robust enforcement mechanism that ensured goods which had not complied with the EU's trade policy stayed in the UK. This could involve, for instance, a tracking mechanism, where imports to the UK were tracked until they reached an end user, or a repayment mechanism, where imports to the UK paid whichever was the higher of the UK's or the EU's tariff rates and traders claimed a refund for the difference between the two rates when the goods were sold to an end user in the country charging lower tariffs.\n\n\"Businesses in supply chains would need to be able to track goods or pass the ability to claim a repayment along their supply chain in order to benefit\".\n\nIs frictionless the first word that springs to mind reading that? How about gangsters paradise? I know its two words, but get used to it - everything is being doubled up by Brexit.\n\nOne piece of good news for Irish exporters in the paper is an indication that Britain will look to membership of the Common Transit Convention, which would mean goods would not have to complete a new customs declaration every time they cross a new border (for example, Holyhead and Dover).\n\nThe British will also publish a Trade Bill in the autumn, and it too will be accompanies by a White Paper. This will also eat into Parliamentary time.\n\nAnd that time is further eroded by the Repeal Bill, the legal action needed to ensure legal continuity after the UK leaves the EU by transforming all EU law into UK law (it is similar to the Minsters and Secretaries Act, the first law introduced by the Oireachtas after independence).\n\nAll this in 591 days, and counting down ...\n\nThe time pressure means the case for a transitional agreement is overwhelming.\n\nBut the hard Brexiters appear to want out at all costs.\n\nLiam Fox, the Trade Secretary, wants above all else to sign new trade deals, but cannot do so until the UK leaves the EU.\n\nPhilip Hammond, Chancellor of the Exchequer wants a \"soft Brexit\" because he is worried about the very damaging effects on the British economy a hard will have.\n\nThe political battle between these two cabinet ministers reflects a split in the UK establishment over which direction policy should take.\n\nAnd Mrs May has been so weakened by a dreadful election result that she lacks the authority to impose direction on her ministers.\n\nIt is telling that on the day the Department for Exiting the EU publishes its first position paper, former Ukip leader Nigel Farage was making himself available to every live television broadcast in Britain (after a quiet period of several months), and the Leave EU campaign funder Aaron Banks started a new campaign to have Mr Hammond removed as an MP (not just a minister), working in Mr Hammond's own constituency.\n\nThe nasty is not just for foreigners ...\n\nThe split in the cabinet is reflected in a policy paper that is trying to promote two different directions of travel. However, it may also offer a way out of sorts.\n\nToday's document is a discussion paper, designed for consultation with business and industrial groups (including foreigners, who have not been shy about making proposals to Department for Exiting the EU in the past few months).\n\nThat consultation process may be the reality check the British government needs to settle this cabinet dispute.\n\nIt may well be British business that gets to decide if ideology of pragmatism gains the upper hand in guiding UK policy as it leaves the EU.\n\nWhich is in 591 days.", "id": "9341143", Supposedly he was looking for a compromise to keep Britain within the customs union and single market as long as possible,\" he said.\n\n\"The rebellion didn't last very long. He has now teamed up with one of the more extreme and ideological supporters of a 'hard Brexit'. It is now painfully clear who calls the shots in the Cabinet; it isn't the Chancellor.\"\n\nIn contrast, the joint move was welcomed by the pro-Brexit Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson who said it was the \"right way forward\".\n\n\"Create certainty and great new European relationship. Get job done + on with Global Britain,\" he wrote on Twitter.\n\nSee Fox/Hammond in Telegraph. Right way forward. Create certainty and great new European relationship. {"timeCrawl": "13:37:00", "uri": "709789744", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:37:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "just-food.com", "uri": "just-food.com", "id": "7020"}, "url": "https://www.just-food.com/news/uk-publishes-post-brexit-customs-proposals_id137478.aspx", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The UK today (15 August) set out its ideas for the post-Brexit customs arrangements between the country and the EU, with London asserting the proposals would \"avoid a cliff-edge\" for businesses in both markets.\n\nThe UK government has said the country would not remain in the EU customs union when it leaves the bloc. Business had been calling for clarity on what type of system the UK wanted to replace the existing arrangements.\n\nThis afternoon, London put forward two models of how post-Brexit customs could look. One is what the UK calls \"a highly streamlined customs arrangement\", which would continue some of the structures currently in place, see the implementation of unilateral processes that would be negotiated and use \"technology-based solutions to make it easier to comply with customs procedures\".\n\nThe second approach put forward by the UK, which London admitted is \"innovative and untested\", would see the country \"align our approach to the customs border in a way that removes the need for a UK-EU customs border\". Under this proposal, London suggested one method could \"involve the UK mirroring the EU's requirements for imports from the rest of the world where their final destination is the EU\".\n\nUnder the UK's proposals, while both sides implement the new customs arrangements, both markets should introduce \"a model of close association\n\nwith the EU Customs Union for a time-limited interim period\".\n\nHowever, during this interim arrangement, the UK would still look to negotiate its own trade deals - which it cannot do as a full member of the EU customs union.\n\nDavid Davis, the UK's Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union, said: \"The approaches we are setting out today will benefit both the EU and UK and avoid a cliff-edge for businesses and individuals on both sides. The way we approach the movement of goods across our border will be a critical building block for our independent trade policy. An interim period would mean businesses only need to adjust once to the new regime and would allow for a smooth and orderly transition.\"\n\nHowever, Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's Brexit coordinator, described the UK's proposals as a \"fantasy\".\n\nTo be in & out of the Customs Union & \"invisible borders\" is a fantasy. First need to secure citizens rights & a financial settlement -- Guy Verhofstadt (@GuyVerhofstadt)\n\nAugust 15, 2017\n\nIan Wright, the director general of UK industry body the Food and Drink Federation, said the \"single point of change\" between pre- and post-Brexit arrangements would \"help to minimise unnecessary disruption for businesses that have established trading relationships with the EU\".\n\nHowever, he added: \"The real challenge will then follow in designing and negotiating a model that maintains these benefits beyond the transition period, delivering the same ease of trading that UK food and drink currently enjoys with the EU27, with zero tariffs and no new regulatory or other non-tariff barriers.\n\n\"As the UK's largest manufacturing sector, our success is inextricably linked to our ability to import and export raw ingredients and finished goods across borders. Nowhere is this more the case than with our Irish neighbours. We will be looking carefully at the detail of the paper and will continue working closely with Government to ensure the future customs model works for UK food and drink manufacturers, allowing them to maintain the quality, choice and value that consumers demand.\"", "id": "9287662", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "UK publishes post-Brexit customs proposals", "image": Businesses welcomed the news, but Europe is growing impatient with Britain's slow progress.\n\nAccording to a partial government document set to be published on Tuesday, the UK is hoping to minimize the strain on business and consumers when it leaves the EU in March 2019, and wants to secure the freest possible trade deal.\n\nThe idea is to create a \"time-limited\" customs union while all the other necessary changes fall into place, in order to provide certainly for companies and investors.\n\n\"Ministers will announce an intention to seek an 'interim' period with the EU of close association with the customs union that would allow for a smooth and orderly transfer to the new regime,\" said a government statement ahead of the publication of its proposals.\n\nWhile British businesses welcome the proposal, the EU warned that it would only negotiate trade deals after sufficient progress had been made on the UK's withdrawal from the bloc.\n\nThe Confederation of British Industry also said that \"the clock is ticking\" and that it was counting on the government to give \"companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible.\"\n\nBrexit minister: The EU is 'quite cross'\n\nBrexit Minister David Davis told LBC Radio that a \"long haggle\" lay in store for Britain. {"timeCrawl": "15:47:00", "uri": "709846846", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:47:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "english.sina.com", "uri": "english.sina.com", "id": "2369"}, "url": "http://english.sina.com/news/2017-08-15/detail-ifyixcaw5068081.shtml", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON, Aug. 15 (Xinhua) -- Opposition politicians in Britain on Tuesday criticised government proposals for an interim trading deal with the European Union (EU), but business leaders welcomed the proposals, saying that if accepted by Brussels, it would avoid a \"cliff edge\" in March 2019 when Britain leaves the EU.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis wants a tariff-free interim customs arrangement to start when Britain ends its EU membership.\n\nIt would mean current exporting and importing arrangements would continue virtually unchanged to enable a permanent deal to eventually be agreed by both sides.\n\nThe new paper was released as the first in a series of documents to be published in order to outline Britain's position on major issues of Brexit.\n\nLabour's Keir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, described Davis's proposals as \"incoherent and inadequate,\" saying they were designed to gloss over deep and continuing divisions within British Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet.\n\n\"Businesses, trade unions and the country need certainty about our future trading and customs arrangements,\" Starmer said. \"Instead, the cabinet remain split on key issues and cannot decide between two very different but equally unachievable options.\"\n\nThe first proposal which suggests \"a new customs border with the EU\" could be introduced without disrupting trade; the second suggests a new borderless customs partnership could somehow be agreed while Britain also signs external trade deals.\n\n\"These fantastical and contradictory proposals provide no guidance for negotiators or certainty for businesses,\" he said. \"The proposals also make it less likely that necessary transitional arrangements will be in place by March 2019.\"\n\nFor his part, Nicola Sturgeon, first minister of the Scottish Parliament and leader of the Scottish Nationalist Party, said, \"It seems the UK government is back to its daft 'have your cake and eat it' approach to Brexit.\n\nSturgeon added that the British government should commit to staying in the EU single market and the customs union.\n\nOne of the strongest attacks came from Nigel Farage, founder and former leader of UKIP, the party set up to campaign for Britain to leave the EU.\n\nFarage, who sits as a British member in the European Parliament said: \"We might find ourselves 10 years down the road from Brexit having not got what we wanted.\"\n\n\"There's no doubt that during this transitional period, the free movement of people will continue, the European Court of Justice will go on having judgements over British business and, of course, we'll go on paying a membership fee,\" Farage said. \"None of those things are acceptable to Brexit voters in any way at all.\"\n\nTom Blake, Brexit spokesman for the minority Liberal Democrat party. said the government's customs union proposal would delay the economic pain caused by leaving the customs union.\n\nBlake said: \"We still face the prospect of more red tape for businesses, longer queues at our borders and higher prices for consumers once the transition comes to an end.\"\n\nBusiness leaders in Britain, however, broadly welcomed the official proposals, saying it will avoid a feared \"cliff edge\" if no post-2019 export and import arrangements are in place.\n\nJosh Hardie, deputy director-general of the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), said: \"Companies will welcome the progress the government has made today in publishing these papers.\"\n\n\"It's encouraging to see that these papers propose a time-limited interim period and a customs system that is as barrier-free as possible,\" he said.\n\nHardie said business wants to see as frictionless a customs system as possible, with a strong emphasis on digital systems that make it easier to trade.\n\nNew round of talks between the British government and EU negotiators are due to resume at the end of this month.\n\nVideo: Abe's misadventure in constitution {"timeCrawl": "15:55:00", "uri": "709850523", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T06:36:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "Verdict", "uri": "verdict.co.uk", "id": "19067"}, "url": "https://www.verdict.co.uk/cost-leaving-eu-wont-find-till-october/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Will it be \u00a350bn? Will it be \u00a336bn? In fact, no one has any idea how much it is going to cost to leave the European Union (EU) and we won't find out until October.\n\nThe UK's Brexit secretary David Davis has said that the EU and the UK will not have an agreed figure for the so-called Brexit divorce bill for at least two more months.\n\nHe told BBC Radio 4's Today programme:\n\nWe're going to talk it through very, very carefully, so at this stage we're not going to commit, there won't be a number by October or November, whenever it is.\n\nThe discussions over the exit bill are holding up talks between the two parties, as the EU wants an agreement on the final figure before they can carry on with talks about Britain's relationship with the union.\n\nRead more: Brexit leaders: who is the man in charge of Brexit, David Davis?\n\nIf a figure for the bill is agreed upon by October, that only leaves 18 months for the EU and the UK to thrash out the rest of the negotiations before the UK officially leaves the EU in March 2019, two years after UK prime minister Theresa May triggered Article 50.\n\nHowever, Davis doesn't seem sure that the UK will be out of the union by this date. He seems to think a Brexit transition could extend until the next parliamentary election, due by May 2022.\n\nDavis said:\n\n\"It's got to be done by the election. I would say the most likely is something like two years, maybe a bit shorter.\"\n\nThe UK government is set to publish several position papers today to establish its ambitions for future relations with the bloc.\n\nToday's paper will focus on the customs arrangement between the two parties.
