{"timeCrawl": "17:51:00", "uri": "709902714", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:54:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "BBC", "uri": "bbc.com", "id": "489"}, "url": "http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-40938826", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The Department for Exiting the European Union has released what it calls a future partnership paper, laying out the government's plans for the UK's relationship with the EU after it leaves.\n\nThe Reality Check team looks at some of the key parts of the document.\n\n\"The government believes that there are two broad approaches the UK could adopt.\"\n\nThe key part of the government's paper is the choice of two different destinations as it tries to negotiate a long-term solution.\n\nThe first is \"a highly streamlined customs arrangement\", in which the UK leaves the customs union, but comes up with ways of simplifying the future customs regime between the UK and EU countries.\n\nThat could include developing technology and negotiating other systems to speed things up at ports. But implementing such a complex scheme would take years of preparation.\n\nThe other option proposed is a new customs partnership with the EU, which would do away with a customs border altogether.\n\nAgreeing to such a partnership, which doesn't really exist anywhere in the world, would be quite a concession for the EU as it would give the UK the benefits of being in the customs union while still allowing it to forge trade agreements with non-EU countries, which EU members are not allowed to do.\n\n\"People and businesses in both the UK and the EU would benefit from an interim period.\"\n\nThe government wants an interim or transition period between the UK leaving the EU and the new permanent customs regime coming into effect.\n\nThe paper suggests a time-limited period during which the UK leaves the customs union only to move straight into another temporary customs union with the EU that would operate in pretty much the same way - except, the UK wants to be able to negotiate and sign (but not implement) free trade deals with other countries outside the EU at the same time.\n\n\"The UK would aim to negotiate trade facilitations with the EU and implement unilateral improvements to our domestic regime.\"\n\n\"The promotion of the free flow of trade in both directions between the UK and the EU would also require the EU to implement equivalent arrangements at its borders with the UK.\"\n\nIt is not clear which aspects of the streamlined arrangement would be unilateral and which would need agreement.\n\nThe paper says, in paragraph 29, that the government would make unilateral improvements to its systems, to speed things up at ports.\n\nBut then, in paragraph 30, it says that the EU would have to implement equivalent arrangements.\n\n\"Through membership of the Common Transit Convention (CTC), which simplifies border crossing for goods in transit.\"\n\nThe CTC is the set of rules for moving goods between EU member states and other countries, including Iceland, Norway, Switzerland, Macedonia and Serbia.\n\nIt is supposed to make it easier to move products from one country to another via a third country that is not necessarily an EU member.\n\nFor the UK, the benefit would be that goods could be imported from Asia via the port of Rotterdam, for example, without having to pay EU duties.\n\n\"Negotiating mutual recognition of Authorised Economic Operators (AEOs), enabling faster clearance of AEOs' goods at the border.\"\n\nAEOs are an international kitemark that recognises businesses as regular international traders that are solvent and have a good record of paying customs fees and taxes and keeping proper records.\n\nCompanies holding the designation are allowed to use certain fast-track systems when going through customs.\n\nThe government estimates that 60% of UK imports and 74% of UK exports involve companies with AEO status.\n\n\"Ensure that individuals travelling to the UK from the EU and vice versa can continue to travel with goods for personal use as freely and as smoothly as they do now.\"\n\nThe amount of alcohol and cigarettes that can be brought into the UK from non-EU countries without paying duty is limited - up to four litres of wine and 200 cigarettes.\n\nAfter Brexit, such limits could return for trips to and from the EU.\n\nBut the government is keen to strike an agreement that ensures that does not happen.\n\n\"We acknowledge this is an innovative and untested approach that would take time to develop and implement.\"\n\nThe government says it wants to look into the \"practical complexities\" involved in a customs partnership, but the EU has already repeated its argument that frictionless trade outside the Customs Union and the Single Market is impossible.\n\nWould ministers be happier being \"innovative and untested\" than being courageous?\n\n\"We will continue to discuss these proposals with stakeholders over the summer and will publish a Customs White Paper in advance of the Customs Bill in the autumn.\"\n\nIf negotiations on the future partnership with the EU have not yet begun by the autumn, there may be a few blank spaces in the Customs White Paper that will have to be filled in later.\n\nAnd this week's paper also emphasises that the government will be ready for a \"no deal\" scenario that would necessitate \"standalone customs and excise systems\".\n\n\"This is not the government's preferred outcome,\" the paper says, \"but it is essential that the UK is prepared for all possible outcomes.\"", "id": "9331460", "body": "The Department for Exiting the EU said it will seek to agree a \"time-limited period of implementation\" to provide certainty for businesses and allow for new customs arrangements to be set warned it will be extremely difficult to negotiate a new EU-UK free trade agreement before Britain leaves the bloc -- particularly as Brussels has so far refused even to start trade talks.\n\nIt says there must be broad agreement first on three key issues -- Britain's financial settlement, the issue of expatriate rights, and the question of the border between British-controlled Northern Ireland and Ireland.\n\nBritain will publish its proposals on the border issue on Wednesday, ahead of the third round of Brexit negotiations in Brussels at the end of the month.\n\nOfficials in London believe the border is inextricably linked to the customs issue.\n\nAfter Brexit, the Irish border will be Britain's only land border with the EU.\n\nThere are fears that the reintroduction of physical checkpoints could upset the fragile balance of peace in Northern Ireland.\n\nBritain's membership of the EU customs union precludes it from striking its own trade deals, and the government made clear {"timeCrawl": "16:25:00", "uri": "708838928", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T16:25:00Z", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/philip-hammond-accused-of-surrender-to-hard-line-brexiteers-over-single-market-36026946.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/article36026941.ece/4dd24/AUTOCROP/h342/bpanews_c4ce256d-3989-4b4f-a5c6-60a56b601e3d_1\n\nChancellor Philip Hammond has been accused of caving in to hard line Cabinet Brexiteers after accepting Britain will withdraw from the European single market and the customs union when it leaves the EU in 20 months' time.\n\nAfter a summer of ministerial feuding, Mr Hammond, who favours a \"softer\" pro-business Brexit, came together with International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, from the Brexiteer wing of the party, to declare there could be no \"back door\" attempt to keep Britain in the EU.\n\nIn a joint article for the Sunday Telegraph, they agreed that while a period of transition would be needed after 2019 to prevent a damaging \"cliff-edge\" break with the EU, it would be \"time limited\" and would mean pulling out of both the single market and the customs union.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May will hope the intervention of the two ministers will cool temperatures in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit and speculation of a possible leadership challenge when MPs return to Westminster in September.\n\nHowever, Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable said it was clear that Mr Hammond had lost his power struggle with the Brexiteers.\n\n\"Over the summer, we heard that Philip Hammond was courageously fighting off the more extreme Brexiteers. Supposedly he was looking for a compromise to keep Britain within the customs union and single market as long as possible,\" he said.\n\nRelated content\n\n\"The rebellion didn't last very long. He has now teamed up with one of the more extreme and ideological supporters of a 'hard Brexit'. It is now painfully clear who calls the shots in the Cabinet; it isn't the Chancellor.\"\n\nIn contrast, the joint move was welcomed by the pro-Brexit Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson who said it was the \"right way forward\".\n\n\"Create certainty and great new European relationship. Get job done + on with Global Britain,\" he wrote on Twitter.\n\nSee Fox/Hammond in Telegraph. Right way forward. Create certainty and great new European relationship. Get job done + on with Global Britain -- Boris Johnson (@BorisJohnson)\n\nAugust 13, 2017\n\nIn their article, Mr Hammond and Dr Fox said a transition period was needed to give businesses confidence they would be able to carry on trading normally.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU,\" they wrote.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the customs union and will be a 'third country', not a party to EU treaties.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the leading Conservative remainer Anna Soubry indicated she could be prepared to join with politicians from other parties to stop the country \"staggering recklessly\" towards a hard break with Brussels.\n\nHammond/Fox letter @dailytelegraph shows the need to form #Brexit consensus which Hammond is leading -- Anna Soubry MP (@Anna_Soubry)\n\nAugust 13, 2017\n\n\"Could I ever see myself joining with like-minded people who want to save our country from such an appalling fate? {"timeCrawl": "16:17:00", "uri": "709861479", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:17:00Z", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "source": {"title": "headlinesnews.net", "uri": "headlinesnews.net", "id": "1397"}, "url": "http://headlinesnews.net/reality-check-19/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The Department for Exiting the European Union has released what it calls a future partnership paper, laying out the government's plans for the UK's relationship with the EU after it leaves.\n\nThe Reality Check team looks at some of the key parts of .\n\nTwo options\n\nThe key part of the government's paper is the choice of two different destinations as it tries to negotiate a long-term solution.\n\nThe first is \"a highly streamlined customs arrangement\", in which the UK leaves the customs union, but comes up with ways of simplifying the future customs regime between the UK and EU countries.\n\nThat could include developing technology and negotiating other systems to speed things up at ports. But implementing such a complex scheme would take years of preparation.\n\nThe other option proposed is a new customs partnership with the EU, which would do away with a customs border altogether.\n\nAgreeing to such a partnership, which doesn't really exist anywhere in the world, would be quite a concession for the EU as it would give the UK the benefits of being in the customs union while still allowing it to forge trade agreements with non-EU countries, which EU members are not allowed to do.\n\nInterim period\n\nThe government wants an interim or transition period between the UK leaving the EU and the new permanent customs regime coming into effect.\n\nThe paper suggests a time-limited period during which the UK leaves the customs union only to move straight into another temporary customs union with the EU that would operate in pretty much the same way - except, the UK wants to be able to negotiate and sign (but not implement) free trade deals with other countries outside the EU at the same time.\n\nUnilateral but also equivalent\n\nIt is not clear which aspects of the streamlined arrangement would be unilateral and which would need agreement.\n\nThe paper says, in paragraph 29, that the government would make unilateral improvements to its systems, to speed things up at ports.\n\nBut then, in paragraph 30, it says that the EU would have to implement equivalent arrangements.\n\nCommon Transit Convention\n\nThe CTC is the set of rules for moving goods between EU member states and other countries, including Iceland, Norway, Switzerland, Macedonia and Serbia.\n\nIt is supposed to make it easier to move products from one country to another via a third country that is not necessarily an EU member.\n\nFor the UK, the benefit would be that goods could be imported from Asia via the port of Rotterdam, for example, without having to pay EU duties.\n\nAuthorised Economic Operators\n\nAEOs are an international kitemark that recognises businesses as regular international traders that are solvent and have a good record of paying customs fees and taxes and keeping proper records.\n\nCompanies holding the designation are allowed to use certain fast-track systems when going through customs.\n\nThe government estimates that 60% of UK imports and 74% of UK exports involve companies with AEO status.\n\nThe booze cruise survives?\n\nThe amount of alcohol and cigarettes that can be brought into the UK from non-EU countries without paying duty is limited - up to four litres of wine and 200 cigarettes.\n\nAfter Brexit, such limits could return for trips to and from the EU.\n\nBut the government is keen to strike an agreement that ensures that does not happen.\n\nInnovative and untested\n\nThe government says it wants to look into the \"practical complexities\" involved in a customs partnership, but the EU has already repeated its argument that frictionless trade outside the Customs Union and the Single Market is impossible.\n\nWould ministers be happier being \"innovative and untested\" than being ?\n\nCustoms White Paper\n\nIf negotiations on the future partnership with the EU have not yet begun by the autumn, there may be a few blank spaces in the Customs White Paper that will have to be filled in later.\n\nAnd this week's paper also emphasises that the government will be ready for a \"no deal\" scenario that would necessitate \"standalone customs and excise systems\".\n\n\"This is not the government's preferred outcome,\" the paper says, \"but it is essential that the UK is prepared for all possible outcomes.\"", "id": "9315612", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Reality check", "image": "http://headlinesnews.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/_97342500_mediaitem97342497.jpg", {"timeCrawl": "11:56:00", "uri": "709201510", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:50:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/aug/14/brexit-david-davis-to-set-out-hoped-for-eu-customs-deal", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "David Davis, the Brexit secretary, is expected to set out more clearly the government's hopes for a future customs deal with the European Union this week, to help inform the next round of Brexit negotiations.\n\nWith the prime minister not expected to return to her desk in Downing Street from her holiday until Thursday, the government is keen to show that preparations for Brexit have not ground to a halt.\n\nThe EU has made clear that it will not discuss Britain's future trading relationship - including customs arrangements - until it has reached agreement on several key issues, including the terms of the financial payments Britain will make on exit, and the future status of the border in Northern Ireland.\n\nBut May's spokesman said the government has concluded from the early Brexit talks that it cannot make more progress without a clearer sense of what the future relationship might look like.\n\n\"We've had the first round of the negotiation, and those talks have shown that many of the withdrawal questions can only be settled in the light of our future partnership, so now is the time to set out our approach to that partnership, to inform the upcoming negotiations, and to provide citizens and businesses at home and across Europe with a deeper understanding of our thinking.\"\n\nPublishing the position paper is also aimed at sending a formal signal that at least one aspect of the bitter row within the cabinet about Britain's future relationship with the EU has been resolved.\n\nThe chancellor, Philip Hammond, regarded by Conservative backbenchers as the champion of a \"soft Brexit\", has signed up to a joint statement with Liam Fox, the international trade secretary, confirming that Britain would be \"outside the customs union\" during the post-Brexit transition phase and that at that point it would be \"a 'third country', not party to the EU treaties\".\n\nFox was concerned that he would be unable to strike trade deals with countries outside the EU unless it was made clear that Britain did not expect to remain part of the customs union, whose members cannot strike individual trade agreements, and are expected to apply EU tariffs on imports.\n\nMay's spokesman said: \"The prime minister set out in January in the Lancaster House speech the need for an implementation period, to avoid a cliff edge for business. The article by the chancellor and the international trade secretary made clear that that is the position of the government,\" adding, \"The customs union as it currently stands has an impact on our ability to make trade deals.\"\n\nHammond appears to have conceded that remaining a member of the customs union is not possible, even as an interim arrangement while a detailed deal is finalised.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the EU is also expected to publish a separate paper, on Northern Ireland, later in the week, which will directly inform the next round of talks, since this is one of the issues the EU wants resolved early.\n\nAfter the last round of negotiations in Brussels last month, the EU's negotiator, Michel Barnier, expressed some frustration at the lack of detail from the British side - particularly on the financial settlement.\n\nHe said: \"As soon as the UK is ready to clarify the nature of its commitments, we will be prepared to discuss this with the British negotiators ... This week's experience has quite simply shown that we make better progress where our respective positions are clear.\"\n\nDavis initially insisted Britain would like to negotiate a new trade deal alongside the exit terms, describing discussions over the phasing of the talks as \"the row of the summer\" and warning that signing up to a financial settlement early could disadvantage Britain later in the talks.\n\nBut when formal negotiations got under way in June, after the general election wiped out Theresa May's comfortable governing majority, Britain quickly signed up to the EU's proposed "eng-3358827", "body": "Britain's plans for a new customs deal with the European Union have been dismissed as \"fantasy\" by the European Parliament's Brexit negotiator.\n\nGuy Verhofstadt delivered his withering verdict as the UK proposals received a chilly welcome in Brussels.\n\n\"To be in and out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy.\"\n\nGuy Verhofstadt\n\nJust two weeks before Brexit negotiations resume, Britain raised the stakes by setting out moves to levy VAT and customs duties on EU imports if a deal is not struck over the terms of Britain's departure.\n\nIn the first of a series of papers setting out its negotiating position, the government called for an interim customs agreement with the bloc following Brexit in March 2019.\n\nBritain would negotiate trade deals with other countries during that period under the UK proposal.\n\nMoves to avoid long queues\n\nAfter that time, ministers have raised the idea of Britain doing away with the need for customs checks for goods destined for the bloc by \"mirroring\" EU tariffs.\n\nAlternatively, a \"streamlined\" approach would see the UK negotiate agreements with the EU to reduce trade barriers and use technology to avoid long queues at ports.\n\nBut Mr Verhofstadt responded: \"To be in and out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy.\"\n\nMichel Barnier, the European Commission's chief Brexit negotiator, also said future customs arrangements could not be discussed until the issues of citizens' rights, Britain's exit payment and Northern Ireland's status had been settled.\n\nA Commission spokesman said Brussels would study the customs paper carefully.\n\nHe added: \"We take note of the UK's request for an implementing period and its preferences as regards the future relationship, but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal.\"\n\nUK warning of VAT\n\nThe 14-page Whitehall paper, Future Customs Arrangements for the UK, disclosed that legislation would be published to impose new custom duties and VAT tariffs on trade with the EU in case no deal is reached.\n\nThe move will be seen as a warning that Britain is ready to walk away from the negotiating table rather than reach an unacceptable agreement.\n\nDavid Davis, the Brexit Secretary, said an interim customs deal would be \"in both sides' interest\" as he insisted European leaders did not want to punish Britain for voting to leave the bloc.\n\nHe also refused to rule out paying for the temporary arrangement, while officials The UK will also attempt to broker trade deals with other, non-EU countries during this time, though they will not be able to take effect until any temporary customs union has expired.\n\nCredit: PA\n\nSpeaking to BBC Radio, the Minister for Brexit David Davies said that the period of transition between the formal date of Brexit in March 2019 and the new trade deals kicking in would be \"something like two years\" and would have to be over by 2022, which is the date of the next scheduled UK General Election.\n\nBritain is intent that free movement of goods, which is a key facet of the existing EU customs union, would end when Britain leaves. \"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU\" is proposed in the statement released today as a potential solution.\n\nThe statement was welcomed by the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), who represent British business worldwide, but are described as \"fantasy\" by a leading Labour MP.\n\nCredit: PA\n\n\"The clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible\" said Josh Hardie, deputy director of the CBI. On the other side, Labour MP for Nottingham East and spokesman for pro-EU group Open Britain Chris Leslie called the Brexit plan \"wishful thinking of the highest order\".\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union,\" he continued.\n\nDavid Davies will announce a raft of potential Brexit strategies this week. Today's announcement will be followed tomorrow by a statement regarding the future status of Northern Ireland, which has Britain's only land border with the European Union.\n\nWords by Mike {"timeCrawl": "00:49:00", "uri": "709514813", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:13:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "Reuters", "uri": "reuters.com", "id": "8"}, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-customs-idUSKCN1AU2IK", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - Britain will propose setting up an interim customs agreement with the European Union after Brexit to allow the freest possible trade of goods.\n\nBut it will also seek the right to negotiate other trade deals, a possible sticking point in the talks.\n\nAccording to excerpts of a government document to be published on Tuesday setting out Britain's strategy, the government will say one option to minimize friction when it leaves the bloc in March 2019 would be to introduce a temporary customs union which should be \"time-limited\".\n\nThat would provide certainty for businesses, the government said, aiming to address a main concern of companies who fear the introduction of customs checks will cause expensive delays.\n\n\"Ministers will announce an intention to seek an 'interim' period with the EU of close association with the customs union that would allow for a smooth and orderly transfer to the new regime,\" the government said in a statement ahead of publication of the first in a series of \"future partnership papers\".\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU ... During this interim period, which will be negotiated with Brussels, Britain will look to negotiate bold new trade relationships around the world.\"\n\nBusinesses welcomed the proposals, but the Confederation of British Industry also warned the government that \"the clock is ticking and what matters now if giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible\".\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May and her government are keen to move the talks with the EU forward to tackle the future relationship rather than focusing only on their divorce, and have promised to publish a series of policy documents this week.\n\nBut after being criticized by some EU officials for being ill-prepared for the first rounds of negotiations, the government's demand to secure trade deals while participating in a temporary customs union may cause further problems.\n\n\"It looks like the new unified position in the cabinet is to return the government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it,\" said Chris Leslie, a pro-EU campaigner and member of Britain's opposition Labour Party.\n\nCountries that are part of the EU's customs union are not allowed to negotiate bilateral trade deals and May's government has said Brexit means Britain must leave the customs union.\n\nBut Turkey, while not an EU member, is part of a separate customs union for industrial goods and can still negotiate bilateral trade deals. It was not clear whether Britain was pursuing a similar arrangement to Turkey.\n\nThe government said that by sorting out the customs arrangements, Britain and the bloc could avoid a \"hard border\" with EU member state Ireland, something which officials fear could reignite tensions between Irish nationalists and unionists.\n\nIt proposed two different ways -- a highly streamlined customs arrangement managed by Britain, or a new customs partnership with the EU, which could \"negate the need for a customs border\".\n\nIts proposals on a future customs arrangement are set out in one of several position papers intended to flesh out the government's Brexit vision and show a united stance over the future relationship after rifts emerged among ministers.\n\nOn Wednesday, the government Reuters\n\nLONDON -- Chancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox have attempted to quell any accusations of a divide within the government over the UK's approach to Brexit.\n\nWriting in a joint article in the Sunday Telegraph, two of Prime Minister Theresa May's most senior ministers said that the UK will seek a transition deal for leaving the EU, but that any deal will not be a \"back door\" to staying in the bloc and would be limited in its time period.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over twenty months' time,\" the pair write.\n\n\"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\n\nHammond and Fox have previously been seen to be sitting on two different sides of the Brexit fence. Hammond, who campaigned to remain in the EU prior to last June's vote, has publicly made clear that he favours a softer Brexit numerous times, and is believed to have frequently clashed with May over her approach to leaving the bloc. Fox on the other hand, is a staunch Brexiteer.\n\nHowever, Sunday's joint article appears to be an attempt to put to bed rumours and reports that May's cabinet is deeply divided on what kind of Brexit Britain should be looking at.\n\nIn recent weeks numerous newspapers have reported cabinet splits, with ministers leaking confidential details of meetings in what appeared to be the first stages of a battle to succeed May as PM.\n\nContinuing, the pair write that any transition \"must ensure a smooth and predictable pathway for businesses and citizens alike. {"timeCrawl": "06:43:00", "uri": "709617844", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T05:55:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "Evening Standard", "uri": "standard.co.uk", "id": "21"}, "url": "https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/brexit-britain-unveils-plan-for-temporary-customs-union-with-eu-a3611681.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Critics have dismissed the proposals as a \"fantasy\" by the Conservative Government\n\nBritain will attempt to retain access to the customs union for several years after Brexit.\n\nThe Government has unveiled plans to continue with current customs arrangements for at least three years after Britain officially leaves the EU in 2019.\n\nThe move, announced in a government paper published on Tuesday, marks a victory for those advocating a smooth transition deal rather than a \"cliff-edge\" feared by businesses.\n\nThe UK will set out its ambitious proposals for a time-limited transition period, which Brexit Secretary David Davis believes will create the \"freest and most frictionless possible trade\" with Europe.\n\nIt is hoped the temporary measure with avert border chaos and calm UK businesses worried by the effects of leaving the European Union.\n\nCritics have dubbed the proposals \"a fantasy\" and said they will do little to provide the certainty businesses have called for.\n\nMr Davis, writing for the City AM newspaper, said the UK's new customs arrangements \"will need to facilitate the freest and most frictionless possible trade in goods between Britain and the EU\".\n\nHe said the Government would seek to negotiate an interim period with the EU in order to avoid \"unnecessary disruption\".\n\nHe added: \"That would be a strong indicator to all our businesses and citizens that politicians on both sides are serious about finding a constructive outcome that works for all involved. Doing so is our shared duty.\n\n\"The united desire to avoid unnecessary disruption or a disorderly exit for the United Kingdom from the European Union is a strong foundation for the negotiations.\"\n\nMinisters have been warned about the strain ports could be put under if they face a big increase in bureaucracy for dealing with goods entering and leaving the country.\n\nThe proposals for new customs arrangements to allow trade with the EU are being outlined in the first of a series of \"future partnership papers\" being released by the Government.\n\nAlthough negotiations on a new system are not scheduled to start for some time, the Government said setting out its aims showed the UK's \"desire to ensure our exit from the EU is smooth, orderly and successful\".\n\nOne option being put forward by Mr Davis for new arrangements would see the UK manage a new customs border with administration streamlined to the \"fullest extent possible\".\n\nSir Keir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, called the proposals \"incoherent and inadequate\" in response to pleas for certainty from British businesses.\n\nHe said: \"The Cabinet remain split on key issues and cannot decide between two very different but equally unachievable options.\n\n\"The first proposal suggests 'a new customs border with the EU' could be introduced without disrupting trade; the second suggests a new borderless customs partnership could somehow be agreed while Britain also signs external trade deals.\n\n\"These fantastical and contradictory proposals provide no guidance for negotiators or certainty for businesses.\"\n\nIt comes after Chancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox said the UK would pull out of both the single market and the customs union in 2019.\n\nLabour former shadow chancellor Chris Leslie, a leading supporter of the Open Britain campaign group, said: \"It looks like the new unified position in the Cabinet is to return the Government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it.\n\nHe added: \"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the Government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union.\"\n\nTom Brake, the Liberal Democrats' Brexit spokesman, said the Government's \"extreme Brexit will end up {"timeCrawl": "08:34:00", "uri": "709658556", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T08:34:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "MaltaToday.com.mt", "uri": "maltatoday.com.mt", "id": "814"}, "url": "http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/europe/79737/uk_suggests_temporary_customs_union_with_eu_new_trade_deals_postbrexit", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The UK sets out the 'ambitious new customs arrangement' it wants to secure with the EU after Brexit\n\nThe UK government will today confirm it wants to negotiate a transitional customs arrangement to take effect after Britain leaves the European Union, in the first of many official position papers to be published over the next few months.\n\nThe paper is expected to express the government's desire to negotiate a bespoke, time-limited customs arrangement, designed to protect British business from the effects of a \"cliff-edge\" Brexit.\n\nAccording to excerpts of the document setting out Britain's strategy, the government will say one option to minimise friction when it leaves the bloc in March 2019 would be to introduce a temporary customs union which should be \"time-limited\".\n\nMinisters said the plans would mean the \"freest and most frictionless possible trade\" with the rest of Europe and would provide certainty for businesses, as the British government aims to address a main concern of companies who fear the introduction of customs checks will cause expensive delays.\n\nThe government also wants to be able to negotiate trade deals with countries around the world during this proposed transitional period. Full custom union members are prohibited from doing trade deals with countries outside the EU.\n\nThe EU has made it clear on several occasions it will not discuss future trade relations with Britain until significant progress has been made on issues like the rights of citizens and the money the UK must pay in financial obligations, or the divorce bill as it has become known.\n\nHowever, the feeling within government is British negotiators will struggle to make progress when talks resume later this month unless the British side has a clear understanding of what it wants post-Brexit trade relations to look like.\n\nBusinesses welcomed the proposals, but the Confederation of British Industry also warned the government that \"the clock is ticking and what matters now if giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible\".\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union (DExEU) is expected to release the papers at around midday on Tuesday. It will be the clearest insight yet into the details of what Prime Minister Theresa May, Brexit Secretary David Davis, and the rest of the Cabinet hope to achieve in divorce talks with the EU.\n\nOn {"timeCrawl": "14:43:00", "uri": "709818462", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:43:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "out-law.com", "uri": "out-law.com", "id": "8088"}, "url": "https://www.out-law.com/en/articles/2017/august/uk-aims-for-transitional-customs-deal-with-eu/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "A \"model of close association with the EU customs union for a time-limited interim period\" would benefit both the UK and EU member states, the government has said in a white paper laying out two potential customs arrangements.\n\nThe paper confirms that \"as we leave the EU we will also leave the EU customs union\". However, an interim deal would minimise disruption and provide certainty for businesses and individuals if it is agreed early in the process, it said.\n\nWhile the UK will pursue new trade negotiations with other countries after leaving the EU, it would not make any new arrangements with third countries \"which were not consistent with the terms of the interim agreement\", the paper said.\n\nThe paper looks at two potential approaches to creating \"the freest and most frictionless trade possible\" between the UK and the EU, while allowing the UK to create new trade relationships both in Europe and elsewhere.\n\nThe first approach involves what the government has called a \"streamlined customs arrangement\" with as few additional requirements on EU trade as possible.\n\nThe aim would be to continue some existing arrangements between the UK and the EU but to put in place new and potentially unilateral agreements to reduce or remove barriers to trade. Technology would be used to make it easier to comply with customs procedures, the paper said.\n\nThis approach would use the UK's existing third country processes for UK-EU trade, \"building on EU and international precedents, and developing new innovative facilitations to deliver as frictionless a customs border as possible\", it said.\n\nThe second proposed approach is a new customs partnership that would remove the need for a UK-EU customs border. This could involve, for example, the UK mirroring the EU's requirements for imports from the rest of the world.\n\n\"This is of course unprecedented as an approach and could be challenging to implement and we will look to explore the principles of this with business and the EU,\" the paper said.\n\nThe ultimate arrangement will of course depend on negotiations with the EU, it said.\n\nThe government will work with the Scottish and Welsh governments and the Northern Ireland executive on the practical impact of new customs arrangements and on specific issues such as ports and the land border between Northern Ireland and Ireland, it said.\n\nGuy Lougher of Pinsent Masons, the law firm behind Out-Law.com, said: \"The EU has indicated that there must be agreement on three core issues - the exit bill, the rights of citizens and Ireland - before there can be negotiations on wider issues, including the shape of the UK's future trading relationship with the EU. By raising now the very important issue of the future customs arrangement between the EU and the UK, the UK government is hoping to advance discussions on this issue; whether the EU negotiators choose to engage at this stage remains to be seen.\"\n\nFive of the UK's major business organisations signed an open letter to the government in June calling for continued access to the EU single market until the UK's departure is agreed and implemented.\n\nThe British Chambers of Commerce, the Confederation of British Industry, the manufacturers' organisation EEF, the Federation of Small Businesses and the Institute of Directors called on the government to \"engage continuously\" with UK business interests as negotiations take place.\n\nThe organisations called for a tariff-free goods trade agreement between the UK and EU, regulatory equivalence and mutual recognition of standards on an ongoing basis to ensure continued mutual access for both goods and services, and a flexible system for the movement of labour and skills.\n\nA number of other organisations have also warned of the impact of leaving the single market. Last July the head of the Financial Conduct Authority said the country should push for continued access to the single market for financial institutions, while think tank the Institute of Fiscal Studies said the move would depress tax receipts and impact gross domestic product.", "id": "9298778", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "UK aims for transitional customs deal with EU", {"timeCrawl": "13:25:00", "uri": "709783757", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:25:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "Mirror", "uri": "mirror.co.uk", "id": "205"}, "url": "http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/tories-brexit-customs-union-plan-10991085", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Tory Brexiteers who claimed they'd sweep bureaucracy away could be humiliated under proposals for how Britain will import and export goods\n\nGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nBritain's Brexit customs plan has been branded a 'fantasy' as it emerged businesses face a surge in red tape.\n\nTory Brexiteers who claimed they'd sweep bureaucracy away could be humiliated under proposals for how Britain will import and export goods.\n\nBritain plans to ask the EU for a temporary customs union to bridge the gap immediately after March 2019.\n\nBut after that officials admit there will be \"additional costs\" and a \"larger volume\" of customs declarations if they change systems after Brexit.\n\nEuro judges could still rule on disputes, and the UK could be forced to pay for its temporary deal - even if it is near-identical to what we enjoy now.\n\nThe revelations came as the government unveiled its vision of a \"future partnership\" when Britain leaves the Customs Union after March 2019.\n\nAfter a transitional deal, today's paper sets out two options.\n\nThe first would keep a lot of the EU's current customs regime in a 'highly streamlined' system.\n\nThe second, more difficult option would mean forming a 'new customs partnership' with separate tariffs for goods sold on in the EU and UK.\n\nYet neither is part of formal negotiations - because EU chiefs refuse to discuss trade until they've sorted out Britain's so-called 'divorce bill'.\n\nEuropean Commission negotiator Michel Barnier took a sideswipe at the plan's timing, tweeting: \"The quicker UK & EU27 agree on citizens, settling accounts and Ireland, the quicker we can discuss customs & future relationship.\"\n\nEuropean Parliament chief Brexit negotiator Guy Verhofstadt trashed the plan itself, writing: \"To be in & out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy.\"\n\nEven under the first 'streamlined' option there will be \"an increase in administration\", the government's plan says.\n\nAnd it could involve business having to \"self-assess\" what they owe in customs duties.\n\nThe second option would supposedly \"mirror\" the EU's customs approach - meaning anything imported from around the world to the UK, then exported to the EU, would use EU rates.\n\nBut goods sold elsewhere would use a different set of tariffs - the cost of which could fall on businesses.\n\nA suggestion is to force firms to pay the highest possible tariff for importing goods, EU or UK - whether or not it's correct.\n\nBusinesses would only be able to claim back what they overpaid when the goods are sold months later.\n\nAnother method would be to force firms to declare the contents of lorry wagons as they set out on journeys, then scan their number plates through cameras fixed on overhead motorway gantries.\n\nA senior government official admitted: \"It is unprecedented as a model and it is untested.\n\n\"And I think that's an area where we would need much more engagement to understand what these businesses would want from that.\"\n\nQuizzed by journalists, officials could not put a firm number on how many new staff will be needed for a new system or how long it would take to implement.\n\nThe document published today says Britain will \"seek to ensure\" Brits can freely travel with goods for personal use as they do now.\n\nDuring the transition Britain will discuss trade deals outside the EU but will be unable to implement them.\n\nAnd officials confirmed there will be a Customs Bill this autumn to prepare Britain for the possibility of leaving with no deal.\n\n\"That's not the government's preferred outcome but it's essential we prepare for it,\" a senior official said.\n\nEarlier, Brexit Secretary David Davis refused to rule out Britain paying for access to a temporary customs union after we leave the bloc in March 2019.\n\nAsked by ITV if Britain would have to stump up cash for the arrangement, Mr Davis said: \"Well what happens in that interim period you have to leave to me to negotiate.\"\n\nLater, he told the BBC: \"I'm not going to do the negotiation here... Wait and see.\"\n\nMr Davis claimed his changeover period would last \"most likely something like two years - probably a bit shorter\".\n\nBut the document his department published was much less specific, saying: \"The length of the interim period needs further consideration.\"\n\nShadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said: \"These are incoherent and inadequate proposals designed to gloss over deep and continuing divisions within the Cabinet.\"\n\nLib Dem Brexit spokesman Tom Brake said: \"We face the prospect of more red tape for businesses, longer queues at our borders and higher prices for consumers once the transition comes to an end.\"\n\nScotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said the government was \"back to its daft 'have cake and eat it' approach to Brexit\".", "id": {"timeCrawl": "14:44:00", "uri": "709818761", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:44:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "Yeni \u015eafak", "uri": "yenisafak.com", "id": "19266"}, "url": "http://www.yenisafak.com/en/world/uk-suggests-customs-plan-for-frictionless-eu-exit-2779886", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "However, opposition party hits out at 'fantastical and contradictory proposals'\n\nThe British government on Tuesday published proposals for a new post-Brexit customs plan with the EU, aiming to make future trade \"as frictionless as possible\".\n\nThe paper, part of a series of documents to be released ahead of renewed Brexit negotiations, claims \"there are two broad approaches the U.K. could adopt\" -- streamlining current arrangements or establishing a new customs partnership.\n\nThe U.K. is expected to leave the EU in 2019 as a result of a 2016 referendum which began the process of ending the country's 44-year membership of the bloc.\n\n\"A highly streamlined customs arrangement,\" is one option the British government seems more eager to propose to EU negotiators.\n\nLondon, in this choice, is aiming to \"continue some of the existing arrangements between the U.K. and the EU\".\n\nLeaving as few additional requirements on EU trade as possible and implementing technology-based solutions form part of the proposals to deliver \"as frictionless a customs border as possible\".\n\nHowever, the U.K. government said a new deal would be \"unprecedented as an approach and could be challenging to implement\".\n\nThe paper said London would \"look to explore the principles of this with business and the EU\".\n\n\"A new customs partnership with the EU,\" forms the second option, which would \"involve the U.K. mirroring the EU's requirements for imports from the rest of the world where their final destination is the EU\".\n\nThe U.K. said persuing either of these options would depend on negotiations with the EU as the two models provided different approaches.\n\n- 'No guidance'\n\nSecretary of State for Exiting the EU David Davis said: \"The approaches will benefit both the EU and the U.K. and avoid a cliff-edge for businesses and individuals on both sides.\"\n\nHowever, Keir Starmer, Davis's opposition Labour Party's counterpart, said Britain's government remained divided internally over Brexit.\n\nIn a statement, he said: \"The first proposal suggests 'a new customs border with the EU' could be introduced without disrupting trade; the second suggests a new borderless customs partnership could somehow be agreed while Britain also signs external trade deals.\n\n\"These fantastical and contradictory proposals provide no guidance for negotiators or certainty for businesses. The proposals also make it less likely that necessary transitional arrangements will be in place by March 2019.\"\n\nTuesday's paper also suggested the U.K.'s only land frontier -- between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland -- should avoid becoming a \"hard border\".\n\nThe government \"would seek to recognize the unique circumstances of Northern Ireland and aim to protect individuals and traders,\" it added.\n\nAnother policy paper on the Irish border issue is expected from the British government on Wednesday.", "id": "9298917", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", {"timeCrawl": "23:21:00", "uri": "709489965", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:21:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "The Huffington Post", "uri": "huffingtonpost.co.uk", "id": "2080"}, "url": "http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/customs-union-brexit-interim-transistion_uk_5991f60ee4b08a24727686e1", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "David Davis seems to be at odds with Liam Fox and Philip Hammond.\n\nThe UK's customs rules could still be imposed by Brussels after Brexit, the Government has revealed as it outlined plans for a trade \"alignment\" with the EU.\n\nAhead of the launch of a new paper on the UK's future trading relationship with the bloc, the Department for Exiting the EU announced two possible solutions for life after leaving the customs union.\n\nOne scenario would see a border managed by the UK - which the Government describes as a \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\".\n\nThe other would see no border with the EU at all, as the UK would be in a \"customs partnership\" with Brussels.\n\nThis arrangement, described as an alignment, could potentially see the UK mirroring the EU's customs arrangements - meaning if Brussels makes changes, Britain would be forced to adopt them.\n\nThe paper also claimed the UK could be in a \"temporary customs union\" with the EU after March 2019 - seemingly contradicting a vow from Chancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox that Britain will be \"outside the customs union\" after that date.\n\nEconomist Ruth Lea - a former civil servant who campaigned for Brexit - branded the call for a temporary union \"rather extraordinary.\"\n\nShe told HuffPost UK: \"That seems to fly in the face of what Liam Fox and Philip Hammond were saying in the Sunday Telegraph - I don't know how they square it.\"\n\n\"They do keep giving out conflicting signals.\"\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May confirmed the UK would leave the customs union - which ensures non-EU imports are subject to the same tariffs across the bloc - in her Lancaster House speech in January.\n\nA House of Lords report published in March warned the imposition of customs checks could damage the annual \u00a3357 billion trade between the UK and the EU, and businesses could be hit financially thanks to increased bureaucracy.\n\nIf the UK is unable to strike a deal with the EU within the two-year period set out by the Article 50 withdrawal process, the two markets will fall back to World Trade Organisation rules.\n\nThis could see cars being sold to the EU hit with a 10% tariff, alcohol with an almost 20% tariff, and dairy products with a more than 36% tariff.\n\nThe Government's \"future partnership paper\" on the customs union is set to be published on Tuesday, and will set out details of a \"time-limited\" transitional period before the new arrangements kick in.\n\n\"One possible approach would be a temporary customs union between the UK and the EU\", an overnight briefing said ahead of the full paper being published.\n\nWhen it comes to the post-interim period arrangement, the briefing states:\n\n\"Our goal is to secure as frictionless trade as possible with the EU alongside the ability to forge trade deals around the world, and avoiding a hard border with Ireland.\n\n\"We are proposing two different ways that would best meet these goals achieve this:\n\nLib Dem Brexit spokesperson Tom Brake claimed trade deals already mooted by the Government would render the \"no border\" option impractical.\n\nBrake said: \"Liam Fox's plans to drop the ban on chlorinated chicken would mean customs checks by the EU. They will rightly want to stop dodgy chicken and other products coming in via the UK.\n\n\"The bottom line is we're either in the customs union or not - you can't be half pregnant.\n\n\"The only way to prevent barriers to trade with the EU is to stay in the Customs Union and Single Market.\"\n\nHis comments echoed those of Labour's former Shadow Chancellor Chris Leslie, who branded the paper's suggestions as \"wishful thinking of the highest order\".\n\nThe Open Britain supporter said: \"It looks like the new unified position in the Cabinet is to return the Government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it.\n\n\"Ministers claim we can leave the Customs Union and yet still achieve 'the most frictionless customs agreement anywhere in the world' but with absolutely no detail about how such a miraculous new system will be achieved.\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the Government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the Customs Union.\"\n\nWant to know what's really going on with Brexit? Sign up for HuffPost UK's Brexit Briefing - sent straight to your inbox every Thursday.\n\nLeading business groups welcomed the report for providing much needed clarity in an area of concern for companies across the UK.\n\nJosh Hardie, CBI Deputy Director-General, said: \"It's encouraging to see that these papers propose a time-limited interim period and a customs system that is as barrier-free as possible.\n\n\"We at the CBI have always been clear that new ideas on crucial issues like this should be brought to the table quickly.\n\n\"But the clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible.\"\n\nHardie added: \"To secure frictionless trade, negotiations on regulation, tariff and non-tariff barriers will have to take place. All efforts should be made to deliver a single-step transition, so that businesses don't have to adapt twice.\"\n\nDr Adam Marshall, Director General of the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC), also called for a \"smooth transition\", adding: \"For most of the businesses we speak to, clarity on the UK's future customs arrangement with the EU is significantly higher on their priority list than the swift negotiation of new free trade agreements.\n\n\"For that reason, business needs to see the government's resources focused on the conclusion of a successful customs deal with the EU.\n\n\"At this stage, it is critically important to keep a number of different options open in order to achieve this goal.\"", "id": "9177798", "details": {"liCnt": 15}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "Government {"timeCrawl": "22:24:00", "uri": "709472791", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T22:17:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/aug/14/theresa-may-interim-eu-deal-brexit", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Ministers hope to strike a temporary deal with the European Union to retain the key benefits of the customs union for an interim period after Brexit, to avoid cross-border commerce grinding to a halt.\n\nThe government will use a position paper published on Tuesday to reveal that, for a brief period, it will seek a deal allowing the transit of goods across borders to continue as now - perhaps by striking a \"temporary customs union\".\n\nMinisters hope this will avoid economic disruption by giving businesses and officials time to gear up for a new customs regime; while sidestepping the constraint that full members of the customs union are not allowed to strike independent trade deals with non-EU countries.\n\nThe government will say it wants to create \"the freest and most frictionless possible trade in goods between the UK and the EU\".\n\nThe paper will also reject the idea of a lengthy transition period, during which the status quo is maintained while negotiations drag on: an option favoured by pro-EU Tories, and business groups including the CBI.\n\nNo specific time limit for the interim deal has been spelled out by the government, but ministers involved in the negotiations believe anything longer than two years would be unlikely to secure the backing of Britain's EU partners. In particular, they fear a more drawn out period would be likely to require the approval of individual member states' national parliaments - a time-consuming process.\n\nOne senior cabinet minister told the Guardian a long transition was \"not a flier\", because it would not be in line with the referendum result, and was likely to be rejected by the rest of the EU.\n\nThe threat of cumbersome new customs checks is one of the key issues causing anxiety among businesses and senior ministers, alongside fears about intricate manufacturing supply chains being broken and long queues of lorries at cross-border ports when Britain leaves the EU.\n\nOn Sunday, Liam Fox and Philip Hammond, the latter previously regarded as a champion of a \"soft Brexit\", published a joint statement in the Sunday Telegraph saying Britain would be outside the customs union during the post-Brexit transition phase and at that point it would be \"a 'third country', not party to the EU treaties\".\n\nHammond was accused of caving in to the demands of the Brexiters, but the paper will make clear that the government is keen to retain the full benefits of the customs union in the short-term - albeit without formal membership. The EU will have to decide whether it would accept such an arrangement.\n\nTuesday's paper will also set out more details of how the government hopes to achieve frictionless trade with the rest of the EU in the long term: the aim set out by Theresa May in her Lancaster House speech in January.\n\nThe government is examining two options: either a highly streamlined new arrangement \"in which the UK would manage a new customs border\" but would seek to make any checks minimal; or a new customs partnership, which would see Britain replicate the EU's approach so closely that it would \"negate the need for a customs border\".\n\nKeir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, dismissed what he said were \"incoherent and inadequate proposals designed to gloss over deep and continuing divisions within the cabinet\".\n\nThe first proposal suggests a new customs border with the EU could be introduced without disrupting trade - apparently to be managed by the UK, making it the first customs union in the world to be managed by just one country. The second suggests a new borderless customs partnership could somehow be agreed while Britain also signs external trade deals.\n\nThe proposals are being published in advance of the next round of negotiations in Brussels - despite the fact the EU has insisted it won't discuss post-Brexit trade arrangements until a series of other issues, including the financial settlement, are resolved.\n\nThe prime minister's spokesman said the government had concluded from the early talks, which kicked off in earnest last month, that it could not make more progress without a clearer sense of what the future relationship might look like.\n\nHe said: \"We've had the first round of the negotiations, and those talks have shown that many of the withdrawal questions can only be settled in the light of our future partnership. So now is the time to set out our approach to that partnership, to inform the upcoming negotiations, and to provide citizens and businesses at home and across Europe with a deeper understanding of our thinking.\"\n\nIn particular it is difficult to hold substantive talks about the future of the land border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic - another of the EU's early demands - without knowing what the customs relationship will be. The government will publish further proposals on the Irish issue on Wednesday.\n\nAfter the last round of negotiations in Brussels, Michel Barnier expressed some frustration at the lack of detail from the British side - particularly on the financial settlement. The EU's chief Brexit negotiator said: \"This week's experience has quite simply shown that we make better progress where our respective positions are clear.\"\n\nThe government's critics said the plans were fresh evidence that David Davis and May had not yet accepted the trade-offs it would be necessary to make once talks got under way.\n\nThe Liberal Democrats' Brexit spokesman, Tom Brake, said: \"The only way to ensure 'free and frictionless' trade with the EU is to remain a full member of the customs union and single market.\n\n\"It doesn't matter how it's dressed up or how long it's postponed: the government's extreme Brexit will end up leaving Britain poorer.\"\n\nThe CBI's deputy director, Josh Hardie, welcomed the publication of fresh details of the government's aims for a new customs deal. However he called for rapid progress on a wider trade deal, including what tariffs and other barriers would be imposed on exports to the EU.\n\n\"Business wants to see as frictionless a customs system as possible, with a strong emphasis on digital systems that make it easier to trade,\" he said. \"But to secure frictionless trade, negotiations on regulation, tariff and non-tariff barriers will have to take place. All efforts should be made to deliver a single-step transition, so that businesses don't have to adapt twice.\"", "id": "9171671", "details": {"liCnt": 31}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "Theresa May {"timeCrawl": "04:02:00", "uri": "709563171", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:18:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "iNews", "uri": "inews.co.uk", "id": "14843"}, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/essentials/news/politics/theresa-may-sets-plans-avert-post-brexit-chaos-ports/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Theresa May will press for Britain to enter into a temporary customs deal with the European Union in 2019 to avoid chaos on the day after Brexit as ministers begin to detail their approach to historic withdrawal talks.\n\nBut the government faced charges of \"wanting to have their cake and eat it\" by suggesting the UK could temporarily enjoy the benefits of existing customs arrangements while standing outside the bloc.\n\nIts plan is also likely to run into fierce resistance in Brussels which could object to Britain trying to negotiate its own beneficial trade deals with countries around the world while effectively being part of the EU customs union.\n\nThe government will on Tuesday announce the plan as it starts to flesh out its negotiating stance in talks over Britain's future relationship with the bloc.\n\nMotorway queues\n\nMinisters have been warned that the imposition of customs checks at ports risks economic damage, huge delays and even lengthy motorway queues.\n\nTo avoid that prospect, ministers are proposing an \"interim period\" of \"close association\" between the UK and the EU customs union under which goods can be bought and sold tariff-free.\n\n\"The only way to guarantee 'free and frictionless' trade with the EU is to stay in the customs union and single market.\n\n\"Anything else risks creating more red tape for business, longer queues at our borders and higher prices for consumers.\"\n\nSir Vince Cable, Liberal Democrat leader\n\nOne possible approach, they say, would be to operate a temporary UK-EU customs union.\n\nDuring this period, the government would attempt to hammer out new trade deals with major trading partners, including forging a new relationship with the EU.\n\nIt believes it can broker a \"streamlined\" deal with the bloc, building on the existing lack of tariffs within the union.\n\nThe proposal will be spelt out in the first of several government papers published in coming weeks which will spell out Mrs May's approach to Brexit.\n\nMore time for business\n\nMinisters argue that the move would give businesses more time to prepare for the eventual new customs regime.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union, headed by Brexit Secretary David Davis, said its goal is \"to secure as frictionless trade as possible with the EU alongside the ability to forge trade deals around the world\".\n\nIt said the government wanted to demonstrate Britain's \"desire to ensure our exit from the EU is smooth, orderly and successful\".\n\nThe proposal strikes a different note from the joint declaration by Chancellor Philip Hammond and Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary, at the weekend that the UK will be \"outside the customs union\" during the transition as it will become a 'third country' not party to the EU treaties\".\n\nJosh Hardie, the CBI's deputy director-general, said: \"It is encouraging to see these papers propose a time-limited interim period and a customs system that is as barrier-free as possible.\n\n\"We at the CBI have always been clear that new ideas on crucial issues like this should be brought to the table quickly.\"\n\n'Wishful thinking'\n\nSir Vince Cable, the Liberal Democrat leader, said: \"The only way to guarantee 'free and frictionless' trade with the EU is to stay in the customs union and single market.\n\n\"Anything else risks creating more red tape for business, longer queues at our borders and higher prices for consumers.\"\n\nThe Labour MP Chris Leslie, of the Open Britain campaign group, accused ministers of \"wishful thinking\".\n\nHe said: \"It looks like the new unified position in the Cabinet is to return the Government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it.\n\n\"Ministers claim we can leave the Customs Union and yet still achieve 'the most frictionless customs agreement anywhere in the world', but with absolutely no detail about how such a miraculous new system will be {"timeCrawl": "00:42:00", "uri": "708970996", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T00:42:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "Xinhuanet.com", "uri": "news.xinhuanet.com", "id": "942"}, "url": "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/14/c_136522998.htm", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON, Aug. 13 (Xinhua) -- Two of Prime Minister Theresa May's leading ministers said in a joint pledge Sunday that there will be a fixed transition period after Britain leaves the European Union (EU).\n\nBut the pro-remain chancellor Philip Hammond and leave supporter and Secretary for International Trade, Liam Fox both insist Britain will not be staying in the EU by the \"backdoor\".\n\nIn an article in the Sunday Telegraph newspaper, Hammond and Fox jointly declare Britain will completely leave the single market and customs union after Brexit in 2019.\n\nThe Telegraph comments that after a summer of bitter infighting between cabinet ministers, Hammond and Fox, with their joint pledge, appear to have buried the hatchet.\n\nThe newspaper adds that Theresa May, who is returning to 10 Downing Street this week after a walking holiday in the Italian Alps, will be hoping that the declaration of resolve by Hammond and Fox will draw a line under weeks of damaging headlines in which the Chancellor had been accused of trying to derail Brexit.\n\nThe two ministers say a transition period will be time limited and designed to avoid a cliff edge that could damage British business. They did not stipulate a likely length of time for any transitional period.\n\nIn their article, Hammond and Fox say: \"We respect the will of the British people; in March 2019 the United Kingdom will leave the European Union.\"\n\nBut they noted that \"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff-edge when we leave the EU in just over 20 months' time.\"\n\nThey further explained \"That is why we believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty, but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\"\n\nThe two ministers add they are both clear that during any transitional period Britain will be outside the European single market and outside the customs union and will be a \"third-country\" not party to EU treaties.\n\nExplaining what a transitional period would mean, Hammond and Fox said: \"During this period our (British) borders must continue to operate smoothly; goods bought on the internet must still cross borders; businesses must still be able to supply their customers across the EU and our innovative, world-leading companies must be able to hire the talent they need, including from within the EU.\"\n\nOnce any interim period is over, add Hammond and Fox, Britain will want a permanent, treaty-based arrangement with the EU which supports the closest possible relationship with Brussels, retaining close ties of security, trade and commerce.\n\nBrexit negotiations between the EU and Britain's Secretary of State for Leaving the European Union, are scheduled to resume in Brussels later {"timeCrawl": "10:06:00", "uri": "709695391", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T06:41:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "id": "14519"}, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/uk-might-pay-access-interim-customs-union-brexit-081327724.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Britain might have to pay to remain in a customs union with the EU after Brexit.\n\nSpeaking after the government unveiled its plans for an interim customs union to avoid a \"cliff-edge\" exit from the European Union, Brexit Secretary David Davis did not rule out the possibility of Britain paying for the privilege.\n\nAsked on ITV, Davis said that \"No, I don't think (so). Well what happens in that interim period you have to leave to me to negotiate.\"\n\nDavis, who embarked on a tour of the broadcasters on Tuesday morning in order to sell the proposals, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that the temporary agreement would be in place for a \"shortish period\" that would end before the next election.\n\n\"It's very very hard to say at this point to say exactly how long\", he said. \"I would say the most likely is something like two years, maybe a bit shorter.\"\n\nThe plan, seemingly designed as a compromise to resolve disagreements within the Cabinet, is contained in the Government's first \"future partnership paper\", published on Tuesday by the Department for Exiting the European Union.\n\nIt confirms the UK will ultimately leave the system, as Prime Minister Theresa May has repeatedly stated, but proposes a temporary customs union as a \"possible approach\" to ensuring a \"smooth and orderly\" transfer.\n\nThe customs union allows goods to travel across the EU free of tariffs and checks.\n\nThe proposal could provide assurances to nervy business leaders that Britain may avoid border chaos after leaving the bloc.\n\nThe plan also outlines an alternative scenario, which would see a border managed by the UK as part of a \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\".\n\nThe plans were unveiled just a day after Chancellor Philip Hammond and Secretary of State for International Trade Liam Fox insisted that the UK will leave the customs union after Brexit in a joint article for the Sunday Telegraph.\n\nThe mixed messages and reports of Britain's lack of preparedness in the first round of exit negotiations have put the government under pressure to lay out a clear position before a new round of talks later this month.\n\nLabour's shadow Brexit secretary, Sir Keir Starmer, branded the proposals \"incoherent and inadequate\" and said they were \"designed to gloss over deep and continuing divisions within the Cabinet\".\n\n\"Businesses, trade unions and the country need certainty about our future trading and customs arrangements\", he said.\n\n\"They also need a pragmatic and considered approach that delivers the best deal for Britain. Instead, the Cabinet remain split on key issues and cannot decide between two very different but equally unachievable options\".\n\nLabour's stance on the issue is itself in some doubt, with Starmer and shadow chancellor John McDonnell stressing that all options should remain on the table in contrast to leader Jeremy Corbyn, who stated unequivocally that he would take Britain out of the single time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty, but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\"\n\nThe within the EU.\"\n\nOnce any interim period is over, Hammond and Fox added, Britain will want a permanent, treaty-based arrangement with the EU which supports the closest possible relationship with
