{"timeCrawl": "23:17:00", "uri": "709489235", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:17:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"title": "derryjournal.com", "uri": "derryjournal.com", "id": "1564"}, "url": "http://www.derryjournal.com/news/ni/britain-could-keep-eu-customs-arrangements-for-interim-period-davis-says-1-8101334", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Britain could keep the same customs arrangements with the European Union for an interim period in order to avoid \"unnecessary disruption\" for UK businesses, David Davis has said.\n\nThe Brexit Secretary will publish a paper on Tuesday outlining proposals for a time-limited transition, meaning businesses on both sides of the Channel only have to adapt once to rule changes.\n\nTemporary arrangements could allow trade deals to be negotiated with other countries while governments and businesses adjust to new arrangements.\n\nHowever, reports suggested this would have to be negotiated during Brexit talks, with members of the EU's customs union barred from striking their own trade deals outside the bloc.\n\nCritics dubbed the proposals \"a fantasy\" and said they did little to provide the certainty businesses have called for.\n\nMr Davis, writing for the City AM newspaper, said the UK's new customs arrangements \"will need to facilitate the freest and most frictionless possible trade in goods between Britain and the EU\".\n\nHe said the Government would seek to negotiate an interim period with the EU in order to avoid \"unnecessary disruption\".\n\n\"That would be a strong indicator to all our businesses and citizens that politicians on both sides are serious about finding a constructive outcome that works for all involved. Doing so is our shared duty,\" he said.\n\n\"The united desire to avoid unnecessary disruption or a disorderly exit for the United Kingdom from the European Union is a strong foundation for the negotiations.\"\n\nMinisters have been warned about the strain ports could be put under if they face a big increase in bureaucracy for dealing with goods entering and leaving the country.\n\nThe proposals for new customs arrangements to allow trade with the EU are being outlined in the first of a series of \"future partnership papers\" being released by the Government.\n\nAlthough negotiations on a new system are not scheduled to start for some time, the Government said setting out its aims showed the UK's \"desire to ensure our exit from the EU is smooth, orderly and successful\".\n\nOne option being put forward by Mr Davis for new arrangements would see the UK manage a new customs border with administration streamlined to the \"fullest extent possible\".\n\nThe Brexit Secretary will also float plans for a customs partnership with the EU that would negate the need for a customs border between the UK and the rest of the bloc.\n\nA position paper on the fraught issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic will be published on Wednesday, ahead of the third round of Brexit negotiations in Brussels at the end of the month.\n\nSir Keir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, called the proposals \"incoherent and inadequate\" in response to pleas for certainty from British businesses.\n\n\"Instead, the Cabinet remain split on key issues and cannot decide between two very different but equally unachievable options,\" he said.\n\n\"The first proposal suggests 'a new customs border with the EU' could be introduced without disrupting trade; the second suggests a new borderless customs partnership could somehow be agreed while Britain also signs external trade deals.\n\n\"These fantastical and contradictory proposals provide no guidance for negotiators or certainty for businesses.\n\n\"The proposals also make it less likely that necessary transitional arrangements will be in place by March 2019.\"\n\nIt comes after Chancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox said the UK would pull out of both the single market and the customs union in 2019.\n\nLabour former shadow chancellor Chris Leslie, a leading supporter of the Open Britain campaign group, said: \"It looks like the new unified position in the Cabinet is to return the Government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it.\n\n\"Ministers claim we can leave the customs union and yet still achieve 'the most frictionless customs agreement anywhere in the world' but with absolutely no detail about how such a miraculous new system will be achieved.\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the Government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union.\"\n\nTom Brake, the Liberal Democrats Brexit spokesman, said the Government's \"extreme Brexit will end up leaving Britain poorer\".\n\nHe added: \"Even if they were agreed to by the EU, these proposals will only delay the economic pain caused by leaving the customs union.\n\n\"We still face the prospect of more red tape for businesses, longer queues at our borders and higher prices for consumers once the transition comes to an end.\"\n\nCopyright (c) Press Association Ltd. 2017, All Rights Reserved.", "id": "9177553", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": {"timeCrawl": "17:35:00", "uri": "709895556", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T17:34:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/aug/15/the-guardian-view-on-the-eu-customs-union-stay-dont-shadow", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The government's Brexit position papers are not focused on what's best for Britain but on trying to survive this autumn's Tory party conference\n\nIt is impossible not to be both cynical and angry about the government's \"future partnership paper\" on customs arrangements with the EU, which was published on Tuesday. Like the other papers on Brexit themes that are expected from Whitehall in the coming days, this one seems less concerned with its ostensible purpose, UK policy towards the EU after Brexit, than it is with the management of internal Conservative party divisions. The document is primarily an attempt to signal to MPs that Theresa May's government is back at its desks and back in business after its election debacle, and is now working together as one. It is not a serious attempt to set out a desirable relationship with the EU that stands up for Britain, its economy, its workforce and this country's values.\n\nThe document is being spun as a contribution towards the soon to be resumed Brexit negotiations between the UK and the EU. But that is largely pretence. Those discussions, which aim to reach some agreements in October, are not about future customs arrangements. They are strictly focused on the rights of EU and UK citizens in one another's jurisdictions after Brexit, on the Irish land border and on the financial settlement between the UK and the EU. Even if the new document were remarkably interesting and enlightened - and it is neither - the issues with which it deals are for later in the process, as critics were quick to point out.\n\nMost of what it contains, and most of what the Brexit secretary, David Davis, said about it on Tuesday, is little more than flannel. The paper speculates about ways in which future customs arrangements could be made simple and frictionless - as they are at the moment. But the words are aspirational not concrete. Alternative approaches are rehearsed, yet the government does not say which of them it prefers. Terms like \"innovative facilitations\" and \"technology-based solutions\" abound. Mr Davis boasts in an interview about its \"constructive ambiguity\". Yet the paper never escapes from magical thinking.\n\nAt no point does it say what it should say: \"This is what matters to us.\" The paper contains no flesh-and-blood recognition that more than half of the UK's trade in goods is with EU countries, or that Brexit will affect millions of transactions in goods, their certification of origin and the supply chains of which they are integral parts. The closest it comes to reality is to float the possibility of the UK shadowing the EU's external border customs policies in UK-EU traded goods.\n\nIt does not go further because the obvious policy for British business and British workers is not to shadow the customs union but to remain within it. That, though, is too hot for the Tory party. To open up that issue in that way, even though it is the way that would best defend the UK economy and would involve no change in our trade rules, would set off a Tory civil war that might topple Mrs May. As a result we are witnessing another episode in the lamentable story that has cursed this country's relations with the EU whenever there has been a Tory government. This latest iteration shows that, in the end, Mrs May is more concerned about getting through the Tory party conference than she is about the future of British trade. The country should be truly indignant about that.\n\nThere is, nevertheless, a substantive policy announcement in the customs paper. This is the confirmation of the government's commitment to what used to be called transitional arrangements, now rebranded as an \"interim model\" of close association with the EU. Precisely what this will mean in practice is unclear, But it represents a political victory for the chancellor, Philip Hammond, in his efforts to save the government from the prime minister's insane readiness to take the UK over a March 2019 cliff edge with the EU rather than confront the Daily Mail. It means Mrs May's earlier claim that no deal with the EU is better than a bad deal is now in the dustbin of history. This is something to welcome in an otherwise confused document.\n\nIt is not enough. Instead of taking the bold decisions to change course over Brexit policy, and putting the economy first, ministers have again feebly put their party first. It therefore falls to the opposition parties and sensible Conservatives to work together in every way to defend the public interests that this government seems incapable of defending.", "id": {"timeCrawl": "12:46:00", "uri": "709765941", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:46:00Z", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "source": {"title": "The Sun", "uri": "thesun.co.uk", "id": "16"}, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/4247776/britain-threatens-eu-with-mountain-of-new-red-tape-tax-and-duties-for-their-businesses-if-they-fail-to-give-us-a-good-post-brexit-customs-deal/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Without a new agreement after we quit the bloc, ministers say they would be forced to treat trade with the EU the same as other non-EU countries\n\nBRITAIN is threatening to put in place new laws to slap extra VAT and customs fees onto EU products if Brussels refuses to sign a deal with us post Brexit.\n\nWithout a new agreement after we quit the bloc, ministers say they would be forced to treat trade with the EU the same as other non-EU countries.\n\nNew customs arrangements will have to come into play after BrexitIn a 16-page blueprint published today, the government said they are planning to bring in new laws to make sure we have our own VAT and customs system in place by March 2019 - in case a deal with the EU is not reached.\n\nA Customs Bill, to be brought in later this year, will bring the UK in line with EU trading laws.\n\nToday the Government said they would seek a customs arrangement with the bloc which would aim to stick to the existing rules for a limited time - while a long-term deal can be thrashed out.\n\nThe UK would intend to pursue new trade deals with other countries while this arrangement was in place - but they wouldn't come into effect until after the period ends.\n\nBut the documents warn that traders would have to be registered, submit forms, and hold licences to sell specific products, if this was not completed.\n\nAnd taxes would have to be paid on EU imports.\n\nMinisters have repeatedly said they want \"frictionless\" trade with the EU once we leave.\n\nThe documents say they want to boost trade relationships \"with old friends and new allies\", maintain high standards and protect businesses.\n\nBut Brussels leaders have slammed the plans as \"a fantasy\".\n\nThe European Parliament's Brexit negotiator said that to be \"in and out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders'\" was impossible.\n\nHe also stressed the need to sort out citizens rights and the divorce bill first.\n\nAnd the man in charge of the Brexit talks echoed his sentiment.\n\nMichel Barnier - who will meet with David Davis for a third round of talks at the end of the month - tweeted: \"The quicker UK & EU27 agree on citizens, settling accounts and Ireland, the quicker we can discuss customs & future relationship.\"\n\nToday Brexit Secretary David Davis admitted that Mr Barnier was losing patience with Britain over our exit bill.\n\nHe said the two sides were still \"having a long haggle over the money\" and the EU official was \"getting quite cross with us\".\n\nThere were suggestions the Government would be willing to pay around \u00a336billion but Mr Davis said the EU's demands were still too high.\n\nMr Davis - who once referred to the haggle as \"the row of the summer\" - said: \"It's the tenser part of negotiations. It's going to be quite tough, but we'll sort it out.\"", "id": "9278101", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Britain threatens EU with mountain of new red tape and tax if they fail to give {"timeCrawl": "14:27:00", "uri": "709812095", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:27:00Z", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "source": {"title": "msn.com", "uri": "msn.com", "id": "152"}, "url": "http://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/uknews/david-daviss-customs-union-plan-is-fantasy-says-european-parliaments-brexit-spokesman/ar-AAq8Qsz", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "UK plans to enter into a customs partnership with the EU after 2019 have been dismissed as \"fantasy\" by the European Parliament's Brexit coordinator.\n\nFormer Belgian Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt made the comments just hours after the Brexit Secretary David Davis revealed the UK could seek a \"customs partnership\" with the EU.\n\nThat plan would mean no border checks on goods traveling between the UK and the continent.\n\nThe Government admitted such a system is \"innovative and untested\" and would \"take time to implement\".\n\nThe plan would also see businesses having to pay the highest tariff rate available and then claiming money back - a system which adds yet another layer of bureaucracy on exporters.\n\nVerhofstadt - responsible for the European Parliament's Brexit approach - took to Twitter to criticise the plan.\n\nTo be in & out of the Customs Union & \"invisible borders\" is a fantasy. First need to secure citizens rights & a financial settlement -- Guy Verhofstadt (@GuyVerhofstadt)\n\nAugust 15, 2017\n\nThe customs partnership is one of two proposals put forward by Davis to help deliver the \"freest and most frictionless trade possible between the UK and the EU.\"\n\nThis arrangement, which would see the UK \"mirror\" EU tariffs on goods coming into Britain, involves an increase of red tape for businesses.\n\nCompanies selling goods into Britain would have to pay which ever tariff is higher out of the UK and EU rate, and then claim any money back they are owed at a later date.\n\nThe report says: \"Businesses in supply chains would need to be able to track goods or pass the ability to claim a repayment along their supply chain in order to benefit.\"\n\nSlideshow - Politicians: Then and now (GES Photos)\n\nThe other plan is for a \"highly streamlined\" arrangement, which would make use of new technologies to speed up the processing of goods arriving and leaving the UK.\n\nThe Government admits that this approach - which would see a customs border - would lead to \"an increase in administration compared to being in the customs union.\"\n\nThe Government also confirmed the UK would seek to stay in a customs union with the EU after March 2019, which would stop Britain from implementing free trade deals with other countries.\n\nSpeaking on BBC Radio 4 this morning, Davis said this interim arrangement could last two years.\n\nAnnouncing the 'Future Customs Arrangements' document, Davis said: \"The approaches we are setting out today will benefit both the EU and UK and avoid a cliff-edge for businesses and individuals on both sides.\n\n\"The way we approach the movement of goods across our border will be a critical building block for our independent trade policy.\n\n\"An interim period would mean businesses only need to adjust once to the new regime and would allow for a smooth and orderly transition.\n\n\"The UK is the EU's biggest trading partner so it is in the interest of both sides that we reach an agreement on our future relationship.\n\n\"The UK starts from a strong position and we are confident we can deliver a They should commit to staying in single market and CU, period.\"\n\nStephen Gethins MP, the SNP's Europe spokesman, earlier told BBC Radio Scotland's Good Morning Scotland programme: \"What we're calling for is for continued membership of the single market and the customs union.\n\n\"What the UK seems to want here at the moment is to have its cake and eat it.\n\n\"I think what we're seeing... is just how important the single market and customs union are to jobs and to the economy, to everybody in Scotland and across the UK as well.\n\n\"Let's not forget that these plans haven't yet gone to Parliament for scrutiny, they've snuck them out over the summer recess and they've not yet met up with our European negotiators, because don't forget that once the UK leaves the EU, the UK is not part of the club and they're not looking out for the UK's interests, they're looking out for the EU 27's interests.\"\n\nMs Sturgeon later told BBC Scotland: \"You've got the UK Government appearing to say that they don't want to say in 'the' customs union, but they want to stay in 'a' customs union, which would be pretty much identical to the European customs union that we're in already. It's nonsensical and ridiculous.\n\n\"I think it increasingly makes the UK Government look like a bit of a laughing stock.\n\n\"I wish we weren't leaving the EU, but if the UK is leaving the EU then the common sense thing to do is to stay in the single market and to stay in the customs union. Because that will mean we can continue to export goods and services and continue to travel freely like we can today.\"\n\nGreen MSP Ross Greer said: \"The UK Government's proposal, of a temporary customs union but refusing the authority of the Court of Justice which oversees the union, is contradictory to the point of being embarrassing.\n\n\"With these plans, the Tories are on the verge of {"timeCrawl": "19:17:00", "uri": "709936561", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T09:45:00Z", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "source": {"title": "fruitnet.com", "uri": "fruitnet.com", "id": "4368"}, "url": "http://www.fruitnet.com/fpj/article/173102/logistics-industry-outlines-brexit-asks", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The logistics industry must be at the forefront of Brexit negotiations on trade and customs arrangements, the industry trade body has said.\n\nThe Freight Trade Association (FTA) was responding to a new government report published today (15 August) that states the UK could ask Brussels to establish a \"temporary customs union\" after it leaves the EU.\n\nDuring this period, the UK would also expect to be able to negotiate its own international trade deals, something which cannot be done as an EU customs union member. Once this time expires, the government will hope to establish either a \"highly streamlined\" border with the EU or a new \"partnership\" with no customs border at all.\n\nThe FTA has hailed the report as a step in the right direction, but said it has compiled its own agenda that would help freight businesses and distributors continue trading during and after Brexit.\n\nThe body's Brexit recommendations include:\n\n- Customs systems and procedures capable of handling up to 300 million additional annual declarations\n\n- Learning curve - time to adapt to new systems and customs declarations for UK-EU trade\n\n- Equivalent procedures in all other European customs administrations to avoid intra-EU border delays\n\n- Avoid vehicle checks at ports and airports where there is no time and no room - advance declarations and clearance systems can eliminate the need for checks\n\n- No cliff-edge in trade procedures - businesses will require transitional arrangements to ensure international trade can continue, especially if negotiations break down at short notice and the UK exits the customs union without a deal\n\n\"The government has recognised that it cannot drive the British economy off the cliff edge of Brexit,\" said FTA deputy chief executive James Hookham. \"FTA is keen to play its part in helping to develop efficient customs procedures post-Brexit, which will keep trade flowing freely, and urges the government to include representatives of the sector, with specialist knowledge, at the negotiating table to help reach the best possible deal for Britain.\"\n\nThe logistics industry has \"clearly identified its needs\" if trade is to continue in a frictionless manner with the EU and the rest of the world, Hookham continued, adding that \"the government owes it to British trade and industry to work with us to ensure that these arrangements can be introduced as part of the final Brexit deal.\"\n\n\"No trade deal will succeed unless freight and logistics requirements have been factored into any discussions between the EU and the UK,\" he added.", "id": "9343418", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Logistics industry outlines {"timeCrawl": "12:53:00", "uri": "709768270", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:53:00Z", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "source": {"title": "english.sina.com", "uri": "english.sina.com", "id": "2369"}, "url": "http://english.sina.com/news/2017-08-15/detail-ifyixcaw5040412.shtml", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON, Aug. 15 (Xinhua) -- Britain on Tuesday published a position paper in a bid to negotiate a \"temporary customs union\" arrangement with the European Union (EU) for an interim period after Brexit to avoid chaos in cross-border trade.\n\nBritain is seeking to strike the EU deal to retain the main benefits of the customs union for years after it has left the regional bloc, said the position paper.\n\nThe official document, the first in a series of \"future partnership papers\" to reveal the British government's strategy on the post-Brexit arrangement, was published as part of London's efforts to counter criticism from Brussels about its approach to the Brexit talks.\n\nEU officials said in July that it was hard to make a progress in the Brexit talks because Britain had no position at all on many issues.\n\nBritain hopes to keep the temporary arrangement in place until a final trade agreement with the EU takes effect, according to the paper.\n\nThe British proposal, if accepted by Brussels, will allow the transit of goods across borders to continue as now. After Brexit, there will be no need for companies to fill in additional paperwork, ensuring that goods move smoothly across the border with the rest of the EU countries.\n\nIn 2016, Britain imports and exports from the EU totalled 553 billion pounds (some 718 billion U.S. dollars).\n\nExhibition held in NE China to mark 72nd anniv. of Japan's WWII surrender\n\nPlane sprays nutrient solution over {"timeCrawl": "21:52:00", "uri": "709459814", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:52:00Z", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "source": {"title": "The Scotsman", "uri": "scotsman.com", "id": "1205"}, "url": "http://www.scotsman.com/news/uk/may-pushes-for-interim-customs-deal-to-prevent-brexit-chaos-1-4532056", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Theresa May will press for Britain to enter into a temporary customs deal with the European Union in 2019 to avoid chaos on the day after Brexit.\n\nThe government will today announce the plan as it begins to flesh out its negotiating stance in talks over Britain's future relationship with the bloc.\n\nMinisters have been warned that the imposition of customs checks at ports risks economic damage, huge delays and even lengthy motorway queues.\n\nTo avoid that prospect, ministers are proposing an \"interim period\" of \"close association\" between the UK and the EU customs union under which goods can be bought and sold tariff-free.\n\nOne possible approach, they say, would be to operate a temporary UK-EU customs union.\n\nDuring this period, the government would attempt to hammer out new trade deals with major trading partners, including forging a new relationship with the EU.\n\nThe government believes it can broker a \"streamlined\" deal with the bloc, building on the existing lack of tariffs within the union.\n\nThe proposal will be spelt out in the first of several government papers published in coming weeks which will set out Mrs May's approach to Brexit.\n\nMinisters argue that the move would give businesses more time to prepare for the eventual new customs regime.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the European Union, headed by Brexit Secretary David Davis, said its goal is \"to secure as frictionless trade as possible with the EU alongside the ability to forge trade deals around the world\".\n\nIt said the government wanted to demonstrate Britain's \"desire to ensure our exit from the EU is smooth, orderly and successful\".\n\nThe proposal strikes a different note from the joint declaration by Chancellor Philip Hammond and Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary, at the weekend that the UK will be \"outside the customs union\" during the transition as it will become a 'third country' not party to the EU treaties\". The plan could run into resistance in Brussels where negotiators could question why Britain should enjoy the benefits of the customs union while standing outside it.\n\nJosh Hardie, the CBI's deputy director-general, said: \"It is encouraging to see these papers propose a time-limited interim period and a customs system that is as barrier-free as possible.\n\n\"We at the CBI have always been clear that new ideas on crucial issues like this should be brought to the table quickly.\"\n\nSir Vince Cable, the Liberal Democrat leader, said: \"The only way to guarantee 'free and frictionless' trade with the EU is to stay in the customs union and single market.\n\n\"Anything else risks creating more red tape for business, longer queues at our borders and higher prices for consumers.\"\n\nThe Labour MP Chris Leslie, of the Open Britain campaign group, accused ministers of \"wishful thinking\".\n\nHe said: \"It looks like the new unified position in the Cabinet is to return the Government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it.\n\n\"Ministers claim we can leave the Customs Union and yet still achieve 'the most frictionless customs agreement anywhere in the world', but with absolutely no detail about how such a miraculous new system will be achieved.\"\n\nAdam Marshall, director general of the British Chambers of Commerce, said most businesses were more concerned about future customs arrangements with the EU than future trade deals.\n\nHe added: \"At this stage, it is critically important to keep a number of different options open in order to achieve this goal.\n\n\"While we await the detail of the government's customs position paper, and the reactions of EU negotiators, business is clear that a smooth transition to new arrangements is needed, and multiple adjustment costs must be avoided.\n\n\"In the long term, we should aim to avoid imports and exports being subjected to two sets of customs checks, and to ensuring the smoothest possible future trade relationship between the UK and EU.\"\n\nA position paper on the fraught issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic will published tomorrow, ahead of the third round of Brexit negotiations in Brussels at the end of the month.", "id": "9167527", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "May pushes for interim customs deal to prevent {"timeCrawl": "22:28:00", "uri": "709474100", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T22:28:00Z", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "source": {"title": "Bloomberg Business", "uri": "bloomberg.com", "id": "1749"}, "url": "https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-14/u-k-seeks-interim-customs-union-with-eu-to-smooth-brexit-path", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Proposal set out as part of series of Brexit position papers Next round of talks scheduled in Brussels starting Aug. 28\n\nThe U.K. government said it wants to maintain tariff-free, bureaucracy-light trade with the European Union for a period after Brexit and perhaps permanently, a proposal likely to raise eyebrows on the continent but which was cheered by British businesses.\n\nAhead of the publication Tuesday of the first of a series of new papers aimed at fleshing out its ambitions for future relations with the EU, Britain said it will seek to negotiate a \"close association\" with the bloc's customs union for an unspecified amount of time after it leaves in March 2019.\n\nIndustry lobby groups expressed relief having repeatedly warned against the potential for duties, border controls and regulatory uncertainty on commerce with the U.K.'s biggest market the day after Brexit.\n\nThe road map, though, will likely run into opposition from the EU, given the U.K.'s suggestion it be allowed to line up trade accords with other countries during the interim period, something remaining fully inside the customs union would prevent. The EU has repeatedly warned the U.K. against cherry picking the advantages of membership and that it won't be able to enjoy frictionless trade outside its ranks.\n\nRead more about Britain's options for a trade deal with the EU\n\nWhile the bloc's 27 other governments have said they are open to a post-Brexit implementation phase, they first want to resolve matters such as citizens' rights and a financial settlement. Divorce talks are set to resume in Brussels on Aug. 28 and the EU's lead negotiator, Michel Barnier, has complained of a lack of progress in the first two rounds.\n\nThe U.K. is showing more of its hand after a summer in which members of Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet forged a consensus around supporting a transitional period after Brexit, although there are differences over how long it should run. Tuesday's blueprint will be seen as a victory for Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond who has advocated as smooth a departure as possible from the EU.\n\nBritain's goal \"is to secure as frictionless trade as possible with the EU alongside the ability to forge trade deals around the world, and avoiding a hard border with Ireland,\" Brexit Secretary David Davis's department said in a statement. It also wants to \"negotiate bold new trade relationships around the world.\"\n\nThe Brexit department said the interim period it imagines would enable both sides of the English Channel to establish future customs arrangements to ease border crossings. The U.K.'s public-spending watchdog warned last month of a \"horror show\" if new systems were not in place by the time of Brexit.\n\nFailure to maintain something akin to the status quo could prove costly for the British. The current arrangement saves U.K. exporters from paying tariffs on goods sold to the EU. Countries outside the region and lacking a free-trade accord with it pay about 10 percent on shipments of cars alone.\n\nPotentially more expensive are non-tariff barriers. Customs checks at a U.K.-EU border such as proving the origin of goods could cost 1 billion pounds ($1.3 billion) a year and snarl traffic in both directions, according to a July report by Oxera, an economic consultancy.\n\nThe customs office calculates that in two years' time there will be 255 million declarations per year based on current levels of trade with the EU, up from 55 million now. Carmakers worry such bureaucracies would hurt their ability to ship vehicles and source inputs in a timely fashion, while retailers risk watching goods perish at borders.\n\n\"Business wants to see as frictionless a customs system as possible,\" Confederation of British Industry Deputy Director-General Josh Hardie said in a statement. \"All efforts should be made to deliver a single-step transition, so that businesses don't have to adapt twice.\"\n\nTheCityUK, which represents the finance sector, said the government must conduct \"urgent\" talks to support services, which make up a larger share of the U.K. economy.\n\nOpen Britain, a group that lobbies for close ties with the EU, accused May's government of \"having our cake and eating it.\"\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the government remain intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union,\" said Chris Leslie, a lawmaker in the opposition Labour Party.\n\nBarnier warned in July that it was \"not possible\" for Britain to enjoy as easy trade with the EU as it does now, pointing to the need to comply with tax returns and test animal products among other obstacles.\n\nA customs union-like relationship would help clear up the matter of how to police the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said earlier this month that a new customs union should be designed to avoid the need for controls on the 310-mile (500-kilometer) frontier which forms the EU's only land link with the U.K.\n\nThe Irish issue will be detailed more fully by the British on Wednesday when they publish another paper that will express a commitment to keeping a \"seamless and frictionless\" border on the island.\n\nThe U.K. said ultimately it would like to see as few hurdles to commerce as possible between it and the EU. That could mean designing \"highly streamlined customs arrangements\" or aligning approaches to \"negate the need for\" any border, it said.", "id": "9172158", "details": {"liCnt": 11}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "17:00:00", "uri": "709880427", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T17:00:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"title": "irishmirror", "uri": "irishmirror.ie", "id": "2371"}, "url": "http://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/politics/brexit-secretary-reveals-delays-divorce-10992557", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The EU's chief negotiator Michel Bernier is said to be getting 'quite cross'\n\nGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis has said the UK will not reach an agreement with the EU for its so-called divorce bill by the October deadline.\n\nThe EU wants an agreement to be struck on the mooted \u20ac60 billion exit bill before negotiations move on to Britain's future relationship with the bloc - including the question of the Irish border.\n\nThe UK also published proposals for a two-year customs union transitional period to take effect once Brexit happens in March 2019, that would be identical to the current arrangements with the EU.\n\nBut in a move likely to put him on a collision course with Brussels, Mr Davis insisted the divorce bill would not be finalised by the October target.\n\nHe said: \"We're going to talk it through very, very carefully, so at this stage we're not going to commit, there won't be a number by October or November, whenever it is.\"\n\nMr Davis wants an interim customs union as a grace period for businesses to adapt to the new arrangements that could last until the next UK election in 2022.\n\nBut he admitted that the EU's chief negotiator Michel Bernier is getting \"quite cross\" that the UK has not put forward proposals for the exit bill.\n\nThe European Commission has said that while the proposals for an interim customs union were welcome and would be examined, no talks on Britain's future relationship with the EU will take place until the divorce bill is settled.\n\nMr Davis believes Britain should be allowed to negotiate new trade deals while in the interim customs union - something they are prevented from doing as an EU member.\n\nBut Brussels has so far refused to start trade talks until broad agreement is reached on three key issues.\n\nThey include Britain's financial settlement with Europe, the issue of expatriate rights, and the question of the Irish border.\n\nAnd Michel Bernier indicated he would be in no rush to discuss an interim customs deal until those issues are tackled.\n\nHe tweeted: \"The quicker #UK & EU27 agree on citizens, settling accounts and #Ireland, the quicker we can discuss customs & future relationship.\"\n\nSinn Fein Brexit spokesman David Cullinane TD said the UK's proposals had \"an air of unreality\" to them, and called on the Irish Government stall talks if necessary.\n\nHe said: \"The paper released today shows that the Conservative party has at least finally acknowledged that a full and complete break from the customs union and the single market is not possible by March 2019.\n\n\"Britain has neither the physical infrastructure nor legal framework in place. The proposals today, however, have an air of unreality to them.\n\n\"The whole purpose of any interim agreement is to allow breathing space to work out a post-Brexit trade deal as it is simply not possible to so that before March 2019.\n\n\"Those constraints apply equally to the drafting of a bespoke customs deal as proposed by the British government today.\"\n\nThe UK's proposal to extend article 50 requires the agreement of all 27 states, including the Irish government.\n\nDeputy Cullinane said: \"The Irish government should stand up for the national interest and should only agree to an extension that is in our interests, that is, the economy, trade, the rights of citizens, and the protection of the Good Friday Agreement, in all of its aspects.\"\n\nRead More Today's top stories", titled 'Future customs arrangements: A future partnership paper', states that the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland is 'the UK's only land border.'\n\nIn fact, a 1.2km international boundary separates the British overseas territory of Gibraltar and Spain.\n\nOverlooking this detail, the Brexit paper says: 'The border between Northern Ireland and Ireland is the UK's only land border.\n\n'We must avoid a return to a hard border, and trade and everyday movements across the land border must be protected as part of the UK-EU deal.'\n\nThe Rock has proved to be an issue during Brexit negotiations, with an EU paper in March suggesting that Brexit deals would not apply to Gibraltar without the agreement of Spain.\n\nThis sparked a war or words between politicians, with Michael Howard going so far as to suggest that Theresa May might go to war with Spain over the issue.\n\nThe Brexit document, released today, outlines the UK's plans for future trade deals with the European Union and the rest of the world following Britain's exit from the bloc.\n\nIt calls for a highly streamlined customs arrangement' between the UK and the EU with customs arrangements that are 'as frictionless as possible.'\n\nMOST POPULAR STORIES ON YAHOO UK:\n\nBritish banker accidentally flies to Las Vegas instead of Stansted after boarding the wrong flight\n\nPaedophile is shot dead and {"timeCrawl": "23:32:00", "uri": "709493751", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:32:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"title": "TheJournal.ie", "uri": "thejournal.ie", "id": "979"}, "url": "http://www.thejournal.ie/brexit-uk-customs-union-3546257-Aug2017/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Image: Stefan Rousseau via PA Images Image: Stefan Rousseau via PA Images\n\nTHE UK GOVERNMENT has officially announced that it wants to leave the customs union in order to negotiate a new deal with the EU.\n\nBritain's Brexit negotiator David Davis and chancellor Philip Hammond have said previously that the UK would leave the customs union, but this is the first official evidence of their intention.\n\nBut there is still a lot of confusion around what would replace it. In the UK government's statement which outlines their intention, it lists two possible options: a \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\", or a \"new customs partnership\" with the EU.\n\nThe customs union allows EU countries to trade more freely with one another, as it imposes the same regulations and duties levied on imported goods.\n\nA change to this would impact greatly on businesses in the UK and the EU that do business with one another on a regular basis. In order to prepare businesses in Europe for the change, the UK is suggesting that an interim strategy be put in place.\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May could strengthen trade relations with the US if the UK were to leave the customs union. Source: PA Images\n\nThe UK have emphasised in the announcement that the new, \"ambitious\" deal would allow the \"freest and most frictionless possible trade in goods\" between the UK and the EU, although failed to mention any specifics of what it specifically wants.\n\n\"The UK is proposing two different ways that would best meet these goals,\" the UK government's statement said, listing its (publicly available) suggestions as:\n\n- A highly streamlined customs arrangement in which the UK would manage a new customs border with the EU, streamlining and simplifying requirements to the fullest extent possible through negotiated and unilateral facilitations which reduce and remove barriers to trade, or\n\n- A new customs partnership with the EU, based on alignment of our customs approaches, which would negate the need for a customs border between the UK and the EU.\n\nBut Guy Verhofstadt, the EU's Brexit negotiator said before that \"if you want the advantages of a single market and customs union, you have to take the obligations\".\n\nThose obligations include trading with countries outside the EU in the same way as other member states do - which is the exact restriction the UK is trying to avoid.\n\nJean Claude-Juncker, the President of the European Commission, also told Prime Minister Theresa May that \"Brexit cannot be a success\" at a dinner at Downing Street in April, adding that Britain will not even be in the customs union.\n\nAn example of the anti-Brexit sentiment. Source: Alberto Pezzali via PA Images\n\nWhat does this mean for Ireland?\n\n\"It's too early to say, but it's pretty bad news for us that they won't stay in the customs union,\" Fianna F\u00e1il's Brexit spokesperson Stephen Donnelly told TheJournal.ie previously.\n\nHe said that any kind of 'streamlined' border, as suggested by the UK in the above statement, could easily turn into a hard border.\n\nIf we have to check goods in discreet warehouses on the side of the road, that sounds good.\n\nBut if we're going to have to start checking IDs, checking passports, then there's a queue, and behind the official is men and women with guns... then we're back to a border.\n\nTomorrow, the UK government will set out its solutions for the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic, ahead of the third round of Brexit negotiations at the end of the month.\n\n- With reporting from Business Insider.\n\nRead: What's a 'hard' and 'soft' Brexit, and which one are we likely to get? {"timeCrawl": "11:38:00", "uri": "709193999", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:38:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"title": "betting.betfair.com", "uri": "betting.betfair.com", "id": "652"}, "url": "https://betting.betfair.com/politics/brexit/brexit-latest-uk-will-leave-trade-agreement-during-transitional-period-140817-699.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "\"We will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation,\"\n\nChancellor Philip Hammond has \"come to heel\" after appearing to switch sides in the ongoing debate of how Britain will leave the EU.\n\nAnti-EU Conservatives have said Hammond has \"caved in\" after he signed an article saying the UK will leave the customs union during any transitional period of Brexit, the Independent reports.\n\nWritten along with long-time Eurosceptic and Secretary of State for International Trade Liam Fox, the article published in the Sunday Telegraph states: \"We will leave the customs union and be free to negotiate the best trade deals around the world as an independent, open, trading nation.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the single market and outside the customs union and will be a 'third-country' not party to EU treaties.\"\n\nTheir united front will be welcomed by pro-Leave Conservatives who have supported Britain making a clear break from the union as soon as possible. However, whether the EU will agree to this until after Brexit is finalised is unknown as it could be seen as acting against the bloc's agreement.\n\nIt is a surprising turn for the Chancellor, as he argued that delaying the UK's departure from the customs union would lessen the economic shock. He and Fox have also been at loggerheads during many of the Brexit talks, with the Secretary of State for International Trade favouring a 'hard Brexit'.\n\nHowever, the pair has faced criticism over the article from both hardline Brexiteers and pro-Remainers who argue the decision is more about party unity than finding the best Brexit deal.\n\nThere is also still the matter of the 'divorce bill' to sort that has so far been a sticking point for the Conservative party.\n\nReports suggest that the Prime Minister Theresa May may be willing to pay the sum, which is estimated to be around \u20ac40 billion if it would allow the UK to negotiate a trade deal with the union.\n\nHowever, other leading Conservatives, such as Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, have spoken out against the 'fine', saying the UK owes nothing.\n\nThese reports come as the Prime Minister returns to Downing Street from her summer break. She is expected to restart negotiations with the EU soon, though it's unclear how much progress has been made up to now.\n\nThe change of heart from the Chancellor has also led to others in Parliament doubting whether Hammond can prioritise the UK's best financial interests.\n\nLeader of the Liberal Democrats Vince Cable said the u-turn from the Chancellor showed that he was not \"fighting off the more extreme Brexiteers\". He added that Hammond was supposed to be \"looking for a compromise to keep Britain within the customs union and single market as long as possible\".\n\nBrexit negotiations are likely to see the So there are a lot of things there.\"\n\nAsked whether Britain would have to pay to stay in the customs union, he said: \"Well, I don't think ... well, what happens in that sort of interim period you will have to leave me to negotiate, I'm afraid, how we do it, but the aim is to bring to an end these huge \u00a310 billion-a-year payments, bring that to an end now.\n\n\"We are still haggling with them over what we may owe them in the short term but we are going to bring the overall thing to an end. This is something that is in both sides' interest.\"\n\nSecuring future trade deals outside the EU could also be on the cards under the new plans, Mr Davis said.\n\nHe told Today: \"There's a legal position here. The reason we can't sign now is because of something called the duty of sincere cooperation, it's written into the treaty, and it's not related to the customs union, it's related to the overall treaty.\n\n\"Once in 2019 when we leave, that legal duty goes away. Now we will still be responsible around it but our view is there is no legal basis for saying we can't do it, we are talking about it to other countries, we are just not signing.\"\n\nThe proposals After the victory of (President) Macron in France, that terror is reduced. {"timeCrawl": "05:03:00", "uri": "709032931", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T05:03:00Z", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "source": {"title": "The Scotsman", "uri": "scotsman.com", "id": "1205"}, "url": "http://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/david-davis-vents-frustration-at-cabinet-during-festival-joust-1-4531087", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Brexit Secretary David Davis has voiced frustration at the changing position of Cabinet colleagues on Britain's exit from the European Union - and revealed that a newspaper article written jointly by the Chancellor and the Trade Secretary was not \"cleared\" with him.\n\nThe article by Philip Hammond and Liam Fox, published in the Sunday Telegraph, pledged that the post-Brexit transition period would be \"time-limited\". But Mr Davis said the transition could vary between sectors and would be \"driven by practicalities\" rather than ideology or timing.\n\nThe Brexit Secretary was speaking in Edinburgh when he appeared as the first guest at Alex Salmond's Edinburgh Festival Fringe show yesterday.\n\nThe ex-SNP leader alluded to the article in yesterday's Sunday Telegraph in which Mr Hammond and Mr Fox sought to draw a line under months of Cabinet feuding over Brexit.\n\n\"They're venting this united front about what to do about the transition period - is that the sort of thing they clear with you as Brexit Secretary?\" Mr Salmond asked.\n\nMr Davis replied: \"Not as I remember, no.\" The Brexit Secretary said that he had cautioned against using phrases like \"transition\" period following the formal departure from the EU because \"that means something different to absolutely everyone\" involved in the process.\n\n\"Including members of the Cabinet?\" Mr Salmond interjected.\n\nMr Davis replied: \"Sometimes on different days.\"\n\nAsked if the Cabinet was \" fully united\" on Brexit, Mr Davis gave a long pause, prompting laughter from the Edinburgh crowd.\n\n\"Well we're all captives - the answer is yes,\" he responded to more laughter.\n\nEU chief negotiator Michel Barnier had initially hinted that the post-Brexit transition period could last up to a decade, Mr Davis also revealed, after the formal \"divorce\" is finalised in March 2019.\n\nMr Davis insisted this was \"never going to fly\" but made it clear the timing of the implementation would be driven by practicalities.\n\n\"It will differ with different things,\" he insisted.\n\n\"Much of this will be driven not by ideology, but by practicalities - when you get the customs system in place, what you do about financial services and so on.\n\n\"That's why the implementation period comes into play with different people in different ways.\"\n\nMinisters are prioritising the customs union because this will need reciprocal work in other European countries, but other areas like financial services will need a lengthier period \"to make any adjustments\".\n\nMr Davis added: \"It may well vary by sector. What will help the financial sector of Edinburgh? What will make sure it doesn't take any hits?\"\n\nPrime Minister Theresa May will have been hoping the intervention of Mr Hammond and Dr Fox would ease tensions in the Tory ranks amid divisions over Brexit and speculation of a possible leadership challenge when MPs return in September.\n\nMr Hammond, who favours a \"softer\" pro-business Brexit, and Dr Fox, a hardline Brexiteer, agreed that any transition would be \"time-limited\" and that Brexit would mean the UK pulling out of both the EU single market and the customs union.\n\n\"We believe a time-limited interim period will be important to further our national interest and give business greater certainty - but it cannot be indefinite; it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU,\" they wrote.\n\n\"We are both clear that during this {"timeCrawl": "06:58:00", "uri": "709623368", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:27:00Z", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "source": {"title": "expressnewsline.com", "uri": "expressnewsline.com", "id": "18917"}, "url": "http://expressnewsline.com/2017/08/15/united-kingdom-says-it-may-seek-temporary-customs-union.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "BRITAIN will crash out of the the customs union immediately after Brexit, two leading Cabinet ministers have declared, saying they will not commit to a transitional period that will lead to the the United Kingdom staying in the EU by the \"back door\". Its proposals on a future customs arrangement are set out in one of several position papers meant to flesh out the government's Brexit vision and show a united stance over the future relationship after rifts emerged among ministers.\n\nHowever, continuing membership would stop Britain being able to make bilateral trade deals with non-EU countries.\n\nThe Brexit Secretary will on Tuesday publish a paper in which he agrees not to implement any new free trade deals until after an \"interim\" transition period.\n\n\"So it's encouraging to see that these papers propose a time-limited interim period and a customs system that is as barrier-free as possible\".\n\nMPs supporting a soft Brexit strategy were critical of the plans. That would provide certainty for businesses, the government said, aiming to address a main concern of companies who fear the introduction of customs checks will cause expensive delays.\n\n\"Instead, the cabinet remain split on key issues and can not decide between two very different but equally unachievable options\".\n\nBut it will also seek the right to negotiate other trade deals, a possible sticking point in the talks.\n\nLabour MP Chris Leslie, a leading supporter of the Open Britain cross-party campaign group, said the Cabinet's \"new unified position is to return the government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it\".\n\nThe proposals for new customs arrangements to allow the \"freest and most frictionless possible\" trade with the European Union are being outlined in the first of a series of \"future partnership papers\" from the government. \"The only way to retain genuinely free trade with Europe, and protect the millions of jobs created by it, is to But others hail it as a welcome step that helps clarify London's position for businesses across the continent.\n\nHere is a selection of quotes from officials in London, Edinburgh and Brussels.\n\n\"They set out arrangements that would allow UK businesses to continue to trade with their European partners in the future, while expanding their markets beyond the EU.\"\n\n:: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon: \"Seems UK gov is back to its daft 'have cake and eat it' approach to Brexit. They should commit to staying in single market and CU, period.\"\n\n:: Labour's shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer: \"These are incoherent and inadequate proposals designed to gloss over deep and continuing divisions within the Cabinet.\"\n\n:: Hilary Benn, Brexit Select Committee chairman: \"If ministers think staying in the customs union is right for the next two or three years, then why not do so for the long term? That would be the best way to offer much-needed certainty for businesses, jobs and UK trade.\"\n\n:: Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's chief Brexit co-ordinator: \"To be in and out of the customs union and 'invisible borders' is a fantasy. First need to secure citizens rights and a financial settlement.\"\n\n:: EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier: \"The quicker #UK & EU27 agree on citizens, settling accounts and #Ireland, the quicker we can discuss customs & future relationship.\"\n\n:: Nigel Farage, former UKIP leader: \"This is dither and delay. It shows a lack of decisive leadership and it lowers our standing in the world. ... This is not what we voted for - we voted to leave, not for transitional arrangements.\"\n\n:: Tory former minister Anna Soubry, a staunch Remainer who co-chairs the all-party parliamentary group on EU relations: \"Ministers appear to be moving in the right direction, but they need to go further.\n\n\"They should acknowledge that no new agreement with the EU can fully replace the benefits of customs union membership, as the EU and business has made clear.\n\n:: Pro-EU Labour MP Chuka Umunna said: \"They might promise frictionless trade, but they are offering a red tape bombshell for British business.\"\n\n:: Eurosceptic Tory MP Nigel Evans said: \"The ability to be able to negotiate our own trade deals during that transitional deal is vitally important, so full negotiations can take place rather than the scoping-out going on at the moment.\"\n\n:: George Osborne, the former chancellor-turned-newspaper editor, and frequent Government critic, tweeted an Evening Standard cartoon of David Davis eating a customs union cake, and said the cartoon \"captures the government's latest position on Brexit\".\n\n:: John McGrane, director of the British Irish Chamber of Commerce: \"The recognition of the need for an interim period to allow for the adoption of new systems and infrastructures will be welcomed by businesses ...\"\n\n\"It is important that this phase is as close to the status quo as possible with minimum disruption caused by tariff and non-tariff barriers.\"", "id": "9305444", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Fantasy or real deal? {"timeCrawl": "09:03:00", "uri": "709670413", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T09:03:00Z", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "source": {"title": "POLITICO", "uri": "politico.eu", "id": "19273"}, "url": "http://www.politico.eu/article/britain-wont-commit-to-brexit-bill-by-october-says-david-davis/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON -- The U.K. will not commit to a Brexit bill figure by the October EU summit, Brexit secretary David Davis said.\n\nSpeaking on the BBC's Today Program ahead of the publication of Britain's customs union plan, Davis said the EU had had a \"difficult time in the negotiation\" over its legal justification for Britain's so-called divorce bill. But he added that the negotiations were going \"incredibly well\" with the U.K.'s \"constructive ambiguity\" a deliberate negotiating tactic.\n\nChief negotiator Michel Barnier has said talks on future relations between the EU and the U.K., including a free-trade agreement, can't begin until EU leaders decide that \"sufficient progress\" has been made on separation issues such as the exit bill. EU leaders will make that assessment at a summit in October.\n\nDavis said Britain would meet any \"real international obligations.\"\n\n\"What we have been talking about is what they claim and what their legal basis is. They have had a difficult time in the negotiation on that, which is why they came back and said 'why don't you make your proposal.' We are going to go down that route and we are going to talk it through very very carefully. But at this stage we are not going to commit. There won't be a number by October or November, or whenever it is.\"\n\nHe would not be drawn on when a figure would be forthcoming.\n\nIn its proposals for a customs union transition period, published today, the government is putting forward a temporary customs union, distinct from but effectively identical to the current arrangements with the EU to give businesses certainty.\n\nDavis said that after Brexit in March 2019 the U.K. no longer had a legal duty -- as it currently does until EU membership -- not to negotiate and sign trade deals. So it would be free to pursue new trade deals during the transition. \"The reason we can't sign now is because of something called the duty of sincere cooperation,\" he said, \"That legal duty goes away [after Brexit].\"\n\nAnd he reiterated that the customs transition would be time limited. \"It's got to be done by the election [scheduled for 2022]. I would say the most likely is something like two years, maybe a bit shorter,\" Davis said.\n\nDavis also revealed that an \"international arbitration\" position paper, setting out Britain's Traders would need to be registered.\n\n\"Traders exporting to the EU would have to submit an exploration declaration, and certain goods may require an export licence\".\n\nTo be in & out of the Customs Union & \"invisible borders\" is a fantasy. First need to secure citizens rights & a financial settlement -- Guy Verhofstadt (@GuyVerhofstadt)\n\nAugust 15, 2017\n\nIt made clear that the \"Government is actively considering ways in which to mitigate the impacts of such a scenario.\n\n\"Other EU member states will also need to make contingency preparations to mitigate the risk of delays resulting from their own customs processes\".\n\nGuy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's chief negotiator, dismissed the plans, writing on Twitter: \"To be in & out of the Customs Union & \"invisible borders\" is a fantasy. First need to secure citizens rights & a financial settlement.\"\n\nOfficials declined to estimate on how long these new layers of red tape might delay goods at ports and airports.\n\nThe document, which only deals in trade in goods and not services, set out two options for a customs deal with the EU: a streamlined customs arrangement and a new customs partnership.\n\nThe streamlined arrangement would see Britain and the EU develop new technology to clear goods speedily through ports and treat the UK as part of the EU.\n\nBarnier on Brexit divorce bill: 'accounts must be settled' 01:45\n\nThe customs partnership would see the EU's customs rules mirrored by the UK so that \"all goods entering the EU via the UK have paid the correct EU duties.\n\n\"This would remove the need for the UK and the EU to introduce customs processes between us, so that goods moving between the UK and the EU would be treated as they are now for customs purposes\".\n\nHowever officials conceded that this could mean the UK is still subject to the European Court of Justice, although this is part of the negotiation with the EU.\n\nA new computer system - which will be compliant with the EU's customs rules - called the Customs Declaration Service will only be ready in January 2019 - two months before Britain leaves the EU.\n\nThe blueprint said delivering this project on time was a \"high priority project\".\n\nOfficials said if the system was not delivered on time then the older computer system - known as CHIEF - will be able to continue to process customs information.\n\nIt also moved to calm fears that Britain's NHS or environmental standards are at risk; last month there was a Cabinet row over whether US chlorine washed chicken will be allowed into the UK.\n\nThe document said: \"We will maintain our high level of standards and protect our public services.\n\n\"As we leave the EU, the Government will continue to maintain our high standards for consumers, employees, the environment and {"timeCrawl": "13:06:00", "uri": "709773993", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:06:00Z", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/uk-still-haggling-with-eu-over-financial-terms-says-david-davis-36033387.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/article36033382.ece/18184/AUTOCROP/h342/bpanews_f552885a-b122-448b-b313-b5d130bc177c_1\n\nDavid Davis has refused to rule out making payments to Brussels for temporary customs arrangements after leaving the EU.\n\nThe Brexit Secretary will publish proposals on Tuesday morning, outlining plans for a time-limited transition which would ensure businesses on both sides of the Channel only have to adapt once to the rule changes.\n\nIn a series of broadcast interviews, Mr Davis failed to rule out whether the UK would have to pay for the temporary customs deal, which he said would last \"something like two years\".\n\nHe also suggested the temporary arrangements could allow Britain to negotiate trade deals with other countries for when it leaves, as current rules bar members of the EU customs union from making their own deals outside the bloc.\n\nPressed on whether the UK would have to pay, he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"I am not going to do the negotiation on air.\n\n\"What we are not going to do, let's be clear, we are not going to continue the \u00a310 billion a year net contributions we currently have.\"\n\nAsked if money could be a part of the negotiations, he said: \"I didn't say that. Wait and see.\"\n\nMr Davis also told ITV's Good Morning Britain: \"We sell them, the Europeans, about 230 billion euro of goods and services a year.\n\n#Brexit Secretary David Davis speaks on temporarily keeping the custom arrangements the same after we leave the EU pic.twitter.com/UjYKt4wGTd -- Good Morning Britain (@GMB)\n\nAugust 15, 2017\n\n\"They sell us 290 billion euro. So there are a lot of things there.\"\n\nAsked whether Britain would have to pay to stay in the customs union, he said: \"Well, I don't think ... well, what happens in that sort of interim period you will have to leave me to negotiate, I'm afraid, how we do it, but the aim is to bring to an end these huge \u00a310 billion-a-year payments, bring that to an end now.\n\n\"We are still haggling with them over what we may owe them in the short term but we are going to bring the overall thing to an end. This is something that is in both sides' interest.\"\n\nSecuring future trade deals outside the EU could also be on the cards under the new plans, Mr Davis said.\n\nHe told Today: \"There's a legal position here. The reason we can't sign now is because of something called the duty of sincere cooperation, it's written into the treaty, and it's not related to the customs union, it's related to the overall treaty.\n\n\"Once in 2019 when we leave, that legal duty goes away. Now we will still be responsible around it but our view is there is no legal basis for saying we can't do it, we are talking about it to other countries, we are just not signing.\"\n\nThe proposals for new customs arrangements to allow trade with the EU are being outlined in the first of a series of \"future partnership papers\" being released by the Government.", "id": "9281488", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "UK 'still haggling' with EU over financial terms, says David Davis", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/article36033382.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/bpanews_f552885a-b122-448b-b313-b5d130bc177c_1", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1553, "date": "2017-08-15", "amb": false, "textEnd": 1568}], "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "concepts": [], "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "id": 99, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Signage", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Signage"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 108, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 139, "label": "dmoz/Society/Government", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Government"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 140, "label": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 147, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Customer Management", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Customer_Management"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 268, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business"}], "time": "13:06:00"}

paper, part of a series of documents to be released ahead of renewed Brexit negotiations, claims \"there are two broad approaches the U.K. could adopt\" - streamlining current arrangements or establishing a new customs partnership.\n\nThe U.K. is expected to leave the EU in 2019 as a result of a 2016 referendum which began the process of ending the country's 44-year membership of the bloc.\n\n\"A highly streamlined customs arrangement,\" is one option the British government seems more eager to propose to EU negotiators.\n\nLondon, in this choice, is aiming to \"continue some of the existing arrangements between the U.K. and the EU\".\n\nLeaving as few additional requirements on EU trade as possible and implementing technology-based solutions form part of the proposals to deliver \"as frictionless a customs border as possible\".\n\nHowever, the U.K. government said a new deal would be \"unprecedented as an approach and could be challenging to implement\".\n\nThe paper {"timeCrawl": "14:29:00", "uri": "709813053", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:22:00Z", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "source": {"title": "The Independent", "uri": "independent.co.uk", "id": "3441"}, "url": "http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/editorials/the-government-still-isnt-paying-attention-to-whats-most-important-and-immediate-about-brexit-a7894696.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "While ministers believe 'the money' is their trump card, the EU may have a bigger one: the clock\n\nIn setting out its long-term proposals for a customs deal with the EU, the UK Government has put the cart before the horse. Its plan for a two-year transitional deal allowing existing customs arrangements to continue is sensible, and will hopefully provide some reassurance for an increasingly anxious business community. This follows a welcome intervention by the Chancellor Philip Hammond to head off the \"clean break\" favoured by hardline Brexiteers, which would have created a damaging \"cliff edge\" for business in 2019.\n\nHowever, the Government's document seems to be designed more for domestic political consumption - and the need to show a semblance of Cabinet unity after ministers promoted their conflicting ideas - than the reality of the difficult negotiations with the EU. There are two options for a UK-EU customs regime after the \"interim period\": a streamlined system using technology to limit bureaucracy, and a more ambitious partnership in which both parties would enforce each other's rules, which the Government admits is \"untested\" as it does not exist anywhere in the world.\n\nThese ideas are an opening bid, a wish list in tune with Boris Johnson's \"have our cake and eat it\" approach, under which the UK expects to walk out of the EU club and yet be allowed to continue to enjoy its benefits. When asked what the UK would give the EU in return, the Brexit Secretary David Davis reverted to the \"German cars\" argument, pointing out that the EU sells more to the UK than vice versa.\n\nHe will have to do better than that. It is obvious that the 27 EU countries will not allow the UK a pain-free exit; they will use Brexit to discourage other states from trying to cherry-pick their membership terms. Britain will have to pay a price for the close trading links it wants to keep, while naively expecting the EU to allow it to strike rival trade deals with non-EU nations.\n\nBrexit Secretary: UK wants temporary EU customs deal\n\nRather than gazing at the horizon, the Government should be prioritising the more pressing issues on which the EU is demanding progress before it will discuss a long-term deal: citizens' rights, the UK's divorce payment and the Irish border. Ministers will address the Irish question on Wednesday but, ominously, Mr Davis warned that the UK would not provide \"a number\" for the financial settlement by October or November. The Government should show more flexibility on this sensitive issue but is doing little to prepare the ground.\n\nWhile ministers believe \"the money\" is their trump card, the EU may have a bigger one - the clock. Time is running out for an agreement, which will need to be struck by the autumn of 2018 to allow it to be approved by EU institutions by March 2019.\n\nBuried in the Government's document is the announcement that its Customs Bill will give it powers to operate standalone customs, VAT and excise systems in case there is no deal with the EU. While this is not ministers' preferred outcome, the extra bureaucracy and costs it would involve should encourage the Government to strain every sinew to secure what Theresa May has called \"a deep and special partnership\" with the EU.\n\nAvoiding the worst outcome of all - no deal - will require much more clarity from the Government, and quickly. Ministers will have to accept some painful compromises; the sooner they admit that, and stop dreaming about a one-sided agreement in which the EU allows the UK \"frictionless trade\" at no cost, the Britain will look to negotiate bold new trade relationships around the world.\"\n\nIt did not say how long the interim arrangement would last. Businesses have put investment plans on hold while they wait for greater clarity about what Brexit means.\n\nThe CBI, which represents 190,000 businesses, said it welcomed the government's proposals.\n\n\"But the clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible,\" it said in a statement.\n\nManufacturing makes up 45% of U.K. exports and directly employs 2.7 million people. The document also says this option would involve \"technology-based solutions\" adopted for businesses to comply with customs procedures.\n\nOption two \"A new customs partnership\"\n\nThe other option outlined in the proposal is for a new customs partnership with the EU in which the UK would \"align its approach to the customs border in a way that removes the need for a UK-EU customs border\". One potential approach would involve the UK mirroring the EU's requirements for imports from the rest of the world where they will be consumed within the EU.\n\nThis means the UK would have to apply the same tariffs as the EU and impose the same rules on imported goods.\n\nThe Government acknowledge this option \"is an innovative and untested approach\" that would \"take time to develop and First need to secure citizens rights & a financial settlement,\" Mr Verhofstadt said on Twitter.\n\nAnd opposition Labour lawmaker Chris Leslie, from the campaign group Open Britain, said the proposal represented \"wishful thinking of the highest order\".\n\nThe government said it would seek to agree to a \"time-limited period of implementation\" after leaving the EU to provide certainty for businesses and allow new Customs arrangements to be set up.\n\nBritain says its membership of the EU Customs Union, which currently allows for the tariff-free movement of goods, will end along with its membership of the single market when it leaves the bloc in March 2019.\n\nAfter that, \"one possible approach would be a temporary Customs union between the UK and the EU,\" the Brexit ministry said in a statement, ahead of the publication of the full paper.\n\nThe Department for Exiting the EU said Britain wanted to be able to sign free trade agreements with third countries during this period, although these would only be implemented at the end of it.\n\nThe European Commission, the EU's executive arm, said it would \"take note\" of the proposals but would not negotiate on the future relationship with Britain before other issues are resolved.\n\nExperts have warned that it will be extremely difficult to negotiate a new EU-UK free trade agreement before Britain leaves the bloc - particularly as Brussels has so far refused even to start trade talks.\n\nIt says there must be broad agreement first on three key issues - Britain's financial settlement, the issue of expatriate rights, and the question of the border between British-controlled Northern Ireland and Ireland.\n\nBritain will publish its proposals on the Northern Ireland border issue later today, ahead "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/republic-of-ireland/article36034454.ece/f6d38/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-ef04390e-fffc-4164-8752-278a02e0b5db_I1.jpg\n\nAny temporary post-Brexit customs deal must be as close to the status quo as possible, leading business lobbyists have warned.\n\nThe British Irish Chamber of Commerce said it was cautious about the feasibility of some proposals being put forward in London on simplifying new trade barriers with Europe.\n\nJohn McGrane, director of the association, said the ideas were a constructive contribution to the negotiations.\n\n\"The recognition of the need for an interim period to allow for the adoption of new systems and infrastructures will be welcomed by businesses who have long warned of the dangers of leaving the Customs Union without such a transition phase,\" he said.\n\n\"It is important that this phase is as close to the status quo as possible with minimum disruption caused by tariff and non-tariff barriers.\"\n\nOne plan being put forward by London is a time-limited transition which would ensure businesses trading in and out of the UK would only have to adapt once to the rule changes.\n\nA two-year period is being suggested by Brexit Secretary David Davis and he is pushing for the UK to have the right to negotiate new trade deals with other countries.\n\nOn customs, one option being put forward would see the UK manage a new trade border with administration streamlined to what has been described as the \"fullest extent possible\".\n\nMr Davis will also float plans for a customs partnership with the EU which would negate the need for customs checks between the UK and the European bloc.\n\nMr McGrane said the idea of an alternative customs arrangement was interesting but completely unproven and that anything less than a completely open border is problematic for business and citizens.\n\nThe next Brexit negotiation round starts at the end of the month.\n\nMr McGrane said a comprehensive post-Brexit customs deal is vital for borderless trade on the island of Ireland and between the UK and the EU.\n\n\"The future customs relationship that is agreed between the UK and the EU will be hugely important for the future trade relationship on the island of Ireland,\" he said.\n\n\"An agreement must be sought that ensures borderless trade can continue on the island in order to protect the economic and social gains that have been won over the past 19 years with the development of the all-island economy.\"\n\nChambers Ireland chief executive Ian Talbot said it was wildly optimistic to think new customs rules could be agreed and in place in less than two years.\n\n\"We remain of the view that the best kind of transitional agreement for businesses in the UK and the EU would be the maintenance of the
