{"timeCrawl": "12:13:00", "uri": "710301457", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T12:13:00Z", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "source": {"title": "Evening Standard", "uri": "standard.co.uk", "id": "21"}, "url": "https://www.standard.co.uk/comment/comment/matthew-dancona-the-blind-lead-the-blind-on-the-long-and-winding-brexit-road-a3613161.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The more ministers say about leaving the EU, the weaker and more clueless the Government looks\n\nWhen challenged on his government's failure to match expectations, Tony Blair used to speak of a \"post-euphoria, pre-delivery phase\". Today, those ministers charged with the delivery of Brexit lurk in a similar limbo, insisting their urgency is undimmed while demanding patience of those who, not unreasonably, would like to know what, precisely, the UK's departure from the EU will mean.\n\nThe Government's new position papers are the latest reports on Britain's negotiating strategy, intended both to manage such expectations of clarity and (less explicitly) to sedate the fractious Conservative Party.\n\nIn their defence, ministers argue that their objectives have become more detailed in the past six months. Theresa May's Lancaster House speech and its accompanying white paper in January have been followed by the parliamentary debate over Article 50, the Repeal Bill, and now a series of documents on specific aspects of the process.\n\nYet the first two such papers -- on customs arrangements after Britain leaves the EU and the Irish border -- do not inspire confidence. They amount to little more than different and more elaborate ways of posing the same old question: how the hell do we do this?\n\nMuch has been made of the fact that the Cabinet is now broadly united behind the proposition that the UK will leave the institutions of the EU at the end of March 2019, that there will be a transitional period thereafter, but that this \"implementation phase\" will be limited to the current Parliament (on the dubious assumption that it lasts until 2022). The joint article in this weekend's Sunday Telegraph by Philip Hammond and Liam Fox was intended to seal this Cabinet ceasefire in advance of the Prime Minister's return to work.\n\nYet this pact reflects a recognition of reality. Painful as it was to those who backed Remain, the referendum result was a vote against freedom of movement and the sovereignty of the European Court of Justice.\n\nWhatever constitutionally nuanced arrangements are theoretically available, there has never been the slightest political chance that Britain would stay in the single market, customs union or other subsidiary parts of the EU. It is no accident that Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell have been so clear on this. No modern populist, of the Left or Right, can afford to say otherwise.\n\nThis has two important consequences. First, Britain must be seen to leave the EU, clearly and unambiguously, on March 31, 2019. Second, we must then re-invent the wheel: to enable British business to trade as openly as possible with our former European partners, to facilitate the migration of labour to the UK and to retain the many benefits of pan-European co-operation (notably in law and order, counter-terrorism measures and intelligence sharing).\n\nHence the core contradiction in the first two transition papers. Carbonated by the fizz of radical change ahead, they still seek as much continuity as possible. The proposals for post-Brexit customs, for instance, combine an insistence that present arrangements must end with a tortuous plan to reproduce them.\n\nThe first option proposed is essentially an exercise in damage limitation, euphemistically described as \"highly streamlined... streamlining and simplifying requirements, leaving as few additional requirements on EU trade as possible\". Quite how this would be achieved is opaque, beyond the promise of \"technology-based solutions\" and \"innovative facilitations\". At times, the jargon veers close to the sales patter of a marketing presentation.\n\nThe second proposal is even more baffling, proposing \"innovative approaches that could support UK-EU trade outside of a customs union arrangement, while still removing the need for customs processes at the border\". This would apparently involve \"mirroring the EU's customs approach at its external border\" so as to \"ensure that all goods entering the EU via the UK have paid the correct EU duties\".\n\nConfused? You should be. When the paper acknowledges that \"this is an innovative and untested approach\", one can sense the justified panic of Whitehall officials beneath the surface. The sub-heading \"Providing certainty\" has a desperate quality to it.\n\nNo less enigmatic are today's plans for a new border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland that would involve no physical infrastructure. Welcome as such an arrangement would be, it is hard to imagine how it would be compatible with the UK's new status outside the EU. At the very least it would depend upon a level of technological sophistication that has defeated successive governments.\n\nSome of the objections already raised by our 27 soon-to-be-former partners are part of the great poker game that lies ahead. But not all. It is quite true that the new border between the UK and the EU cannot be both exclusionary and \"frictionless\", any more than we can both fulfil our international financial obligations and tell Europe to \"go whistle\" over the divorce bill.\n\nSuch reservations infuriate Brexiteers, who dismiss them as the cavilling of \"Remoaners\". But the time for such fury is long past. The referendum was won and lost last year, and the Government has now, quite properly, embarked upon the process of departure. But questioning the practicality of its proposals is scarcely treasonable, or even an insult to those who voted Leave. Indeed, it is in the interests of those who believed in Brexit last year to scrutinise its implementation with care.\n\nThe curse of contemporary politics is the urge to insist that complex problems have simple solutions. The Leave campaign presented Britain's departure from the EU as a light-switch moment that would transform its prospects.\n\nYet the reality is not a sudden catharsis but a forest of technicalities from which, at times, it seems we may not emerge. The more ministers say, the clearer it becomes that this is a desperately weak Government, unsure of its own, and the nation's, trajectory.", "id": "9474583", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", {"timeCrawl": "00:10:00", "uri": "710035763", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T00:10:00Z", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/london-does-not-seem-to-be-deviating-from-position-of-hard-brexit-1.3187923", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The UK government is trying to have it all its own way: maintain the benefits of the Customs Union while also using any transitional period to negotiate, but not finalise, its own free trade deals\n\nMichel Barnier, the EU's chief Brexit negotiator, has told the British government the clock is ticking towards the March 2019 date when the UK will leave the union.\n\nThat clock, however, is also ticking towards a European Council summit in October when Taoiseach Leo Varadkar will, along with his other EU heads of state and government, decide if enough progress has been made to move on to the next phase of Brexit talks, which will focus on trade.\n\nIt is the crucial phase for Irish economic interests. But the publication this week of Brexit position papers by the UK government indicate that London is not deviating from its position of a so-called \"hard\" exit, but is maintaining its stance that it would like to cherrypick aspects of its current EU arrangements it likes.\n\nIn recent weeks Varadkar has made his feelings known on a number of Brexit fronts, primarily that the Government does not want an economic border on the island of Ireland. But when he toned the rhetoric down in a speech at Queen's University in Belfast, the Taoiseach anticipated some of the issues that have been confirmed this week.\n\nIf the UK wanted to leave the Customs Union, he argued for a separate \"EU-UK customs union\".\n\nThe Taoiseach also said the UK could rejoin the European Free Trade Association, which gives access to the Single Market, but would most likely mean Britain accepting free movement of people. That is likely to be a non-runner given the emphasis in the Brexit referendum on immigration.\n\nThe customs position paper published Tuesday outlined that the UK wants a customs arrangement of sorts with the EU, the most benign of which for Ireland would not require any customs checks on the Border.\n\nBut it again showed the UK government trying to have it all its own way: maintain the benefits of the Customs Union while also using any transitional period to negotiate, but not finalise, its own free trade deals.\n\nAn arrangement such as the customs union the EU has with Turkey - previously cited by Varadkar - allows for bilateral trade deals to be struck by \"third countries\". But the Turkish experience suggests the UK would face some restrictions if it is to go down that path, which are unlikely to sit well with the buccaneering free-trade vision favoured by many Brexiteers.\n\nThe UK is seemingly clear in what it wants, or else knows that what it is outlining this week is an opening offer that will shift in time. Perhaps Theresa May is attempting to manage the right wing of her party towards a pre-determined destination.\n\nBut, in proposing \"practical solutions\" in his Queen's University speech, Varadkar also acknowledged there is a \"space in which agreements are made\".\n\nThe Irish Government clearly wants the UK to remain in the Customs Union or a similar arrangement at the very least.\n\nThe UK wants the benefits of it too but, as of now, is demanding far too much.\n\nIn October, Varadkar will probably have no choice but to side with the EU27 if it decides insufficient progress has been made for the talks to move on to trade.\n\nBut he could soon find himself in that space he described - the one where deals are made - if Ireland is to prevent a nightmare scenario of a \"no-deal\" {"timeCrawl": "23:26:00", "uri": "710024536", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T23:26:00Z", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/editorial/brexit-border-dilemma-must-focus-minds-1.3187625", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The horrendous complexity and challenge of negotiating Brexit is slowly starting to become clear. The British position paper on future customs arrangements, published yesterday, and today's paper on the Border and the North, cover issues vital to Ireland. The Government in Dublin will welcome the fact that London is finally starting to put some suggestions and options on the table, even if they are still lacking in detail and a way forward is far from clear.\n\nIssues relating to Ireland are one of three topics on which progress is meant to be made before the talks move on to future trade arrangements between the UK and the EU. As such, the weeks ahead will be important for Ireland and the Government will, before an EU summit in October, have to decide whether it feels sufficient progress has been made on the Irish issues.\n\nToday's paper is expected to propose that the ability to move and work freely between Ireland and the UK broadly continues after Brexit. This is important, particularly recognising the deep social and economic links that have built up over many years. It also means free movement of people can continue across the Border.\n\nThere are also other Irish-specific issues to be negotiated, some springing from the Belfast Agreement, which was negotiated in the context of both countries being part of the EU. Nothing is more sensitive, politically, than the future of the Border itself.\n\nThe British paper on new customs arrangements recognises that the reimposition of a Border on the island would be a key consequence if it leaves the EU customs union, the arrangement which allows goods to flow freely. It does suggest that this might be avoided, or at least mitigated, if the UK and the EU agreed a new customs union deal to apply after Brexit, though there are clear difficulties to negotiating such an agreement on the terms suggested by London. In particular, the EU will be highly sceptical of London's attempts to negotiate a customs union while still trying to retain the flexibility of negotiating new deals with third countries.\n\nIf a new customs deal is not possible, Britain says, arrangements can be put in place to make the Border as \" seamless and frictionless\" as possible. It also suggests that other, unspecified steps \"may be necessary.\" However, checks, controls and documentation would still be needed and what the Taoiseach called an \" economic border\" would be in place. The Government has decided not to engage in technical discussions on how this might operate, fearing that doing so would concede that the Border is coming back. With so much still in play, this seems a sensible approach.With huge questions remaining about how Brexit might happen, there is still a lot of talking ahead, and a clear need for the Government to "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/republic-of-ireland/article36034454.ece/f6d38/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-ef04390e-fffc-4164-8752-278a02e0b5db_I1.jpg\n\nAny temporary post-Brexit customs deal must be as close to the status quo as possible, leading business lobbyists have warned.\n\nThe British Irish Chamber of Commerce said it was cautious about the feasibility of some proposals being put forward in London on simplifying new trade barriers with Europe.\n\nJohn McGrane, director of the association, said the ideas were a constructive contribution to the negotiations.\n\n\"The recognition of the need for an interim period to allow for the adoption of new systems and infrastructures will be welcomed by businesses who have long warned of the dangers of leaving the Customs Union without such a transition phase,\" he said.\n\n\"It is important that this phase is as close to the status quo as possible with minimum disruption caused by tariff and non-tariff barriers.\"\n\nOne plan being put forward by London is a time-limited transition which would ensure businesses trading in and out of the UK would only have to adapt once to the rule changes.\n\nA two-year period is being suggested by Brexit Secretary David Davis and he is pushing for the UK to have the right to negotiate new trade deals with other countries.\n\nOn customs, one option being put forward would see the UK manage a new trade border with administration streamlined to what has been described as the \"fullest extent possible\".\n\nMr Davis will also float plans for a customs partnership with the EU which would negate the need for customs checks between the UK and the European bloc.\n\nMr McGrane said the idea of an alternative customs arrangement was interesting but completely unproven and that anything less than a completely open border is problematic for business and citizens.\n\nThe next Brexit negotiation round starts at the end of the month.\n\nMr McGrane said a comprehensive post-Brexit customs deal is vital for borderless trade on the island of Ireland and between the UK and the EU.\n\n\"The future customs relationship that is agreed between the UK and the EU will be hugely important for the future trade relationship on the island of Ireland,\" he said.\n\n\"An agreement must be sought that ensures borderless trade can continue on the island in order to protect the economic and social "489"}, "url": "http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-wales-politics-40935572", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The National Farmers' Union has welcomed the idea of a temporary customs union with Europe after Brexit.\n\nThe UK government has put forward the idea to avoid the damage of a \"cliff-edge\" departure before a final deal.\n\nSpeaking at the Pembrokeshire Show, NFU President Meurig Raymond said sheep farmers could suffer most from any return of tariffs.\n\nThe Welsh Government said it was \"disappointed\" a permanent post-Brexit customs union was not explored.\n\nThe UK government's position paper, published on Tuesday, said the UK would want to negotiate its own trade deals during the transition period, something it cannot currently do as a member of the EU customs union.\n\nMr Raymond, who farms in Pembrokeshire, told BBC Wales: \"We're delighted to hear the government will be arguing for a transition period post-March 2019.\n\n\"We cannot afford that cliff-edge departure - it would have a devastating effect on certain sectors, particularly sheep, if we ended up with tariffs on our exports to Europe.\n\n\"Obviously we need to be within the customs union through that transition period as I believe it would take at least two to three years to negotiate a bilateral trade deal with the European Union.\n\n\"We need to have a frictionless trade position where business can carry on as normal, at least in the short term.\"\n\nMr Raymond stressed the need for an agreement across the nations on how the financial aid to farmers promised by the UK government following Brexit would be spent.\n\n\"No farmer must be disadvantaged - whether you're in Wales, England, Scotland or Northern Ireland - because we're going to have to be competing against the rest of the world,\" he said.\n\n\"That money needs to be directed to farming so that it can become more efficient, more competitive, and invest for the future.\"\n\nStephen James, president of NFU Cymru, agreed with the idea of a temporary customs union, for the sake of the whole rural economy.\n\n\"We've got all these businesses that are dependent on farming and agriculture - for every pound of support we have, it delivers \u00a37.40 in the wider economy.\n\n\"That's a good message for all governments, because that keeps an economy going.\"\n\nThe Farmers' Union of Wales (FUW), also represented at the Pembrokeshire Show, renewed its call for an agricultural summit of the various UK governments to agree the rules on how the sector should be run when EU policies no longer apply.\n\nThe UK government proposes an \"innovative and untested approach\" to customs checks once any transition period is over, using measures such as number plate recognition technology for lorries.\n\nHowever, Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's negotiator, dismissed the idea of \"invisible borders\" as a \"fantasy\".\n\nThe Welsh Government said it welcomed \"the recognition that there will need to be an interim or transitional period with as little change as possible in terms of practical customs arrangements\".\n\nBut a spokeswoman added that there had been \"no attempt to seek input\" from devolved administrations.\n\nShe said the Welsh Government was \"disappointed\" that the costs and benefits of establishing an independent trade policy had not been analysed, and that the idea of a new customs union with the EU post-Brexit had not been considered.\n\nPlaid Cymru MP Hywel Williams said the idea of the UK keeping \"the perks of remaining in the EU Customs Union whilst negotiating alternative deals with third countries is at best naive and at worst deluded\".\n\n\"What was meant to be a reassuring step {"timeCrawl": "21:14:00", "uri": "709446784", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:14:00Z", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "source": {"title": "WalesOnline", "uri": "walesonline.co.uk", "id": "1272"}, "url": "http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/politics/theresa-mays-tories-crisis-welsh-13476827", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Tories who campaigned for Remain and Leave have rejected claims the party could break apart\n\nGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nWelsh Conservatives who campaigned on either side of the Brexit divide have stamped on speculation the party is heading for a split over Britain's future relationship with the EU.\n\nFormer Steel Minister Anna Soubry has warned that the party could divide unless Theresa May confronts \"ideologues\" who are pushing for a hard Brexit.\n\nShe has refused to rule out joining \"like-minded people who want to save our country from such an appalling fate\" and Brexit Secretary David Davis' former chief of staff James Chapman is now pushing for the creation of a new party.\n\nMr Chapman has warned that the Tory brand is now so damaged that it \"won't be elected again\". He argued that the consequences of a hard Brexit would \"make Black Wednesday look like a picnic\" and is championing the creation of a new centrist party called the Democrats.\n\nHe said it was time for MPs in \"all parties to admit Brexit is a catastrophe, come together in new party if need be, and reverse it\".\n\nThis comes as the anti-EU group Leave.EU is leading calls to deselect two Conservative cabinet ministers, Chancellor Philip Hammond and Home Secretary Amber Rudd, because they sought to \"meddle\" in the Brexit process.\n\nAccording to political historian Anthony Seldon: \"We have to go back 100 years to see a time when the Conservative Party was in such disarray.\"\n\nRemaining hopes that the UK could stay in the single market and the customs union appeared killed off this week when Chancellor Mr Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox stated the UK would leave both in March 2019.\n\nHowever, Welsh Tories who were on opposite sides of the referendum debate in 2016 denied the party was on the verge of fracturing.\n\nCraig Williams, who as Cardiff North MP was a leading Conservative supporter of continued EU membership, lost his seat in the June election but was adamant he was \"not going anywhere\".\n\nHe predicted the Tories would unify in shared opposition to \"the idea of Jeremy Corbyn as Prime Minister\".\n\nMr Williams said: \"I think even the most hardened of Remainers now realise the biggest danger is not Brexit but the deep, deep left-wing alternatives being presented [in] the form of Jeremy Corbyn's Labour's party.\"\n\nHe expected any new grouping would \"die out swiftly\".\n\nFormer Brexit Minister and Clwyd West Conservative MP David Jones - who was at the forefront of the campaign to quit the EU - played down the chances of people joining the new party envisaged by James Chapman.\n\nHe said: \"I don't honestly think that there's any appetite at all... I worked quite closely with James, very closely indeed, and I really had no inkling that he was as unhappy as he appears to be.\"\n\nMr Jones added: \"What you have to remember is there was a party that actually made remaining in the EU a general election issue, and that was the Lib Dems and the Lib Dems suffered a drubbing at the general election, not least in Wales where of course they were left with no seats at all... I think James may be overlooking the fact that the Lib Dems don't appear to be getting any traction for that policy - 85% of the voters at the last general election voted for parties who were committed to taking Britain out of the EU.\n\n\"I really don't know why he's ploughing this particular furrow but if he wants to do so that's up to him and it's a matter for individual conscience really.\"\n\nAngela Burns, Conservative AM for Carmarthen West and South Pembrokeshire, wanted the UK to stay in the EU in 2016 but said politicians should now \"focus on delivering what the voters have asked for\".\n\nShe said: \"My only comment would be we must be sure that the interests of the nation come before the self-interests of individual politicians with ambition.\"\n\nDescribing the concerns of local voters, she said: \"Truly and honestly, when I go about my business in Carmarthen West and South Pembrokeshire, this doesn't reach voters' lips. They voted for Brexit or they didn't.\n\n\"Those who did want it to be delivered, delivered properly, delivered fairly and delivered to the benefit of Britain. Those who voted against Brexit expect to be delivered fairly for Britain but also for the EU and for the rest of the world...\n\n\"Apart from that, they are concentrating on school standards, the local hospital, jobs for their kids, what's going to happen to their pensions, the price of food in the shops... They've made a decision and they expect people to be sensible and grown up and mature and get on and sort it out on their behalf.\"\n\nMontgomeryshire Conservative MP Glyn Davies, who supports leaving the single market and the customs union, did not expect a new party to win support.\n\nHe said: \"There's clearly a division of opinion in all political parties at the moment and you always get this sort of talk... Any politician is foolish to discount any possible occurrence but I can say honestly I just cannot see any such occurrence happening.\"\n\nArguing that the UK must leave the single market and customs union to achieve true Brexit, he said: \"I know that those who don't want Britain to leave the European Union are still hoping that we might stay within the single market and the customs union but [that] means you have effectively not left the European Union and I just don't think that's going to happen.\"\n\nMr Davies was unimpressed by the argument that some Conservatives will feel they have more in common on this issue with moderate Labour politicians.\n\nHe said: \"If you go back through history you'll always find people in one political party have got very close colleagues in another political party. I'e seen it myself... I don't think that's anything new or anything unusual.\"\n\nSetting out his own approach, he said: \"You can try to make a headline or you can try to make a difference in politics and I always preferred the latter course.\"", "id": "9162855", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "Welsh Conservatives refuse to accept the Tories will split", "image": {"timeCrawl": "07:31:00", "uri": "710173113", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T19:36:00Z", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "source": {"title": "worldview.stratfor.com", "uri": "worldview.stratfor.com", "id": "19140"}, "url": "https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/uk-eu-wont-fold-key-issues-despite-new-brexit-paper", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "It's no Magna Carta, but a new paper from the British government outlines a potential future for the United Kingdom. On Aug. 15, the British government published a strategy paper on Brexit in preparation for a new round of negotiations with the European Union scheduled to begin Aug. 28. It proposes establishing a temporary customs union between the United Kingdom and the European Union during the Brexit transition period beginning in March 2019, confirming London's desire to buy more time to negotiate a permanent settlement.\n\nThe document is the first in a new series of position papers to be published in the run-up to October, when the British Parliament and the European Council will publish two separate assessments on how much progress has been made toward resolving three major Brexit issues: the Brexit bill, citizens' rights, and the Irish border. According to the proposal, the United Kingdom would be able to negotiate new trade deals while remaining in a temporary customs union with the European Union. The new deals, however, would only be implemented after the United Kingdom has left the interim stage and Brexit has been fully enacted.\n\nAccording to the British paper, the United Kingdom and European Union would then establish a customs partnership with no internal customs border. The United Kingdom would also be required to mirror EU tariffs on imported goods whose final destination is in the European Union. The alternative option would be a highly streamlined arrangement, under which the United Kingdom would impose the same conditions as the European Union on international customs and collect customs duties on its behalf. This second option would require a customs border -- including one between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland -- which would utilize technology to minimize the need for physical checks.\n\nThe European Union replied to the paper on the same day of its release, saying the issue concerns bilateral relations and cannot be addressed before sufficient progress has been made in negotiating the details of Brexit. The United Kingdom, for its part, insists that its withdrawal from the European Union and its future relationship to it are inextricably linked. British Brexit Secretary David Davis said on Aug. 15 that the United Kingdom will not commit to a number for the Brexit bill before the European Council meets in October. However, chief Brexit negotiator for the European Union Michel Barnier responded to the British paper by saying that the sooner withdrawal negotiations are successful, the sooner discussion of a future relationship -- including a customs arrangement -- can begin.\n\nThe plan outlined by the British paper is expected to be met with resistance within the European Union. Europeans have already made it clear that the United Kingdom will not be able to negotiate trade deals while it's in a customs union. On Aug. 15, a spokesman from the European Commission reiterated Barnier's statement, saying that frictionless trade is not possible outside the single market and customs union. When it comes to trade with the European Union, the United Kingdom won't be able to have its cake and eat it too.", "id": "9424622", "details": {"liCnt": 13}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "U.K.: EU {"timeCrawl": "12:38:00", "uri": "709220975", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T12:24:00Z", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "source": {"title": "Evening Standard", "uri": "standard.co.uk", "id": "21"}, "url": "https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/theresa-may-s-summer-holiday-enters-fourth-week-as-brexit-tensions-mount-a3611371.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Theresa May will not fly back into the UK until later this week despite fresh Brexit tensions as Britain prepares for the next round of EU negotiations.\n\nThe Prime Minister, who is holidaying in Switzerland, will only return to her desk in Downing Street on Thursday, pushing her summer break into an unusual fourth week.\n\nHer time away risks proving controversial given concerns over Britain's preparation for Brexit. Position papers on future customs arrangements and the border with Ireland are expected to be released during her absence, so her first day back will be in the midst of debate among senior politicians.\n\nMrs May headed to Italy with husband Philip at the end of July, then attended the Passchendaele commemorations in Belgium and spent a day working from No 10. Following that, she left for a two-week walking holiday in Switzerland. A spokesman said she has had 15 working days off.\n\nIan Lavery, Labour Party chair, said: \"With her Cabinet squabbling over the Government's position on issue after issue, it seems like she's given up on governing.\"\n\nToday a leading Conservative Remain campaigner warned against \"siren voices\" calling for a new party to be set up to fight against Brexit.\n\nFormer Cabinet minister Nicky Morgan said liberal Tory MPs should not be \"drummed out\" of the party by being lured into joining a new one or forced out by hardline Brexiteers.\n\n\u200bBrexit Secretary David Davis's former chief of staff, who is campaigning to launch a new anti-Brexit party, revealed last week that two members of Theresa May's Cabinet had been in contact with him.\n\nJames Chapman said the two senior Tories believed there was \"an enormous gap in the centre of British politics\", though he added that neither had suggested defecting. Ms Morgan, who campaigned for Remain last year and chairs the influential Commons Treasury committee, warned against Conservatives resigning to join a new party, which she believes would swiftly \"collapse under its own contradictions\".\n\n\"If one-nation liberal Conservatives listen to these siren voices, what would it say about the Tory Party we now have?\" she added on the ConservativeHome website. \"To accept the argument for creating a new party would be to accept that the Conservative Party can no longer appeal to the British political centre ground.\"\n\nShe said the Tories must stay a \"broad church\" not become a \"narrow ideological shrine, appealing only to a narrow and ageing group of supporters\".\n\nMrs May will return to a Tory Party still rumbling with talk of a leadership challenge. Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg has even been mooted as a possible successor. However, fellow backbencher Heidi Allen said she would quit the party if he took the helm.\n\n\"I couldn't be in the Conservative Party if he was my leader,\" she told BBC radio's The Westminster Hour. She described him as \"incredibly charming\" and \"very generous\" but added: \"He's not the modern face of the Tory party that we are desperate -- or I am, certainly -- and colleagues are desperate to prove is out there.\"\n\nThe Prime Minister will seek to gain some control over the political agenda by publishing the Brexit position papers. However, there are concerns among senior Whitehall officials that some documents are being rushed through without proper analysis.\n\nAt the weekend, Chancellor Philip Hammond, who favours a \"soft\" pro-business Brexit, and International Development Secretary Liam Fox, a leading Brexiteer, issued a joint statement that there would have to be a transition period after Britain leaves the EU. But they stressed it would be time-limited and Britain would quit the EU single market and customs union.\n\nIn a sign of the fraught negotiations ahead, New Zealand warned against a proposal that would limit the amount of its lamb which could be sold in Britain after Brexit.", "id": "9077594", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "PM's summer holiday enters fourth week as Brexit {"timeCrawl": "13:04:00", "uri": "709233699", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T13:04:00Z", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "source": {"title": "msn.com", "uri": "msn.com", "id": "152"}, "url": "http://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/other/theresa-may%e2%80%99s-summer-holiday-enters-fourth-week-as-brexit-tensions-mount/ar-AAq3E6r", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Theresa May will not fly back into the UK until later this week despite fresh Brexit tensions as Britain prepares for the next round of EU negotiations.\n\nThe Prime Minister, who is holidaying in Switzerland, will only return to her desk in Downing Street on Thursday, pushing her summer break into an unusual fourth week.\n\nHer time away risks proving controversial given concerns over Britain's preparation for Brexit. Position papers on future customs arrangements and the border with Ireland are expected to be released during her absence, so her first day back will be in the midst of debate among senior politicians.\n\nMrs May headed to Italy with husband Philip at the end of July, then attended the Passchendaele commemorations in Belgium and spent a day working from No 10. Following that, she left for a two-week walking holiday in Switzerland. A spokesman said she has had 15 working days off.\n\nIan Lavery, Labour Party chair, said: \"With her Cabinet squabbling over the Government's position on issue after issue, it seems like she's given up on governing.\"\n\nToday a leading Conservative Remain campaigner warned against \"siren voices\" calling for a new party to be set up to fight against Brexit.\n\nFormer Cabinet minister Nicky Morgan said liberal Tory MPs should not be \"drummed out\" of the party by being lured into joining a new one or forced out by hardline Brexiteers.\n\n\u200bBrexit Secretary David Davis's former chief of staff, who is campaigning to launch a new anti-Brexit party, revealed last week that two members of Theresa May's Cabinet had been in contact with him.\n\nJames Chapman said the two senior Tories believed there was \"an enormous gap in the centre of British politics\", though he added that neither had suggested defecting. Ms Morgan, who campaigned for Remain last year and chairs the influential Commons Treasury committee, warned against Conservatives resigning to join a new party, which she believes would swiftly \"collapse under its own contradictions\".\n\n\"If one-nation liberal Conservatives listen to these siren voices, what would it say about the Tory Party we now have?\" she added on the ConservativeHome website. \"To accept the argument for creating a new party would be to accept that the Conservative Party can no longer appeal to the British political centre ground.\"\n\nShe said the Tories must stay a \"broad church\" not become a \"narrow ideological shrine, appealing only to a narrow and ageing group of supporters\".\n\nMrs May will return to a Tory Party still rumbling with talk of a leadership challenge. Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg has even been mooted as a possible successor. However, fellow backbencher Heidi Allen said she would quit the party if he took the helm.\n\n\"I couldn't be in the Conservative Party if he was my leader,\" she told BBC radio's The Westminster Hour. She described him as \"incredibly charming\" and \"very generous\" but added: \"He's not the modern face of the Tory party that we are desperate -- or I am, certainly -- and colleagues are desperate to prove is out there.\"\n\nThe Prime Minister will seek to gain some control over the political agenda by publishing the Brexit position papers. However, there are concerns among senior Whitehall officials that some documents are being rushed through without proper analysis.\n\nAt the weekend, Chancellor Philip Hammond, who favours a \"soft\" pro-business Brexit, and International Development Secretary Liam Fox, a leading Brexiteer, issued a joint statement that there would have to be a transition period after Britain leaves the EU. But they stressed it would be time-limited and Britain would quit the EU single market and customs union.\n\nIn a sign of the fraught negotiations ahead, New Zealand warned against a proposal that would limit the amount of its lamb which could be sold in Britain after Brexit.", "id": "9082179", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "Theresa May's summer holiday enters fourth week as Ministers said the plans would mean the \"freest and most frictionless possible trade\" with the rest of Europe. This could include a \"temporary customs union\" after Brexit to prevent border problems as the UK leaves the EU. Businesses have called for clarity since the UK said it was leaving the customs union - the EU's tariff-free trading area - as part of Brexit. The customs union document is the first of a series of papers to be published by the UK government on key negotiation issues. On Wednesday it is expected to set out proposals for the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.\n\nSource: BBC News\n\nBeaufort Securities Share Facebook Twitter Google+ LinkedIn {"timeCrawl": "09:24:00", "uri": "710223241", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T09:24:00Z", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "source": {"title": "Grimsby Telegraph", "uri": "grimsbytelegraph.co.uk", "id": "3146"}, "url": "http://www.grimsbytelegraph.co.uk/news/customs-union-matters-grimsby-area-332013", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The Leave campaign promised many changes with a vote for Brexit.\n\nBut there is one thing they never wanted to change much and that's the way the UK trades with the European Union.\n\nRight now, it is decidedly uncomplicated. Goods - from wood chips to cars - come in to the country, while items made in the UK go out.\n\nAs long as the transfer of these goods is between the UK and another EU country, no one really blinks an eye.\n\nAnd that's all because Britain is a member of the customs union - a set of bloc agreements which removes tariffs (i.e. a financial charge) between the 28 EU countries and lifts the need for import and export checks, making business cheaper and faster.\n\nBut, in just over 18 months' time, the country will no longer be part of the EU or its customs union and businesses could face more paperwork and costly delays to sell to, or buy from, Europe.\n\nThe Government yesterday published a paper looking at how a future customs arrangement with the EU could work after March 2019.\n\nIn it, it conceded that the UK would have to prepare for a cliff-edge whereby, overnight, British firms would have to start declaring everything they export to the likes of France and even, in some cases, apply for export licences.\n\nThe same would go for countries looking to sell to the UK, making imports more cumbersome.\n\nThat could create huge issues in North East Lincolnshire, home to the Port of Immingham - the busiest port in the UK by tonnage - and Grimsby Docks, a major port for the car industry.\n\nTraders using the ports are not going to be happy if they face new import tariffs or lengthy waiting times for checks to be carried out.\n\nOfficials and ministers were clear yesterday that they are trying to avoid such a situation, and have proposed two options it would ideally like to see in place after Brexit.\n\nThe first - dubbed the \"highly streamlined customs arrangement\" - would look to \"waiver\" entry and exit declarations, see Britain sign-up to the Commons Transit Convention so goods travelling through Europe don't have to stop for checks at every border, while also allowing for companies to self-declare their goods before entering the country, meaning less need for physical checks.\n\nThe second is a new customs partnership with the EU, which is more complicated as it would require new technology and would be dealing with different pricing structures for import and export tariffs.\n\nIt is also an \"untested approach\", with the Government saying it would require further discussion with those in the industry.\n\nIn the meantime, the Government has officially proposed an \"interim\" period after Brexit, a period of perhaps two years according to Brexit Secretary David Davis, whereby the current EU customs rules will still apply to Britain while both UK and EU-based companies adjust.\n\nThe caveat is that Britain wants to be able to negotiate new trade deals with countries outside the EU - something the customs union forbids - during that interim period.\n\nThe CBI called the proposal of an interim period a \"critical first step forward\" in the EU trade negotiations.\n\nAssociated British Ports, which runs the ports at Grimsby and Immingham, and the Hull and Humber Chamber of Commerce said they would be keeping a \"watching brief\" on how talks progressed over a future customs arrangement.\n\nA spokeswoman for ABP said the company \"welcomed\" the Government's paper and said it would be working to ensure businesses had \"efficient and reliable access\" to the Continent.\n\n\"We are committed to working with our customers and the Government to make sure trade can flow as smoothly as possible following the UK's exit from the Single Market and Customs Union,\" said the spokeswoman.\n\n\"Underpinned by our ongoing commitment to invest in new infrastructure and facilities, ABP's Humber ports will continue to provide British businesses with efficient and reliable access to European markets.\"\n\nDavid Hooper, external affairs manager at the chamber of commerce, said the paper would be discussed by its members and boards in the coming weeks.\n\n\"We are keeping a watching brief on developments and things will be discussed at length at our shipping and transport committee and by our five area councils,\" said Mr Hooper.\n\n\"The chamber will take its lead from our member businesses, so it is probably too early to take a view on which option is best.\n\n\"David Davis has unveiled the Government's preferred option but obviously that has to be agreed by the remaining EU members, so we will watch developments accordingly.\n\n\"We import a lot from Europe as well as export, so it is in nobody's interest to make things more difficult than they need to be.\"\n\nThe reason the Government has decided to publish details on the kind of future customs arrangement it would like to see is because it freely admits that the negotiations are not going as well as they would like.\n\nOne well-connected Whitehall official, speaking on an anonymous basis, told the Telegraph that the \"early experience of negotiations hasn't been as effective as it might otherwise have been\" had they a vision of the future UK-EU relationship to share.\n\nThese proposals, the Department for Exiting the European Union (Dexu) hopes, will help move things forward at a sharper pace.\n\nThat has not stopped EU officials from criticising the ministerial suggestions.\n\nGuy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's chief Brexit negotiator, tweeted: \"To be in and out of the Customs Union and invisible borders is a fantasy\".\n\nThere have been critics closer to home as well. Grimsby MP Melanie Onn said she found Mr Davis' suggestions \"far from ideal\" and feared it could put the region's seafood industry, which employs 5,500 people, \"needlessly at risk\".\n\nAny import delays could harm the quality of the seafood, while new security measures - such as new number-plate recognition software being mooted by HMRC - at Humber ports could prove costly.\n\nMs Onn said: \"Grimsby, Immingham, and Hull ports are major employers here, and I'm worried that [what] the Government admit is their ideal outcome, before they've even started negotiating, would result in increased administration.\n\n\"This could cause delays and ultimately trade moving away from our shores, unless it was accompanied by major investment in our ports.\n\n\"It may not make a huge difference to the motor industry if it takes a couple of days extra to make it through border checks - no one checks the expiry date on a Nissan before they buy one.\n\n\"But senior voices in the seafood industry have been clear that border checks on their imports and exports must remain as simple, quick, and cheap as they are currently if these jobs are to be maintained.\n\n\"The Government shouldn't put our biggest local industry needlessly at risk.\"\n\nCleethorpes MP Martin Vickers, whose constituency is home to Immingham port, said any changes to security operations at Immingham could see \"support from the Government\" being called for locally.\n\nThe Conservative backbencher said a recent meeting with DExU minister Steve Baker and his officials demonstrated they were aware of the \"importance of assuring that documentation is kept to a minimum\" under any new regulations.\n\nAddressing the critics, Mr Vickers said there was bound to be some tit-for-tat between UK and EU figures while negotiations were on-going.\n\n\"On all the issues, whatever the UK says, the European Commission will say, 'That's not quite what we were looking for'.\n\n\"This is a negotiation. They are going to be cautious and push things off as not being up to standard,\" said Mr Vickers.\n\n\"What emerges from the negotiations will be what is in the best interests of all sides.\"", "id": {"timeCrawl": "21:11:00", "uri": "709445295", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:11:00Z", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "source": {"title": "Sky News", "uri": "news.sky.com", "id": "1841"}, "url": "http://news.sky.com/story/government-proposes-interim-eu-uk-customs-union-after-brexit-10988983", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The Government will propose a new UK-EU customs union as an interim measure to avoid a \"cliff-edge\" for manufacturers after Britain leaves the bloc.\n\nThe proposal is contained in the Government's first \"future partnership paper\", published on Tuesday by the Department for Exiting the European Union (DExEU).\n\nThe outline of post-Brexit customs arrangements is designed to keep all members of the Cabinet onside.\n\nWhile confirming the UK's exit from the EU's customs union after Brexit, the paper proposes a \"temporary customs union between the UK and the EU\" as a \"possible approach\" to getting a \"smooth and orderly\" transfer to a post-Brexit customs regime.\n\nAt the moment, all goods and parts travel across the EU free of both tariffs and checks as part of the bloc's customs union.\n\nAfter the Brexit vote there has been an ongoing debate within Cabinet about whether to stay in the system.\n\nRemaining in the EU's customs union would restrict Britain's ability to sign independent trade deals with non-EU countries, with a common external tariff applied outside the zone.\n\nTurkey already has its own customs union with the EU for industrialised goods, which enables participation in complex manufacturing supply chains.\n\nSpeaking to Sky News last month, International Trade Secretary Liam Fox said there was a difference between \"the\" customs union and \"a\" customs union, but cautioned against using Turkey as a model.\n\nDExEU says the interim customs arrangements will be \"time-limited\" to allow for businesses to adapt to a post-Brexit system.\n\nNo actual timeframe has been mentioned, although some Cabinet ministers have suggested it will have to expire before the next scheduled general election in 2022.\n\nThere has been much criticism of the Government's own preparedness to introduce the sorts of customs systems and checks required by its policy to leave the EU's customs union by 2019.\n\nThe National Audit Office was hugely critical of HMRC in a recent report.\n\nThe EU will have to agree to any interim arrangement and especially to the establishment of a temporary customs union.\n\nCritics of the Government's Brexit strategy accused ministers of chasing a \"fantasy\" following the release of the paper.\n\nLabour MP Chris Leslie, a leading supporter of the Open Britain group, said: \"It looks like the new unified position in the Cabinet is to return the Government to the territory of wanting to have their cake and eat it.\n\n\"Ministers claim we can leave the customs union and yet still achieve 'the most frictionless customs agreement anywhere in the world' but with absolutely no detail about how such a miraculous new system will be achieved.\n\n\"It is a fantasy to pretend we can have the freest and most frictionless trade possible with our largest partner when the Government remains intent on pulling Britain out of the customs union.\n\n\"This is wishful thinking of the highest order.\n\n\"The only way to retain genuinely free trade with Europe, and protect the millions of jobs created by it, is to remain a member of the customs union.\"\n\nIt is not clear whether the EU will respond to the paper, having agreed with the UK to first deal with issues of the so-called Brexit bill, Ireland and citizens' rights during negotiations before moving on to the future EU-UK relationship.\n\nOutlining a position on customs arrangements does, however, help bring some clarity to the position of the border with Ireland.\n\nA further Government paper on the issue of Ireland's border will be published on Wednesday.", "id": "9162318", "details": {"liCnt": 22, "gpCnt": 4}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "Brexit: Govt chases interim EU-UK customs union", "image": "body": "It's understood the Prime Minister is expected back in 10 Downing Street on Thursday\n\nGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nTheresa May is still enjoying her summer break despite widespread reports she was getting back to work today.\n\nIt's understood the Prime Minister is expected back in 10 Downing Street this Thursday.\n\nBy the time she returns it'll be three weeks and three days in total since she set off for her first of two summer holidays.\n\nShe returned from a five-day break in northern Italy for an official event marking the centenary of the outbreak of the Battle of Passchendaele on July 31.\n\nShe then set off again for a two-week holiday walking with her husband Philip in the Swiss Alps.\n\nMultiple previous reports had said Mrs May would be back to work on Monday 14 August.\n\nBut it appears August 14 was confused with the \"week of\" August 14 in a to-and-fro between reporters and Downing Street last month.\n\nThe Tory leader will be plunged into the deep end when she does return as the government attempts to show its hand on Brexit .\n\nAt least two 'position papers' spelling out the government's view on thorny issues of customs and the Northern Ireland border will be published this week.\n\nOnly one - the Northern Ireland paper - will actually be used in the next round of negotiations with the EU at the end of this month.\n\nThe other, on the customs union, is expected to be a \"future position\" paper - meaning it won't be discussed straight away.\n\nEU chiefs have warned the \"clock is ticking\" but have been unwilling to discuss Britain's future trade with the EU until key parts of Brexit itself are settled, including a multi-billion pound 'divorce bill'.\n\nAsked why future position papers are being published now, a Downing Street spokesman said: \"The talks which have taken place so far have shown that many of the withdrawal questions can only be settled with the future relationship in mind.\"\n\nMrs May will fly home to face Tory chaos after a senior MP threatened to quit the party over Brexit.\n\nFormer Business Minister Anna Soubry said she would put \"country before party\" and quit the Tories for a new pro-EU group if Mrs May does not soften her stance on Brexit.\n\nIn an attempt to show Cabinet unity, Remain-backing Chancellor Philip Hammond and Brexiteer Liam Fox published a joint article agreeing key red lines.\n\nThey said Britain will need a \"time-limited interim period\" to implement Brexit \"but it cannot be indefinite, it cannot be a back door to staying in the EU.\"\n\nBut behind the public calm anonymous MPs claimed the PM should sack pro-Remain ministers in a mini Cabinet reshuffle.\n\nIt also emerged arch-Brexiteer toff Jacob Rees-Mogg is mulling a possible run for the party leadership if Mrs May is forced out or quits.\n\nMeanwhile Jeremy Corbyn has kicked off a three-week tour of the country after returning from his summer break in Croatia.\n\nThe Labour leader is due to address a rally in Milton Keynes this afternoon after drawing a crowd of more than 1,000 {"timeCrawl": "21:45:00", "uri": "709991251", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T21:45:00Z", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "source": {"title": "The Sun", "uri": "thesun.co.uk", "id": "16"}, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/4250918/brexit-row-boris-johnson-liam-fox-philip-hammond-david-davis/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "A FRESH Cabinet row has broken out after Liam Fox and Boris Johnson insisted any Brexit transition must be no longer than 12 months.\n\nNew government proposals today called for a temporary customs union with the EU after Britain's exit to help businesses prepare.\n\nMinisters conceded the plan would mean the UK could not implement any new global trade deals for as long as it stays in place.\n\nBrexit Secretary David Davis aligned himself with Philip Hammond's softer Brexit camp today when he said the transition would last \"somewhere like two years\".\n\nThe Chancellor is pushing for as long a transition as possible after pleas from worried businesses.\n\nBut his allies' declaration of victory has infuriated the Foreign and International Trade Secretaries.\n\nThe Sun can reveal that the Cabinet's two leading hardline Brexiteers have now joined forces to dig in and insist the UK must be free to reap the benefits of new trade deals across the globe within a year of Brexit happening on March 30, 2019.\n\nA source close to Boris and Dr Fox said: \"No length of time had been signed off by the Cabinet for the transition period yet, so it's utterly wrong of Hammond and Davis to be waving around two or three years.\n\n\"There will be very big trouble ahead if they carry on like this.\n\n\"Liam and Boris see one year as the maximum period we would ever need. There is a world out there waiting for us, and we need to get on with embracing it.\"\n\nThe fresh row shatters a delicate truce brokered by No10 between Mr Hammond and Mr Fox last weekend.\n\nThe formal customs plans paper published today gave no mention of any transition time frame.\n\nOther hardline Brexit campaigners also attacked the transition plan today.\n\nFormer UKIP boss Nigel Farage accused the government of surrender, saying: \"Today is a big victory for the European Commission. The government has shown great weakness.\n\n\"On the current timetabling, President Trump will be near end of his second term before we could enact a US trade deal.\n\nThe government also proposed two options for a longterm customs deal with the EU after the transition, a major streamlining of new border processes and a new customs-free arrangement to keep trade as free as possible.\n\nChancellor Philip Hammond today dubbed the two longterm proposals as \"ambitious, and rightly so\".\n\nBut pro-EU critics of the plan attacked it for ladelling red tape on businesses after the Brexit ministry admitted they would see \"an increase in administration\".\n\nConsultants Ernst and Young also warned a new customs arrangement would be a major tech challenge for the civil service to deliver, saying that \"anything shorter than a four year delivery window could pose major risks\".\n\nEurope's politicians also criticised the government's plans for being unrealistic.\n\nIreland's foreign minister Europe's leaders that failing to give Britain a good customs deal would mean a mountain of new red tape and tax for their own businesses.\n\nIt also confirmed that the government has begun preparations for a worst case 'no deal' scenario on trade borders which would see thousands of companies across Europe forced to join a new registration system before they are allowed to import goods welcomed the idea of a temporary customs union with Europe after Brexit.\n\nThe UK government has put forward the idea to avoid the damage of a \"cliff-edge\" departure before a final deal.\n\nSpeaking at the Pembrokeshire Show, NFU President Meurig Raymond said sheep farmers could suffer most from any return of tariffs.\n\nThe Welsh Government said it was \"disappointed\" a permanent post-Brexit customs union was not explored.\n\nThe UK government's position paper, published on Tuesday, said the UK would want to negotiate its own trade deals during the transition period, something it cannot currently do as a member of the EU customs union.\n\nMr Raymond, who farms in Pembrokeshire, told BBC Wales: \"We're delighted to hear the government will be arguing for a transition period post-March 2019.\n\n\"We cannot afford that cliff-edge departure - it would have a devastating effect on certain sectors, particularly sheep, if we ended up with tariffs on our exports to Europe.\n\n\"Obviously we need to be within the customs union through that transition period as I believe it would take at least two to three years to negotiate a bilateral trade deal with the European Union.\n\n\"We need to have a frictionless trade position where business can carry on as normal, at least in the short term.\"\n\nMr Raymond stressed the need for an agreement across the nations on how the financial aid to farmers promised by the UK government following Brexit would be spent.\n\n\"No farmer must be disadvantaged - whether you're in Wales, England, Scotland or Northern Ireland - because we're going to have to be competing against the rest of the world,\" he said.\n\n\"That money needs to be directed to farming so that it can become more efficient, more competitive, and invest for the future.\"\n\nStephen James, president of NFU Cymru, agreed with the idea of a temporary customs union, for the sake of the whole rural economy.\n\n\"We've got all these businesses that are dependent on farming and agriculture - for every pound of support we have, it delivers \u00a37.40 in the wider economy.\n\n\"That's a good message for all governments, because that keeps an economy going.\"\n\nThe UK government proposes an \"innovative and untested approach\" to customs checks once any transition period is over, using measures such as number plate recognition technology for lorries.\n\nHowever, Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's negotiator, dismissed the idea of \"invisible borders\" as a \"fantasy\".\n\nThe Welsh Government said it welcomed \"the recognition that there will need to be an interim or transitional period with as little change as possible in terms of practical customs arrangements\".\n\nBut a spokeswoman added that there had been \"no attempt As we leave the EU, the Government will continue to maintain our high standards for consumers, employees, the environment and animal welfare.\"\n\nRegister now for Bioenergy Insight & Expo 2017 for {"timeCrawl": "02:06:00", "uri": "709534444", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T02:06:00Z", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "source": {"title": "POLITICO", "uri": "politico.eu", "id": "19273"}, "url": "http://www.politico.eu/article/british-business-to-lobby-brussels-on-brexit-transition-deal/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON -- U.K. businesses want the Brexit negotiations to speed up, and they plan to push the EU side of the talks to make that happen.\n\nAccording to a senior U.K. business figure familiar with thinking among British CEOs, the sector believes that the EU's rigid approach to \"phasing\" the Brexit talks could mean that a job-saving transition deal will come too late. The business leader said U.K. firms plan to lobby Brussels to drop its approach in the hopes of accelerating a transitional deal.\n\nThe EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier insists that talks on the future relationship between the U.K. and EU must wait until separation issues, including Britain's financial obligations, have been resolved. But with many firms requiring several months or a year's lead time to make recruitment, investment and operational decisions for the financial year 2019-2020, the high-ranking business leader said the situation is \"genuinely urgent.\"\n\n\"It's not time to panic, but it is time for everyone to realize that the effects of Brexit are starting to show and it's reasonable to assume those effects will get greater,\" the senior business figure said.\n\n\"Phasing [of the Brexit talks] makes the timing difficult. Some in Brussels feel a transition deal is not possible until the future relationship element of the talks. We are going to be having conversations in Brussels encouraging a sensible approach to phasing.\"\n\nThere are particular concerns for small- and medium-sized businesses that may not have the capacity to conduct detailed contingency planning for a cliff-edge Brexit.\n\nThe plan for a lobbying push in Brussels by British businesses will be music to the ears of the U.K.'s Brexit negotiating team, which this week is publishing position papers laying out the government's stance on future customs arrangements with the EU and the Northern Irish border. They have been forced to accept the EU's phased approach to the talks but maintain that future relationship issues such as the nature of transitional arrangements with the bloc are inextricably linked to the exit terms and should be discussed in parallel.\n\n\"We have been clear that we believe an implementation period is in the interests of both the U.K. and the EU, providing certainty to businesses and citizens, and ensuring we avoid any cliff-edge as we move to our future partnership,\" a U.K. government spokesperson said. \"It would be mutually beneficial for both parties if we agree this principle early in the process.\"\n\nBut time is running out.\n\nContingency planning for a cliff-edge Brexit, in which the U.K. crashes out of the EU without a transitional deal, is already taking place at many U.K. firms, particularly in the financial services sector. Regulatory experts in banks say that those plans would be hard to reverse.\n\nBank of England Governor Mark Carney said earlier this month that banks and insurance companies under his supervision required about 18 months to prepare for any transition period -- more than the time left available for the Brexit talks once ratification of the deal is factored in. And Financial Conduct Authority Chief Executive Andrew Bailey said a transition deal would need to be decided by the end of this year.\n\nA survey of 357 firms in July conducted by the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), a lobby group for 190,000 British businesses, found that 40 percent said Brexit already is affecting investment decisions, with 98 percent of this group saying the effect was negative.\n\nMiles Celic, chief executive officer of TheCityUK lobbying group, said many companies already were making spending decisions and activating contingency plans. Early clarity on the shape of a transitional deal would \"decelerate\" those plans and help keep business in the U.K \"and, indeed, within Europe,\" he said.\n\n\"Different companies have different requirements, but our industry wants confirmation that there will be a time-bound and legally-binding transitional period by the end of this year at the very latest,\" Celic added.\n\nAllie Renison, head of EU and trade policy at the Institute of Directors, an organization representing senior business leaders, said she hoped government would prioritize reaching a deal on transition \"by the end of the first quarter [January to March]\" of 2018 to provide businesses with clarity to plan ahead.\n\nAt the very latest, \"many businesses will need to know by summer 2018 ... whether it is necessary to put in place big changes to operations, should trade arrangements change significantly when we leave the EU in 2019,\" Renison said.\n\nThe CBI is calling for a post-Brexit transition period in which the U.K. remains in the single market and a customs union until a final deal on future trade comes into force. It wants a deal to be agreed, \"as soon as possible, that gives firms today the confidence to continue investing and creates time to get the final deal details right. This period should be as short as practically possible and could be in the realm of two to three years,\" said Josh Hardie, the organization's deputy director general.\n\nThere are particular concerns for small- and medium-sized businesses that may not have the capacity to conduct detailed contingency planning for a cliff-edge Brexit, the senior business figure said. Even businesses that do not export to the EU or employ EU citizens risk being hit as a result of spending decisions made by larger U.K. clients or changes in supply chains.\n\nMike Cherry, chairman of the Federation of Small Businesses, said his group's research showed small business confidence is now falling.\n\n\"There is now real concern about decisions on investment shifting from 'pause' to 'stop' as larger companies look to enact their contingency plans for Brexit,\" he said. \"This would have huge implications for smaller businesses in their supply chains.\"\n\nAttention is now fixed on October's European Council summit, where EU27 leaders will rule on whether \"sufficient progress\" has been made in the Brexit talks to allow them to move on to the next phase.\n\nWhile many businesses would prefer talks on transitional arrangements to begin immediately, a failure to reach the next phase in October would prompt serious anxiety, particularly among trading businesses, said Adam Marshall, director general of the British Chambers of Commerce. \"Many would be concerned,\" he said, if talks between the U.K. and the EU on the post-Brexit transition period were postponed beyond the fall.", "id": "9193786", "details": {"liCnt": 49}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "British business to lobby Brussels on Brexit transition deal", "image": {"timeCrawl": "21:09:00", "uri": "709444729", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:09:00Z", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "source": {"title": "BBC News", "uri": "bbc.co.uk", "id": "264"}, "url": "http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-40922177", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The UK has set out the \"ambitious new customs arrangement\" it wants to secure with the EU after Brexit.\n\nMinisters said the plans would mean the \"freest and most frictionless possible trade\" with the rest of Europe.\n\nThis could include a \"temporary customs union\" after Brexit to prevent border problems as the UK leaves the EU.\n\nBusinesses have been calling for clarity since the UK said it was leaving the EU's customs union as part of Brexit.\n\nCountries in the customs union don't impose tariffs (taxes on imports) on each other's goods.\n\nMembers also agree to impose the same external tariffs on goods from other countries.\n\nSo, for example, a 10% tariff is imposed on some cars imported from outside the customs union, while 7.5% is imposed on roasted coffee.\n\nOther goods - such as soap or slate - have no tariffs.\n\nThe UK's departure from the EU's customs union was confirmed at the weekend in a joint article by Chancellor Philip Hammond and Trade Secretary Liam Fox.\n\nAccording to the newly-published government paper, the UK could ask Brussels to establish a \"temporary customs union\" after it leaves the EU in March 2019.\n\nBut during this period, it would also expect to be able to negotiate its own international trade deals - something it cannot do as an EU customs union member.\n\nOnce this period expires, the UK will look to agree either a \"highly streamlined\" border with the EU, or a new \"partnership\" with no customs border at all.\n\nThe government said the interim arrangements would mean businesses would only have to adjust once to the new arrangements.\n\nAll of this will have to be negotiated with the EU - and the two sides have not yet even started discussing trade matters.\n\nOther obstacles - including the size of the UK's \"divorce bill\" - need to be agreed first.\n\nThe customs union document is the first of a series of papers to be published by the UK government on key negotiation issues.\n\nOn Wednesday it is expected to set out proposals for the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.\n\nThe government, which has faced accusations that cabinet divisions are hampering its negotiations, said the publications reflected the \"huge body of work\" done since the UK voted to leave the EU in June 2016.\n\nAs well as collecting duties, customs checks include enforcing environmental and health and safety rules, cracking down on counterfeit goods, and checking \"certificates of origin\" saying where items have come from.", "id": "9162108", "details": {"liCnt": 293, "gpCnt": 26, {"timeCrawl": "12:50:00", "uri": "709227995", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T12:50:00Z", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "source": {"title": "International Business Times UK", "uri": "ibtimes.co.uk", "id": "713"}, "url": "http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/chancellor-philip-hammond-has-been-hijacked-by-his-pro-brexit-colleagues-1634951", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Labour MP Chuka Umunna blames Eurosceptic cabinet ministers as Tories put on show of unity.\n\nConservative Chancellor Philip Hammond has been \"hijacked\" by his pro-Brexit cabinet colleagues, according to Labour's Chuka Umunna.\n\nThe Vote Leave Watch founder made the claim after Hammond, previously seen as one of the most pro-EU voices in Theresa May's top team, published an article with Eurosceptic International Trade Secretary Liam Fox in the Sunday Telegraph.\n\nThe top Tory duo confirmed that the UK government would split from the EU's single-market and customs union in 2019, while seeking a transitional deal from Brussels so that British businesses do not face a so called \"cliff edge\".\n\n\"We will leave the single market, because there was a vote for change on June 23rd and that is what we will deliver,\" Hammond and Fox wrote.\n\n\"We want our economy to remain strong and vibrant through this period of change. That means businesses need to have confidence that there will not be a cliff edge when we leave the EU in just over twenty months' time.\"\n\nThe show of unity, after a summer of in-fighting over Brexit in the cabinet, prompted Umunna - who wants the UK to remain in the EU's single market and customs union - to speak out.\n\n\"The Chancellor - talked of as the voice of reason in Cabinet - has been taken hostage by those arguing for a job-destroying Brexit,\" he told his Twitter followers. \"There is a consensus that it will be impossible to finalise all the arrangements for our withdrawal from the EU by March 2019. A meaningful transition is essential and it makes sense for us to be in the single market and customs union during that period.\"\n\nLabour's position on staying or splitting from the EU's single-market and customs union is unclear, with Jeremy Corbyn's shadow cabinet issuing contradictory statements on the issue. The party's general election manifesto promised to scrap the Tories' Brexit White Paper and place \"a strong emphasis\" on retaining the benefits of the single-market and customs union.\n\nBut staying in the single-market would mean that the free movement of EU nationals to the UK would continue and maintaining Britain's position in the customs union would mean that the government would not be able to broker free trade deals with non-EU nations.\n\n\"Freedom of movement will end when we leave the European Union. {"timeCrawl": "07:39:00", "uri": "710176816", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T07:39:00Z", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "source": {"title": "Bloomberg Business", "uri": "bloomberg.com", "id": "1749"}, "url": "https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-16/brexit-bulletin-no-hard-border", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "You wait months for the British government to publish a single position paper on Brexit and then two come along almost at once.\n\nA day after Prime Minister Theresa May's team sketched out a vision for future customs arrangements with the European Union, today will see it address the issue of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.\n\nBritish and European negotiators need to show \"flexibility and imagination\" to devise post-Brexit arrangements on the island that preserve free movement of people and goods across the border, the Brexit Department said in an overnight statement.\n\n\"Top of our list is to agree upfront no physical border infrastructure -- that would mean a return to the border posts of the past and is completely unacceptable to the U.K.,\" the department said.\n\nThe 310-mile crossing will form the bloc's only land border with the U.K. after Brexit and it's shaping up to be one of the trickiest parts of the talks. While both sides want to avoid obstacles to trade, Britain's desire to leave the EU's customs union makes that tough.\n\nIrish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar has warned that he won't help the U.K. set up border checks and ordered officials to scale back examining technological solutions to minimize disruption along the frontier. The U.K. will propose remaining a member of the Common Transit Convention to facilitate the movement of goods and new \"trusted trader\" arrangements that would ease commerce for larger companies. Smaller firms, accounting for more than 80 percent of cross-border trade, would be exempt from customs processes.\n\nMeanwhile, Germany's election campaign is touching on Brexit. Chancellor Angela Merkel pledged to protect fishermen in the talks, while opponent Martin Schulz said that a proliferation of U.K. position papers could be \"not meaningful.\"\n\nCabinet Split | The Sun reports on Wednesday that Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and Trade Secretary Liam Fox want any post-Brexit transition to run no longer than a year.\n\nEU Urges Patience | EU negotiator Michel Barnier responded to the U.K.'s customs proposals by stressing the need for agreement first on citizens' rights, a financial settlement and Ireland's border. Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's point person on Brexit, was less diplomatic. \"To be in & out of the Customs Union & 'invisible borders' is a fantasy,\" he tweeted.\n\nRed Tape Warning | In making two suggestions for how post-Brexit customs will work, the U.K acknowledged both would likely inflict red tape on businesses. That will come as a surprise to many who backed Brexit hopeful that leaving the EU would rid them of paperwork.\n\nPolitical Angst | \"Anglo-Saxon political angst\" is spurring a shift in investment from U.S. and British equities to Europe, according to a survey of fund managers by Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Money managers of $587 billion polled from Aug. 4 to 10 cut allocations to the two nations to a post-financial crisis low, while boosting positions in European shares.\n\nNew Party? | James Chapman, a former chief of staff to Brexit Secretary David Davis, plans to launch a new political party to reverse Brexit. His critiques of May's team -- including his former boss -- have raised plenty of eyebrows in Westminster. This morning's was against Trade Secretary Liam Fox. Separately, former Deputy PM Nick Clegg is to publish a book on how to avoid Brexit.\n\nOn the Markets | A divergence in political outlooks between Britain and France is evident in the stock prices of the largest construction companies, according to Bloomberg Gadfly's Lionel Laurent. Shares of Eiffage and Vinci are outperforming Balfour Beatty and Kier Group.\n\nBritish commuters may soon start paying a price for Brexit. Those who travel by rail to work have their fares reset each January depending on how far the retail prices index rose in July. Data out Tuesday showed RPI inflation rising 3.6 percent, the biggest July gain since 2011, after the decision to quit the EU sent the pound sliding.", "id": "9426098", "details": {"liCnt": 33},
