{"timeCrawl": "13:50:00", "uri": "709795357", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:04:00Z", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "source": {"title": "Evening Standard", "uri": "standard.co.uk", "id": "21"}, "url": "https://www.standard.co.uk/business/sean-ogrady-a-buccaneering-brexit-plan-for-bojo-and-fox-in-doublet-and-hose-a3612281.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Not long now. At midnight on March 29, 2019, Britain will leave the European Union.\n\nYou might not think it from some of the commentary, but the sun will still rise the next day, there'll still be a clean water supply, and the trains and buses will still run. Life will go on.\n\nYet while the apocalyptic stuff about life after Europe may be dismissed, we ought to face up to the reality that the most likely possible outcome is a Hard Brexit, whether we like it or not.\n\nIndeed even a so-called \"transition deal\" after March 2019 amounts to Hard Brexit.\n\nThe latest government thinking on that came in that joint article from International Trade Secretary Liam Fox and Chancellor Philip Hammond, with Hard Brexit plainly looming: \"We are both clear that during this period the UK will be outside the single market and outside the customs union and will be a 'third-country' not party to EU treaties,\" they said.\n\nNo matter that this is inconsistent with them also wanting to see that the UK's borders \"must continue to operate smoothly\", that goods bought on the internet \"must still cross borders\", and \"businesses must still be able to supply their customers across the EU\" after Brexit. Cake and eat it, in short. Much the same goes for the Government's \"position papers\" on membership.\n\nThere's been much more sense from Mervyn, now Lord, King. As he said the other day, it is time we made a plan.\n\nI never thought I'd miss the former Governor of the Bank of England so much, his owlish presence in our national life so swiftly eclipsed by his \"rock star\" successor Mark Carney. Yet I can only echo Mervyn's warnings.\n\nFor it does looks increasingly obvious that Britain will not enjoy, if that's the right word, a so-called Soft Brexit, either for the short term -- the \"transition\" or \"implementation\" phase as it's being called -- or in the long run.\n\nFirst, there's no such thing as Soft Brexit anyway. I give Theresa May credit for recognising this in her Lancaster House speech, and the Fox-Hammond article echoes that. Being in the single market means accepting free movement of labour; unacceptable to the British, though the Europeans insist on it. Only Liechtenstein enjoys the perk of membership without free movement, as a micro-state tax haven.\n\nStaying in the EU customs union means we can't sign any trade deals with other countries, so that too is out. In either case we'll have no say in the European Council or the European Parliament. We can try for a bespoke deal, but we'll not get that either, because the EU has no incentive to make Brexit beneficial.\n\nTime has probably already run out to get any \"soft\" deal anyway. A resolution of the Irish border issue is essential before the EU talks move on to broader trade in October. The British have had 600 years to sort out the Irish Question, and this modern iteration of it will not be sorted by David Davis over the summer hols.\n\nTherefore the trade talks may not even start in October and all that is before a fractious and chaotic Parliament gets its hands on things. The talks will get bogged down and fail and we may as well admit it now. Soft Brexit, then, is a false hope. We need a plan. Here are some radical ideas:\n\n*We operate a unilateral free trade policy. So: no tedious trade talks required, and at least our borders are frictionless in one direction, inwards.\n\nWe let into the UK whatever we want, and stop the other stuff, by exception. We take advantage of world prices and bargains, like a giant version of Lidl. If we don't fancy chlorinated chicken from America, we just say no. If we like the idea of tariff-free Ford Mustangs, then in they come. Simple.\n\n*We scrap many restrictions on immigration. It makes the best economic sense.\n\nNot what many voted for last year, but still, needs must and the economy comes first. We offer companies, farms and agencies the right to bring in key workers. That way Goldman Sachs or the LSE would be free to recruit as many Indian, American, South African or Dutch economists as they need; and bulb growers in Lincolnshire too would still be able to employ seasonal labour from Bulgaria, or Bangladesh for that matter.\n\n*We let the pound go. Hard Brexit means sterling will \"overshoot on the downside\" as the euphemism goes. Fine; it will help the adjustment.\n\n*The UK needs to let rip as the Singapore of Europe, a free-trading, flexible, productive powerhouse. A highly competitive economy is the only chance we have in world markets.\n\nThat means relaxing labour laws, a radical shrinking of the state, and an ultra-low corporate and personal taxation regime. It's been called \"Margaret Thatcher's Fourth Term\" and it is no coincidence that so many hard Brexiteers are also hard Thatcherites.\n\nThe UK economic model has to be \"reset\", as Philip Hammond once put it (though he has since retreated from that, a little messily).\n\n*There has to be a shift from consumption to investment, so lower living standards but better infrastructure and capital for future productivity growth -- sacrifices again.\n\nSo what might this brave new world feel like? A harsher, more bracing, more unequal country, for sure.\n\nWe could, in fact, wake up to a Tudor-style kingdom. Scotland and Northern Ireland would go their separate ways, leaving just England and Wales, as Henry VIII might have recognised things: A post-EU \"Littler Britain\" endowed with the same spirit of adventure and commerce as drove the First Elizabeth, Drake, Raleigh and Frobisher.\n\nLondon, then as now, would be at the centre of this great buccaneering maritime power in a Second Elizabethan Age with David Davis, Boris Johnson and Liam Fox in doublet and hose.\n\nWell, there's a plan. More to the point, where's the Government's?", "id": "9289771", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "A buccaneering Brexit plan for BoJo and Fox in doublet and hose", "image": {"timeCrawl": "17:13:00", "uri": "709350654", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:13:00Z", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "source": {"title": "POLITICO", "uri": "politico.eu", "id": "19273"}, "url": "http://www.politico.eu/pro/britain-launches-brexit-charm-offensive-dexeu/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON -- Theresa May has ordered a Brexit charm offensive at home and abroad, coordinated by a new Whitehall team drawn from David Davis' Brexit department and Boris Johnson's Foreign Office.\n\nThe new \"engagement unit\" will exploit the U.K.'s network of European ambassadors in an attempt to directly explain the U.K.'s Brexit strategy to government officials, businesses and other \"stakeholders\" in EU capitals, while also engaging with key interest groups at home, government officials familiar with the strategy told POLITICO.\n\nIt follows a direct \"edict\" from the prime minister herself for the U.K. to redouble efforts to \"get the message out,\" one senior U.K. official said.\n\nLondon has become increasingly sensitive to accusations that Whitehall is underprepared for Brexit. The communications strategy, which hitherto saw the government keep many aspects of its Brexit plan a closely-guarded secret, has allowed the EU side to fill the void and frame the debate, senior officials now believe.\n\nThe change in approach is also symptomatic of an opening up of communications under the new team in No. 10 Downing Street following the June 8 election. Prior to the election, in which Prime Minister Theresa May lost her majority, the prime minster's two co-chiefs of staff ran a very tight operation which controlled communication across all government departments. Both were forced to resign in the wake of the election campaign and May's new team has made deliberate efforts to make government more open.\n\n\"This is about making the most effective use of specialist knowledge across both departments\" -- DExEU spokesperson\n\nThe strategy will particularly focus on EU capitals, ahead of a crucial European Council summit in October that will decide whether negotiations can progress to the next stage and discussions of the future relationship between the U.K. and the EU.\n\n\"As we approach the next stage of negotiations -- discussing our future relationship with the EU once we've left -- we want to ramp up the communications work, campaigns and stakeholder engagement that will enable the government to communicate its messages effectively in EU member states as well as at home,\" a spokesperson from the Department for Exiting the European Union (DExEU) said.\n\n\"Staff from DExEU and FCO are working together to deliver this. This is about making the most effective use of specialist knowledge across both departments.\"\n\nBritain's network of ambassadors in the EU27 capitals, who are coordinated from the Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO) led by Johnson, had been underused in the Brexit process so far, the first official said.\n\n\"Ambassadors know who to talk to and how to talk to them, but they have been a relatively untapped resource ... They can have more influence than an opinion piece by a minister in a newspaper,\" the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.\n\nWith the role of the EU member countries in the Brexit negotiations about to become critical when leaders of the EU27 and Theresa May meet for the October European summit, British officials are conscious of the need to reassure May's counterparts that the U.K. wants a good economic outcome for both sides and a close relationship with the EU after Brexit.\n\nMay's Article 50 letter from March called for a \"deep and special partnership\" with the EU and \"a fair settlement of the U.K.'s rights and obligations as a departing member state.\"\n\nThe new Whitehall unit will ensure ambassadors and their teams are fully briefed on Brexit plans and empowered to reach out to their opposite numbers and other key influencers.\n\nTheir task will be made easier after the U.K. publishes up to 12 position papers, expected in the coming weeks, on crucial aspects of its EU strategy -- part of what officials are calling a \"big push\" to firm up and publicize the Brexit plan.\n\nRobin Niblett, director of the London-based foreign policy think tank Chatham House, said that the U.K. had neglected diplomacy in European capitals in recent years, and welcomed the move toward deeper engagement ahead of Brexit.\n\n\"During the last big push for 'Global Britain,' prior to Brexit, the government raised the number of British diplomats in India, China, the Gulf, while cutting back some of the human capacity in European capitals. Now the government is having to do some re-engineering to bring back that capability to prepare for the pointy end of the Brexit negotiation,\" he said.\n\n\"But the government has to be clear that we are negotiating with Brussels and that we do have clear ideas on everything from fisheries to farming to air traffic control, and on the whole negotiating position with the EU, right down to granular details.\"\n\nThe formation of the new unit is in part a victory for senior DExEU official Alex Ellis, a former ambassador to Brazil and European Commission staffer, who has long argued for greater openness and engagement over Brexit, according to the first official.\n\nEllis, who previously worked in the office of former European Commission President Jos\u00e9 Manuel Barroso, became a director general at DExEU in January. His push, supported by others within the Brexit department, for officials to have more contact with external parties such as foreign governments, businesses, and the media fell foul of No. 10's tight communications management prior to the June general election, the official said.\n\nA third former Whitehall official also said that the ambassador network had been under-used, and unable to feed into the Brexit strategy with political intelligence from EU27 capitals because of the closed-shop nature of Downing Street prior to June's general election.\n\nMay's civil service restructure following the June 2016 EU referendum result -- which created DExEU and sidelined Johnson's Foreign Office -- was seen as a mistake by many senior officials at the time, the ex-official said.", "id": "9127635", {"timeCrawl": "00:25:00", "uri": "710039690", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T00:25:00Z", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "source": {"title": "thetimes.co.uk", "uri": "thetimes.co.uk", "id": "2798"}, "url": "https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/customs-union-plans-are-mere-fantasy-institute-of-directors-guy-verhofstadt-keir-starmer-nicola-sturgeon-hilary-benn-58kmq82k8", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Ministers have been accused of glossing over the complexities of reaching a new customs deal with the European Union as the government published its blueprint for a post-Brexit trading pact.\n\nA 13-page document outlines two alternatives. The first involves the use of new technology to make trade as \"frictionless as possible\". This could mean using numberplate recognition to avoid physical checks at borders.\n\nThe second sets out a customs partnership under which Britain and the EU would have different import tariffs depending on where goods were eventually sold.\n\nWhitehall sources said that under this plan Britain would become \"an agent of the EU\" and mirror much of the existing customs system. Britain would administer the collection of tariffs and there would be no need for...", "id": "9380237", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Customs union plans 'are mere fantasy' says EU {"timeCrawl": "01:07:00", "uri": "710051318", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:50:00Z", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "source": {"title": "farmersjournal.ie", "uri": "farmersjournal.ie", "id": "4778"}, "url": "http://www.farmersjournal.ie/uk-position-means-a-hard-brexit-ifa-301015/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "None of the options outlined by the UK in its position papers on Brexit would safeguard Irish exports to our main export market, according to IFA president Joe Healy.\n\nThe British Government favours an initial transition period after Brexit, during which free movement of goods would continue with the EU. For the long term, the UK wants either a customs border with checks reduced to the minimum, or a \"customs partnership\" without a formal border.\n\nHowever, under any of these three arrangements, London wants \"the ability to forge trade deals around the world\".\n\nHealy said that the UK's insistence on pursuing an independent trade policy \"amounts to a hard Brexit and is potentially very negative for Irish agriculture and the value of our agri-food exports\".\n\nThe customs border option, even with lighter checks, would be \"a very retrograde development for trade on the island of Ireland and between Ireland and Britain, after 45 years of EEC/EU integration,\" he commented.\n\nAny increase in low-cost food imports into the UK that would undermine the value of the UK market would have a devastating effect on the Irish agri-food sector\n\nThe \"customs partnership\" arrangement would not suit Ireland's agri-food industry either, Healy argued, because the UK wants to sign its own trade agreements allowing potentially cheaper food imports at the same time.\n\n\"Any increase in low-cost food imports into the UK that would undermine the value of the UK market would have a devastating effect on the Irish agri-food sector. The potential displacement of Irish food exports from the UK market will in turn destabilise the EU market balance,\" he said.\n\nInstead, the IFA wants the UK and the EU to conclude a free-trade agreement whereby no tariffs or additional checks would apply and the two markets would continue to negotiate trade deals with other partners as a bloc.\n\nForeign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney is expected to respond to the UK position on Wednesday.\n\nLooking forward to responding to UK BREXIT paper on Ireland tomorrow - we'll work with EU partners to negotiate best deal possible with UK -- {"timeCrawl": "09:19:00", "uri": "709676229", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T09:19:00Z", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "source": {"title": "POLITICO", "uri": "body": "Brussels reasserted its position that the terms of the UK's divorce must be settled before they will discuss plans for future relations between the two.\n\nThe EU on Tuesday flatly rebuffed the U.K.'s first formal proposal on a post-Brexit trading relationship, saying a new position paper released by London was an effort to leapfrog divorce proceedings.\n\nIn its response, Brussels noted that withdrawal terms must be settled first -- a position they believe is strongly supported by Article 50, the brief provision in the EU treaty that sets the parameters for a nation's withdrawal from the bloc.\n\n\"We take note of the U.K.'s request for an implementing period and its preferences as regards the future relationship, but we will only address them once we have made sufficient progress on the terms of the orderly withdrawal,\" the EU said in a statement. \"An agreement on a future relationship between the EU and the UK can only be finalized once the UK has become a third country.\"\n\nThe EU also rejected the U.K.'s attempted assertion that future trade might be as easy and efficient as it is now, as a member of the bloc.\n\n\"As Michel Barnier has said on several occasions, 'frictionless trade' is not possible outside the single market and customs union,\" the EU statement said referring to its chief negotiator.\n\nOverall, the EU said it welcomed the first in a series of papers intended to lay out the U.K.'s negotiating position, which many in Brussels have viewed as a mystery.\n\n\"We see the U.K.'s publication of a series of position papers as a positive step towards now really starting phase one of the negotiations. {"timeCrawl": "08:45:00", "uri": "709663144", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T08:45:00Z", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "source": {"title": "postandparcel.info", "uri": "postandparcel.info", "id": "7114"}, "url": "http://postandparcel.info/81766/news/uk-suggesting-temporary-customs-union-with-eu/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "As part of its preparations for exiting the European Union, the UK government has published a new position document and put forward a strategy which could include a \"temporary customs union\" to maintain the \"freest and most frictionless possible trade\" during the transition.\n\nDavid Davis, Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union, said he envisaged the temporary accord being \"as close as we can to the current arrangements\" and added that the transition phase could last for about two years.\n\nThe temporary customs uion proposal has been floated in response to concerns from UK businesses about the dangers of the UK leaving on a \"cliff edge\" (i.e. exiting the EU without new trade accords and customs arrangements already in place).\n\nPerhaps predictably, the UK's opposing parties have criticized the government's plans but the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) welcomed the them as \"encouraging\".\n\nIn a statement issued today (15 August), Josh Hardie, CBI Deputy Director-General, said: \"Companies will welcome the progress Government has made today in publishing these papers. Over the past year, businesses have been providing policymakers with the evidence, ideas and solutions to make a success of Brexit.\n\n\"So it's encouraging to see that these papers propose a time-limited interim period and a customs system that is as barrier-free as possible.\n\n\"We at the CBI have always been clear that new ideas on crucial issues like this should be brought to the table quickly. But the clock is ticking and what matters now is giving companies the confidence to continue investing as quickly as possible.\"\n\nAnd focusing on the customs issues, Hardie said: \"Business wants to see as frictionless a customs system as possible, with a strong emphasis on digital systems that make it easier to trade.\n\n\"But to secure frictionless trade, negotiations on regulation, tariff and non-tariff barriers will have to take place. It shows a lack of decisive leadership and it lowers our standing in the world.\n\n\"The big opportunity of Brexit, and sure there are technical things that need to be sorted out and that's where the detail comes in, is for us to be able to open ourselves up to do trade deals with the rest of the world.\"\n\nThe leading Brexiteer added: \"We have an American president in Donald Trump who is really keen as mustard to do a deal with us.\n\n\"Under the plan revealed by David Davis today, we would not be able to sign that trade deal until President Trump was nearing the end of his second term.\n\n\"This is not what we voted for - we voted to leave, not for transitional arrangements.\"\n\nAnd he added that he fears big business will seek to extend the initial transition period beyond the two years Mr Davis said it will last for.\n\nThe position paper released by the Brexit department was also criticised by the Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon - who called the position \"daft\".\n\nShe wrote on Twitter: \"Seems UK Government is back to its daft 'have cake and eat it' approach to Brexit. They should commit to staying in single market and CU, period.\"\n\nMeanwhile the Brexit Select Committee chairman said the Government's \"have their trade cake and eat it\" stance does not provide the certainty business needs.\n\nBut disagreeing with Mr Farage, Hilary Benn said ministers should consider staying in the European customs union for the long term.\n\nThe Labour MP said: \"Six months on from the Brexit white paper, UK businesses are today still no clearer about what will actually happen to our trade with the EU after March 2019.\n\n\"It is all very well for ministers to say they want to have their trade cake and eat it once the transition is over, but this doesn't amount to certainty for companies trying to plan ahead.\n\n\"We have no idea whether the EU will agree to the Government's proposals and if they are rejected, then what?\"\n\nEurosceptic Tory MP Nigel Evans said Britain must be able to negotiate new trade deals during any temporary arrangements.\n\nThe former shadow Welsh secretary said the Government's position was not an ideological measure but a practical one in response to shortfalls in the Lisbon treaty.\n\nHe added: \"But, and this is a huge but, the {"timeCrawl": "11:31:00", "uri": "709191350", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:31:00Z", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "source": {"title": "newsletter.co.uk", "uri": "newsletter.co.uk", "id": "2767"}, "url": "http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/opinion/joint-article-by-ministers-gives-some-brexit-clarity-1-8101757", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The joint article by Philip Hammond and Liam Fox in yesterday's Sunday Telegraph was important.\n\nThe Chancellor of the Exchequer and the International Trade Secretary came together to write that a period of transition would be needed after the United Kingdom left the European Union in 2019.\n\nThis appeared to be a softening of Mr Fox's position, who is a firm Brexiteer and had previously seemed wary about a transition phase when he said there was no Cabinet agreement for such.\n\nBut the article also appeared to be a hardening of Mr Hammond's position, because it said that the UK would leave both the European single market and customs union. He had previously appeared to suggest that we might remain in one of the two arrangements, as part of a softer Brexit.\n\nThe article is welcome for two reasons: it seems to be a deliberate attempt to demonstrate unity, after what at times has seemed like an alarming free-for-all in the Cabinet.\n\nIt ought to hardly need be said that ministers should speak publicly with a single voice, and air their disagreements privately. That this has not been happening is an illustration of the fact that Theresa May's ministers have no fear of her. If it continues she will have little option but to sack someone senior to make an example of them, regardless of the fact that her own position is precarious.\n\nYesterday's article is also welcome for bringing some clarity to the government's intentions.\n\nQuitting the customs union is the more obvious route for Britain to follow, because otherwise it will not be possible for the UK to strike its own trade deals.\n\nBut there is no point denying that leaving the customs union is the development that will cause most difficulties with the Irish land border. Local politicians will have to plan for Brexit with that in mind. (Reuters) - Britain's car industry welcomed government plans for a interim customs union agreement with the European Union after Brexit but said the sector also needed to retain full participation in the single market to give firms certainty.\n\nBritain's major carmakers, all of whom are foreign-owned, have warned over the last year that any tariffs on exports or imports or a loss of the frictionless trade with their biggest overseas market could damage the viability of their plants.\n\nOn Tuesday, Britain outlined plans for a future customs agreement with the European Union and an interim deal to ease companies' Brexit concerns.\n\n\"It is encouraging that government recognises the need for interim arrangements which must be in place until the new relationship with our biggest trading partner is implemented,\" the Chief Executive of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders Mike Hawes said.\n\n\"However, to maintain frictionless trade and ensure business only has to {"timeCrawl": "13:25:00", "uri": "709784063", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T03:44:00Z", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "source": {"title": "BBC", "uri": "bbc.com", "id": "489"}, "url": "http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-40900189", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The Republic of Ireland's customs authorities do not have the resources to deal with a hard Brexit, a former enforcement manager has warned.\n\nSean Kelleher monitored the 310-mile (499km) stretch along the border from Carlingford Lough in the east to Lough Foyle in the west.\n\nHe said Revenue would be required to increase staffing to deal with \"challenging\" post-Brexit issues.\n\nThe UK is due to leave the EU by the end of March 2019.\n\nThe former customs manager, who served between 2007 and 2015, said commercial traffic would be subjected to certain customs controls but private vehicles should not face too much disruption.\n\n\"The reality is we will be obliged to maintain EU regulations and that will determine how those checks are carried out and to what level,\" Mr Kelleher told BBC news NI.\n\n\"For commercial cargo moving north to south, I would expect that all importers and exporters will register with Revenue for online declarations.\"\n\nMr Kelleher said \"trade facilitation stations\" should be \"judicially placed somewhere near the border\" to carry out checks on commercial traffic.\n\n\"You won't need too many if you are only doing a percentage check,\" he said. \"For example, if you have traffic going west from Derry to Donegal, you may require a facilitation station, one at least in Donegal.\n\n\"For the midlands, you would need one certainly around the Monaghan border or somewhere close. For the east coast, one perhaps around the Dundalk area.\n\n\"It's all subject to what Revenue decides. They may not necessarily be in those areas but they would be the locations I would believe are where the trade facilitation stations should be located,\" he added.\n\nThe border separating Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic will become an EU-UK frontier after Brexit.\n\nMr Kelleher said he could not see a return of fixed customs posts that existed from 1923 until the creation of the EU Single Market in 1993.\n\n\"Logistically it wouldn't prove possible and politically it's unpopular,\" he said.\n\nThe former customs manager said \"all crossings points would have to be monitored\" as they would be ideal for people \"with a mind to do a bit of smuggling\".\n\nHe also said that random checks could be carried out by mobile patrols on crossing points and roadways along the border.\n\n\"There's going to be some disruption. It may not be major but if vehicles are called to trade facilitation stations, that's a disruption.\n\n\"It means that vehicles are going to be delayed until goods are examined and documents processed. If there are problems, the goods may be detained.\"\n\nIn a statement, Revenue said its focus was on facilitating trade by maximising the free flow of goods.\n\nA spokeswoman said it was in the early stages of developing its main customs processes to cater for the phased introduction of the Union Customs Code which it said \"envisages paperless customs systems, managed by electronic processing\".\n\n\"The operation of customs post-Brexit and the resulting impact on business will be defined to a great extent by the terms of the agreement between the EU and the UK,\" she said.\n\n\"The full impacts will not be clear until negotiations have been finalised.\"\n\nA series of papers is being published, including one this week covering what will happen to the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic after the UK has left the EU.\n\nMr Kelleher said a generation had grown up in the border region facing no checks, and would find changes difficult to accept.\n\n\"The reality is there is no border. People can drive across the land frontier and not realise they're in Northern Ireland.,\" he said.\n\n\"How you control that will be a major challenge for Revenue.\"", "id": "9285455", "details": Ireland.\n\n\"The emphasis on the priority areas identified by the Government, including the Common Travel Area, the Good Friday Agreement, North/South co-operation and avoiding a hard Border, is welcome,\" the statement said. \"Protecting the peace process is crucial and it must not become a bargaining chip in the negotiations.\"\n\nThe statement added that the Government hopes that enough progress can be made in Brexit talks to advance to the next stage of negotiations, which will outline the future EU-UK relationship.\n\n\"As these papers are inputs to the negotiation process between of the UK's position paper on future customs arrangements, Ms McGuinness said it reflected a view that it would be possible for Britain to enjoy the full benefits of membership while being outside the EU.\n\n\"The idea of leaving and coming back on your own terms is quite an ask,\" she said.\n\nFianna F\u00e1il's Brexit spokesman Stephen Donnelly said the paper was \"full of propaganda\" and did not advance the UK's position. \"Essentially this document is a restating of the Brexiteers' opening position. "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "LONDON, Aug 15 (Reuters) - Britain's car industry welcomed government plans for a interim customs union agreement with the European Union after Brexit but said the sector also needed to retain full participation in the single market to give firms certainty.\n\nBritain's major carmakers, all of whom are foreign-owned, have warned over the last year that any tariffs on exports or imports or a loss of the frictionless trade with their biggest overseas market could damage the viability of their plants.\n\nOn Tuesday, Britain outlined plans for a future customs agreement with the European Union and an interim deal to ease companies' Brexit concerns.\n\n\"It is encouraging that government recognises the need for interim arrangements which must be in place until the new relationship with our biggest trading partner is implemented,\" the Chief Executive of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders Mike Hawes said.\n\n\"However, to maintain frictionless trade and ensure business only has to adjust to one change, interim arrangements must retain membership of a customs union with the EU and full participation in the single market.\" (Reporting by Andy Bruce and Costas Pitas)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your Furious Farage blasts transition & warns of Brexit dragging for 10 YEARS", "image": "http://cdn.images.express.co.uk/img/dynamic/1/750x445/841357.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "concepts": [{"label": {"eng": "Nigel Farage"}, "id": "303060", "score": 4, "type": "person", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigel_Farage"}, {"label": {"eng": "European Union"}, "id": "303064", "score": 4, "type": "org", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union"}, {"label": {"eng": "UK Independence Party"}, "id": "318261", "score": 3, "type": "org", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UK_Independence_Party"}, {"label": {"eng": "Dither"}, "id": "364672", "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dither"}, {"label": {"eng": "Customs union"}, "id": "382637", "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customs_union"}, {"label": {"eng": "BBC News Magazine"}, "id": "387324", "score": 3, "type": "org", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_News"}, {"label": {"eng": "United Kingdom withdrawal from the European Union"}, "id": "1268836", "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union"}], "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "id": 108, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict"}], "time": "12:38:00"}
{"timeCrawl": "00:50:00", "uri": "709515198", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:16:00Z", "sim": 0.4431372582912445, "source": {"title": "Verdict", "uri": "verdict.co.uk", "id": "19067"}, "url": "https://www.verdict.co.uk/brexit-leaders-man-charge-david-davis-brexit/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "In terms of Brexit, there are few more important people than David Davis.\n\nAfter Brexit, Davis was appointed secretary of state for leaving the European Union, a brand new title made just for him.\n\nAnd, in terms of experience, Davis is a safe pair of hands to mastermind Brexit.\n\nDuring his time in office, Davis has held numerous senior positions within government.\n\nHe was a minister of state for Europe from 1994 to 1997, chairman of the public accounts committee between 1997 and 2001, and shadow home secretary from 2003 to 2008.\n\nDespite his opposition to abortion, fertility treatment, embryo research and LGBT rights, Davis is noted for his passionate support of civil liberties.\n\nAs shadow home secretary, he campaigned against the Labour government's plan to introduce national identity cards. He's also been unafraid to team up with Labour MPs, despite his Conservative background, to fight on issues of civil liberty.\n\nIn fact, once he felt so strongly that he resigned from being an MP in order to raise awareness of civil liberty issues and the UK government's involvement in torture.\n\nConsidered a passionate eurosceptic, Davis has nonetheless been on both sides of the Brexit debate at one time or another.\n\nAt the divisive signing of the Maastricht treaty (the precursor to the EU as we know it) he acted as pro-EU prime minister John Major's chief whip.\n\nHowever, on the other hand, Davis has expressed anti-EU sentiment time and again. Essentially, Davis' opposition to the EU centres around his belief that Europe stagnates growth and trade for Britain. Writing for ConservativeHome, Davis outlines his opposition to the EU:\n\nEconomic growth on the continent has ground to a halt. Since the turn of the century, the EU has grown at a third of the rate of the global average, and the Eurozone has grown even more slowly than that. Europe's share of global GDP is falling, as is its share of global trade. This trend is expected to continue. When we last voted on our membership in 1975, trade with Europe was the vast majority of our total trade. This has fallen since then, and in 2008 the UK started to trade more with the rest of the world than with Europe. The fact is that Europe is becoming less and less important. The Euro has become a destroyer of jobs. Unemployment across the continent is running at almost 10 per cent, with youth unemployment double that at 20 per cent. For individual countries, these figures are even worse... Then there is the Schengen Zone. The passport-less travel area once held up as the pinnacle of European integration is crumbling before our very eyes. The migration crisis that has brought more than a million refugees to Europe's shores, with many more expected to come, is a stake in the heart of a borderless Europe... From the faulty European Arrest Warrant, that has led to innocent Brits being detained for months overseas in terrible conditions without trial, to the slow steady creep of the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice, we are increasingly finding that our justice system is incompatible with the one on the continent. So the problems facing the EU are mounting up. Economic stagnation, high debt, high unemployment, high regulation, ineffective foreign policy and failing internal policies.\n\nEssentially, there are few areas of the EU that Davis doesn't hold in contempt.\n\nHowever, despite numerous oppositions to the European Court of Human Rights, he has also suggested he wishes the UK to remain within its jurisdiction.\n\nHe suggests that to leave the ECHR would encourage other countries with worse human rights records to do so too.\n\nWhile Theresa May and the rest of her cabinet (led by Davis) have been involved in working out general negotiating positions for Brexit, it is Davis who'll do the bulk of the actual negotiating.\n\nIt is him who'll be sitting down with EU leaders to hammer out the specifics of any deals between Britain and the EU.\n\nIn an article on ConservativeHome, Davis laid out some general policy positions:\n\nOf course, as it stands, much of the negotiating is going on behind closed doors but we know that the general plan is to pull the UK out of the single market and the EU custom's union, even during a transitional phase between Brexit and fully leaving the EU.", "id": "9187151", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "05:18:00", "uri": "709585030", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T05:18:00Z", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "source": {"title": "POLITICO", "uri": "politico.eu", "id": "19273"}, "url": "http://www.politico.eu/newsletter/playbook/politico-brussels-playbook-uk-lays-out-customs-plan-anti-competitive-ice-skaters-german-electioneering/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "By Judy Dempsey | Send tips here | Subscribe for free | Listen to Playbook's EU Confidential podcast | Playbook desktop version\n\nGreetings from Berlin, I'm Judy Dempsey from Carnegie Europe and editor-in-chief of its Strategic Europe blog.\n\nQUOTE DU JOUR: \"I'd be very interested to see how the dogs are expressing that interest.\" Commission spokeswoman Annika Breidthardt in response to a question from journalists about whether British pets could switch their passports to remain in the EU.\n\nCOMMISSION -- VESTAGER INVESTIGATES ANTI-COMPETITIVE ICE SKATING: The European Commission is close to finalizing an antitrust investigation into a complaint by two Dutch speed skaters, whose governing body the International Skating Union (ISU) banned them from taking part in a lucrative Dubai race. The ISU objected to the race on the grounds it would attract gamblers. The skaters complained the ISU was abusing its dominant position over skating, restricting their professional opportunities and limiting the sport's reach. Nicholas Hirst reports European Commissioner for Competition Margrethe Vestager has taken a personal interest in the case, telling one of the skaters on Twitter: \"I will look into the matter.\"\n\nCOUNCIL -- EU AGREES ON COMMON LINE OVER NORTH KOREA: Jacopo Barigazzi has this analysis for Playbook of Monday's meeting of diplomats in the Political and Security Committee: EU security officials on Monday approved a common EU line on North Korea's nuclear arsenal escalation, as part of the bloc's efforts to play a diplomatic role in the crisis. \"There's a urgent need for de-escalation,\" said EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini in a statement released after the meeting. Mogherini added the EU is ready to \"consider further appropriate measures\" in line with the U.N. Security Council.\n\nThe EU will convey its message on the crisis \"by reaching out to the Republic of Korea, the United States, China, Russia and Japan, as well as the DPRK,\" the statement continued, a nod to the long-stalled \"six-party talks\" -- the regional format favored by Beijing. But the EU won't seek a bigger role in the crisis as, for example, a mediator, officials told Jacopo -- that wasn't even on the meeting's agenda.\n\nMIGRATION -- LIBYA CROSSINGS DOWN IN JULY: Frontex, the EU's border agency, confirmed the number of migrants arriving in Italy across the central Mediterranean route fell by 57 percent in July compared to the previous month, the lowest level since 2014.\n\nMerkel says no to linking EU funds to receiving refugees: Rejecting the proposal made by SPD leader Martin Schulz to only disburse EU funds to countries that accept migrants, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said: \"This is not the European solidarity that I am imagining.\"\n\nItaly feels abandoned by Europe: \"Italy is contributing, but we cannot cope with this burden alone,\" said Angelino Alfano, Italy's foreign minister, before acknowledging \"the only solution\" to ensuring fewer migrants reach Italy \"is in Libya.\"\n\nBREXIT CORNER ...\n\nUK sets out Brexit customs plan: In the first of up to 12 position papers to be published before the October Council summit, the U.K. government laid out two options for a \"close association\" with the EU in customs matters during a transition period, confirming the country will leave the customs union.\n\nThe first option would see it manage a new customs border with the EU, unilaterally simplifying requirements on EU goods entering the country as much as possible and providing border \"facilitations\" to reduce and remove trade barriers. Under the second option, the U.K. and EU would negotiate a \"new customs partnership,\" aligning their approaches to customs -- an option which, the DExEU briefing said, would negate the need for a customs border.\n\nBritish business to lobby Brussels over need for transition: A senior U.K. business leader told POLITICO industry will start pushing EU Brexit negotiators to accelerate talks over a transitional period in a bid to stop companies from going over a cliff-edge.\n\nNorwegian PM cautious about UK membership of EFTA: Norway's Prime Minister Erna Solberg, who is facing a tough election battle, told Reuters the U.K. may find membership of the European Free Trade Area challenging, even during a transition period. \"There would be a cost they would have to share, and an authority outside their border that could impose binding decisions on them, which is not entirely in line with what they've said they want,\" said Solberg.\n\nCorbyn bets on Brexit fatigue: Britain's Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has made a success of mostly ignoring Brexit and choosing instead to focus his energy (and campaigning) on public services. But with the party readying for its annual September conference and Brexit negotiations heating up, Labour MPs told Annabelle Dickson and Charlie Cooper that internal disputes over membership of the single market and whether or not to promise a second referendum on the terms of the Brexit deal will reach boiling point.\n\nBrexiteers take on Hammond: Pro-Brexit campaign group Leave.EU called on supporters to pressure the local Conservative Party to ditch Chancellor Philip Hammond as its candidate at the next election, saying he is plotting to stop Brexit, Reuters reports. \"He is part of a cabal of Westminster MPs who believe that if they can delay exit, they can overturn the wishes of the 52 percent who despite threats from the political classes drew upon the courage of their conviction at the ballot box,\" said Leave.EU Chairman Arron Banks in a letter sent to voters in Hammond's constituency.\n\nUK -- THERESA MAY TO VISIT JAPAN AUGUST 30: The British PM will discuss defense and security cooperation as well as trade and investment opportunities with her counterpart Shinz\u014d Abe on her three-day visit.\n\nGERMAN ELECTION PRIORITIES ...\n\nThings that won't be raised and won't happen during the German election campaign ...\n\nEnergy prices: German household power prices, some of the highest in Europe (after Denmark), reached a record high in early 2017, despite the fact wholesale prices are sinking. For the average four-person household, annual prices vary by as much as almost \u20ac470. Meanwhile, Merkel's Energiewende (a shift to complete reliance on renewable energy by 2050), which the chancellor unilaterally announced in 2011, still needs infrastructure that saves wind energy, links the northern (windy) parts of Germany to the (non-windy) southern regions, and makes the renewables sector competitive.\n\nNord Stream 2: Merkel's conservative bloc and her Social Democrat one-time allies, now opponents, want to steer clear of discussions of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline, which would deliver Russian gas to Germany. Ever since Merkel became chancellor in November 2005, she has supported what she has dubbed a purely \"commercial project.\" Forget the fact former SPD Chancellor Gerhard Schr\u00f6der took a job with Gazprom weeks after he lost the election to Merkel in 2005, is now a big-shot in Nord Stream 2 and has just joined the board of Rosneft, Russia's state-owned oil giant.\n\nDieselgate: The Dieselgate scandal won't get a look-in in any serious way either -- all the established parties are too connected to the car industry. Americans who bought German diesel cars will be compensated, Europeans won't, at least not for now. In the meantime, forget about trying to resell your diesel auto in Germany.\n\nDigitization: Merkel likes to talk about the issue but only at industry fora. Everyone know what it means for jobs, education and migration policy. Take a look at this report by McKinsey: \"Germany ... lacks large-scale consumer tech companies and online business-transaction platforms to rival global giants such as Apple, Alphabet and Alibaba. As a result, Germany runs a digital services trade deficit with the United States of over 4 percent of total services trade.\"\n\nCampaigning: Forget about leaflets and door-to-door canvasing. In my dozen or so years here, not one candidate knocked on the door, and the only party to drop a leaflet in my letterbox was the far-right NPD.\n\nMerkel rules out coalition: \"Since there are no natural coalitions, everyone is now fighting for themselves,\" German Chancellor Angela Merkel told Deutschlandfunk.\n\nSPD say Merkel wants to join Trump's weapons madness: The September federal election will be \"a vote on whether Germany remains a peaceful power or joins Trump's weapons madness,\" said Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel. Like Trump, Merkel's Christian Democrats \"want to put all their money into weapons and cut social spending,\" he said. The chancellor's position to \"practically voluntarily bend over and promise to double the German military budget after the Bundestag election is nothing less than a sign to Trump that they will give in to his pressure.\"\n\nPOLAND -- PiS WANTS WAR REPARATIONS: Poland's Law and Justice (PiS) party sure knows how to needle Germany. PiS leader Jaros\u0142aw Kaczy\u0144ski said at a convention in July that Poland never received compensation for the massive war damages it suffered in World War II, losses which \"we have really still not made up for.\" PiS deputy Arkadiusz Mularczyk said a report from parliamentary experts on whether Poland can claim reparations from Germany should be ready by the middle of August and would then be handed to the government. He added that seeking war reparations from Germany was a \"moral duty.\" Polish Foreign Minister Witold Waszczykowski said in a weekend interview: \"Today we have powerful ... opposition against raising this issue at all in talks with Germany.\" Germany's next foreign minister, you've been warned.\n\nFRANCE -- MACRON CHOOSES MARSEILLE FOR HIS SUMMER HOLIDAY: Emmanuel Macron will spend his time off in August in Marseille. Politically, the choice makes sense -- the president is following his own order to his ministers to remain within a few hours of Paris through the summer break. But more than that, it represents a major vote of confidence in a city with a growing reputation as an ideal weekend getaway, and a sunny foil to Paris' seriousness, writes Nicholas Vinocur.\n\nAUSTRIA -- SP\u00d6 CAMPAIGN ADVISER ARRESTED IN ISRAEL: Austria's governing Social Democrats (SP\u00d6) terminated their relationship with Tal Silberstein, a key election adviser, on Monday after reports emerged he was allegedly the subject of a money-laundering investigation in Israel.\n\nSLOVAKIA -- FICO TO MEET COALITION PARTNERS: Attempts to reach a new agreement between the three parties making up Slovakia's Smer-led government are set to continue today when Prime Minister Robert Fico meets leaders of the Slovak National Party and Most-H\u00edd, the country's ethnic Hungarian party.\n\nSERBIA -- KOSOVO DIVISION? Ivica Da\u010di\u0107, Serbia's foreign minister, in an article in state-owned newspaper Vecernje Novosti Sunday suggested that in order to avoid future conflict, what belongs to Serbs and Albanians in Kosovo should be divided up, although he did not explain what this might mean in practice. He said an Association of Serbian Municipalities should be established in the south of Kosovo, similar to the one already due to be set up in the mainly Serb north under the EU-mediated agreement between Belgrade and Pristina. To ensure the security of Serbian Orthodox churches in Kosovo, Da\u010di\u0107 proposed the creation of \"independent monastic communities,\" which would have a certain degree of territorial autonomy.\n\nWestern powers put pressure on Kosovo MPs: Attempts to elect a new speaker in Pristina have failed four times due to many MPs not showing up to vote. Without a speaker, a new government cannot be formed, resulting in the embassies of the U.S., France, Germany, Italy and the U.K. releasing a statement of concern.\n\nFINLAND -- BREAKAWAY FINNS PARTY STRUGGLES TO REGISTER: Terho Sampo, the chairman of New Alternative, a group of former True Finns MPs who left the far-right party after MEP Jussi Halla-aho was elected its leader, is struggling to gather the 5,000 signatures needed to register his new Blue Reform party. \"People are taking time off after a fraught political spring,\" said Sampo, who was also an MEP before entering Finland's national parliament.\n\nBELARUS -- OBSERVERS WELCOME AT ZAPAD WAR GAMES: Minsk is pulling out all the stops, for now, to make this year's Zapad military exercises between Belarus and Russia as transparent as possible. Belarus Defense Minister Andrei Ravkov told Russian news agency TASS: \"We will invite our partners to come and see with their own eyes that the exercise does not have the goals they claim it does. A total of over 80 observers will be invited.\" Here's the Economist's take.\n\nWHO SPENDS THE MOST ON SUMMER VACATIONS? Luxembourgish residents spent the most per trip on transport and accommodation (around \u20ac740) in 2015, followed by Austrians (around \u20ac610) and Maltese (around \u20ac590). On average in the EU, residents spent around \u20ac320 per holiday.\n\nUS -- TRUMP SAYS 'RACISM IS EVIL': U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday denounced the white supremacist groups whose rally in Virginia on Saturday turned deadly, more directly condemning racism than in his initial, widely panned response.\n\nPLAYBOOK COULDN'T HAPPEN WITHOUT Harry Cooper, Quentin Ari\u00e8s, Zoya {"timeCrawl": "07:09:00", "uri": "709627554", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T07:09:00Z", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "source": {"title": "Quartz", "uri": "qz.com", "id": "1915"}, "url": "https://qz.com/1052893/the-eu-may-make-it-easier-for-britain-to-sign-a-post-brexit-china-trade-deal/", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "The European Union's plan to make it harder for China to acquire European companies could make it easier for Britain to forge a trade deal with Beijing after Brexit.\n\nThat's one scenario following a \"hard Brexit,\" in which the UK retains few, if any, special links to the EU. This would free the UK from the bloc's rules and restrictions, like the one that requires trade deals to be negotiated by Brussels on behalf of member states. Considering Britain's desire to sign its own trade deals to bolster its economy post-Brexit, it could emphasize its differences to the EU as part of the negotiations.\n\nBrussels is expected to push back on Chinese takeovers of European companies in key areas such as infrastructure and manufacturing by pushing for more \"rigorous screening,\" according to the Financial Times (paywall). This is after months of reports that the EU and US have been fretting about China gaining a technological edge by taking over key companies abroad.\n\nWith Britain heading towards a \"hard Brexit,\" it will be pretty desperate for new trade deals to replace the ones it benefited from as a member of the EU. Prime Minister Theresa May has dispatched key members of her cabinet around the world for talks, pledging to seal its trade deals (pay wall) as soon as possible with major economies.\n\nEven if the EU makes it harder for China to seal deals, there are obstacles for Britain to overcome when it comes to convincing China to give it more attention. The uncertainty about the effects of Brexit has dampened GDP growth, and the potential destabilizing impact of a \"hard Brexit\" (paywall) may put off investors from sinking money into the economy in the future.\n\nBut China appears to have a strong appetite for investing in Britain. Even when its ambassador to UK government grumbled about its $20 billion-plus nuclear power deal being put on hold (it is partly financed by a Chinese consortium), he also noted that \"I hope the UK will keep its door open to China\" (paywall).\n\nChina is the sixth-largest investor in Britain, according to Grant Thornton. London, in particular, has been the destination for large-scale investments, including China's CC Land buying the iconic \"Cheesegrater\" skyscraper for \u00a31 billion ($1.29 billion) earlier this year.\n\nThere are some suggestions that Chinese investors are taking a breather while they see how Brexit talks shape up. But Dealogic says that more $15.6 billion worth of M&A deals by Chinese buyers are currently pending in the UK. {"timeCrawl": "16:15:00", "uri": "709860517", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:15:00Z", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "source": {"title": "inta.org", "uri": "inta.org", "id": "14249"}, "url": "https://www.inta.org/INTABulletin/Pages/Europe_Update_7214.aspx", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "While summer is usually quiet in Brussels, with the EU Parliament in recess until August 28, the past month included several notable developments.\n\nNo Summer Recess for Brexit\n\nBrexit continues to dominate the summer in Brussels, as the second round of negotiations between the EU and the UK took place on July 17\u201220 and the third one is due on August 28\u201231.\n\nWhile both parties are currently focusing on the main priorities (such as the \"bill\" to be paid by the UK after leaving, the fate of EU citizens living in the UK and UK citizens living in the EU, and Ireland's border), intellectual property and trademarks have not yet been discussed.\n\nNonetheless, before the summer, INTA (together with other IP associations) met with the European Commission's representatives of the 'Internal Market and Sectorial Policies' Cluster of the Task Force for the Preparation and Conduct of the Negotiations with the United Kingdom under Article 50 TEU.\n\nINTA is now developing its positions on trademarks, designs, and geographical indications (GIs).\n\nAs part of INTA's efforts, Anna Carboni (Redd Solicitors LLP, UK), a member of INTA's \"Brexit Rapid Response Group,\" attended a meeting on July 27 in London at the UK Intellectual Property Office (UKIPO), to discuss the issue of exhaustion of rights.\n\nFor more information on Brexit and INTA's advocacy efforts, please visit the dedicated Brexit Topic Portal here.\n\nBoard of Directors to Visit Brussels in September\n\nThe September meeting of the Association's Board of Directors will take place in Brussels. As part of the Board's Brussels visit, INTA is organizing a \"Government Relations Program\" dedicated to IP in Europe on September 11. This program will feature speakers from various EU institutions, officials from third countries, and brand owners. The objective is for government officials to brief and exchange views with the Board on the current hot topics and future policy and regulatory trends of relevance to brand owners.\n\nThe program will be followed by an \"INTA Partners in Europe\" cocktail reception, aimed at providing Board members with an opportunity to network with EU and third-country officials, Brussels-based associations and stakeholders, brand owners' representatives in Brussels, and of course local INTA members.\n\n41.3 Million Fake Goods Seized by EU Customs in 2016\n\nAs reported in a recent INTA blog post, on July 20, the European Commission - Directorate-General for Taxation and Customs (DG TAXUD) published its annual report on customs enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPRs) at EU borders.\n\nThere were 63,000 detentions in 2016 (81,000 in 2015), for a total of 41.3 million articles (43.7 million in 2015) seized, representing a value of more than EUR 672 million (EUR 640 million in 2015). IPR infringements in general, and counterfeiting in particular, remains a wide and important phenomenon even though customs' performance at tackling it seemed to have improved (the number of intercepted articles rose by 2 percent compared to 2015).\n\nThis report is a statistics-based document covering the year 2016 and does not entail any policy or political recommendation. It is mainly aimed at feeding information to customs authorities to ultimately help them better understand their shortcomings and areas of improvements with regards to customs enforcement of IP rights.\n\nFor more information on INTA's anticounterfeiting activities in Europe and how you can be involved, please contact Maysa Razavi, INTA's Advisor on Anticounterfeiting, at mrazavi@inta.org.\n\nAlthough every effort has been made to verify the accuracy of items in the INTA Bulletin, readers are urged to check independently on matters of specific concern or And has that moment arrived yet?\n\nEasyJet customers 'vomit' in severe turbulence which forced plane to divert\n\n'The answer to the first question is \"it is not impossible\"; the answer to the second is \"no\".\n\n'But I would be betraying my principles if I did not make it clear that country must always come before party.'\n\nAlthough Soubry is one of the most vocal pro-EU Tory MPs, she has never been this explicit about how she could quit the party over Brexit.\n\nIt comes as a joint statement from Chancellor Philip Hammond and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox ruled out Britain staying in the EU customs union, even as part of a transitional deal.\n\nSoubry has previously said that a good Brexit deal would have to involve the UK staying in the customs union.\n\nPerseid meteors bring stunning shower of shooting stars across the UK\n\nAnd James Chapman, who was a special adviser to George Osborne and then later to David Davis, claimed last week that ministers say there is a space open for a pro-European party.\n\nApparently pro-EU MPs want to form a new party called the Democrats.\n\nAlthough Soubry is the only MP from any party to publicly {"timeCrawl": "14:17:00", "uri": "710363991", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T13:56:00Z", "sim": 0.407843142747879, "source": {"title": "The Independent", "uri": "independent.co.uk", "id": "3441"}, "url": "http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/brexit-theresa-may-immigration-leaving-her-isolated-a7896636.html", "eventUri": "eng-3358827", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3358827", "body": "Brexit is becoming a hall of mirrors. The Government wants to leave the EU customs union but then replicate it. Ministers insist that free movement will end in 2019, but say that EU nationals will still be able to come to the UK.\n\nIrish citizens will continue to enjoy free movement as the Government seeks to recreate the existing soft border on the island after Brexit. Despite Theresa May's notoriously tough stance on immigration, the Government said there was \"no question of new immigration checks operating between Northern Ireland and Ireland\". Its position paper published on Wednesday raised lots of questions about how to stop migrants getting into Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK via Ireland but provided few answers.\n\nThe proposed two-year transitional phase after the UK leaves the EU in 2019 gives the Government a breathing space to bring some sense to its wider immigration policy. Officially, May remains wedded to the discredited target to reduce net migration below 100,000 a year. But I have never known a government policy supported by so few members of the Government. It is May's target; her ministers barely pay lip service to it.\n\nBrexit Secretary: UK wants temporary EU customs deal\n\nAmber Rudd, the Home Secretary, did not even mention the target when she belatedly asked the independent Migration Advisory Committee to review EU migration last month. It might have been better if Rudd had asked these experts to look at the target, since they might well have buried it for good.\n\nAnother nail was hammered in its coffin by Ruth Davidson, the impressive leader of the Scottish Conservatives. \"The time for easy slogans is over,\" she wrote in The Daily Telegraph last week. \"We have to ask whether the target is the right one.\" She joined calls for overseas students to be taken out of the migration figures. Again, it is only May's obstinacy which prevents her ministers doing so.\n\nI have been writing about the \"tens of thousands\" goal as part of the Drop the Target campaign by The Independent and the Open Britain group, which urges a soft Brexit. It is nice to see we are not alone. The Sun, not always a bastion of liberal values, welcomed Davidson's important intervention, saying in an editorial that the target \"is a random, nonsense figure, probably impossible to achieve without damaging the economy.\"\n\nIt was going to be hard for whoever followed May at the Home Office but Rudd is now making her own mark. She struck a conciliatory tone when launching the review, hinting that free movement would continue at least for the transitional period. Rudd seems to have formed a highly significant alliance with Davidson, whom she met privately in Glasgow recently. The Scottish Tory leader would probably back Rudd to also succeed May in Downing Street. (My sources tell me Davidson will not be running Jacob Rees-Mogg's leadership campaign).\n\nMay clings to the migration target as an insurance policy against claims that she is not delivering on the demand for more control over immigration in last year's EU referendum. But there is new evidence that she might not be as in tune with the mood of the country as she thinks.\n\nIn pictures: European Parliament Brexit discussions 12 show all In pictures: European Parliament Brexit discussions 1/12\n\nEuropean commission member in charge of Brexit negotiations with Britain, French Michel Barnier listens at the President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker speaking at the European Parliament in Strasbourg\n\nGetty Images\n\n2/12\n\nFrank-Walter Steinmeier, President of the Federal Republic of Germany, delivers his speech at the European European Parliament during a debate on Brexit priorities and the upcomming talks on the UK's withdrawal from the EU\n\nReuters\n\n4/12\n\nMichel Barnier, European Chief Negotiator for Brexit reacts during a meeting at the European Parliament in Strasbourg\n\nEPA\n\n5/12\n\nMember of the European Parliament and former leader of the anti-EU UK Independence Party (UKIP) Nigel Farage wears socks with Union Jack flag at the European Parliament in Strasbourg\n\nGetty Images\n\n6/12\n\nNigel Farage, United Kingdom Independence Party (UKIP) member and MEP, addresses the European Parliament during a debate on Brexit priorities and the upcoming talks on the UK's withdrawal from the EU\n\nReuters\n\n7/12\n\nEuropean commission member in charge of Brexit negotiations with Britain, French Michel the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE), addresses the European Parliament during a debate on Brexit priorities and the upcomming talks on the UK's withdrawal from the EU\n\nReuters\n\n10/12\n\nGetty\n\n11/12\n\nGerman president Frank-Walter Steinmeier delivers a speech during a plenary session at the European Parliament in Strasbourg\n\nGetty Images\n\n12/12\n\nThe European Parliament in Strasbourg, eastern France\n\nGetty Images\n\nThe British Future think tank and HOPE Not Hate campaign have visited the first 24 towns and cities of 60 where their \"National Conversation\" is holding citizens' panels. Anyone can contribute via an online survey (www.nationalconversation.org.uk). It is part of a wide-ranging inquiry into immigration by the Commons Home Affairs Select Committee, which is aiming to find common ground in an often polarised debate.\n\nThe group discussions so far show that most people have a balanced view of immigration: there are concerns about pressures on schools, the NHS and housing, neighbourhood decline and the enforcement of immigration rules but also recognition of the benefits. Even people worried about the impact of low-skilled EU migration in their area accept the economy needs immigration. Many acknowledge that migrants keep the NHS going. While some people worry about numbers, there is support for the level of migration to remain about the same.\n\nThe findings suggest that politicians would do well to follow Davidson's lead by spelling out the national economic benefits of migration in order to put the local pressures in context. But after feelings were whipped up by the Leave campaign last year, few Conservatives are willing to make the case.\n\nBrexit is the right time to press the re-set button on immigration. There should indeed be a national conversation about both the pressures caused by immigration and its benefits. In place of an arbitrary target that ministers admit privately will not be hit, a forward-looking new policy should be driven by the needs of the economy rather than by the politicians' need for a headline.\n\nMore about: Brexit Customs Union transitional deal EU immigration Reuse content", "id": "9496229", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Theresa May's immigration target is
